name: President. –
text: Tomorrow this Parliament will vote against the persecution of sexual minorities in Chechnya. I call on the responsible authorities to stop this violence, to release those who are still illegally detained and protect potential victims. I urge them to honour their international commitments on respect for fundamental freedoms and the fight against discrimination. Today is International Day against LGBTI Discrimination. On this day we must reaffirm our strong commitment to combat all forms of discrimination in the world, including those based on sexual orientation.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the statements of the European Council and the Commission on the European Council conclusions of 29 April 2017 [2017/2628 (RSP)].

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, Members of the European Parliament, I would like to report the outcome of the first formal meeting of the European Council of 27, which took place on 29 April. Our main purpose was to adopt political guidelines for the Brexit negotiations, a mandate that sets out the overall principles, objectives and process, and a mandate that the European Council will update as necessary, as the talks get under way. A key element of the guidelines is the need to conduct the talks on the basis of a ‘phased approach’. This means simply that there will be no discussion of the framework for our future relations with Britain before sufficient progress is made on ensuring an orderly withdrawal. Leaders fully supported this logic.  To ensure an orderly withdrawal, we first and foremost need to address the situation of more than four million people whose lives will be directly impacted by Brexit, on both sides. In a very real way, their futures depend on the outcome of these talks. It is our particular responsibility to secure the best guarantees for citizens – citizens of the Union – and for their families. That means guarantees that are effective, enforceable, non-discriminatory and comprehensive, accompanied by simple and smooth administrative procedures. There is a need to act quickly, and so we are ready. Now we must move from sharing objectives to actually ensuring that citizens get the necessary guarantees. That is also why I welcome the fact that the Commission has already listed a number of detailed requirements. The second priority in the first phase is the need to agree that all financial commitments undertaken by the EU of 28 will also be honoured by the UK. And thirdly, in order to protect the peace and reconciliation process described by the Good Friday Agreement, we must aim to avoid a hard border between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland. Only once there is sufficient progress on these priorities can we proceed to the next phase of the negotiations, about our future relations. And it will be for the European Council of 27 to assess and decide if, and when, we have achieved sufficient progress. When it comes to our future, the European Council shared the United Kingdom’s desire to establish a close partnership. It is obvious, however, that the relationship between the European Union and a non-Member State cannot offer the same benefits as EU membership. It is clear that a free trade agreement between the EU and the UK, which is what the UK has chosen, even if it is ambitious and wide-ranging, cannot mean participation in the Single Market or its parts. And at the same time, the UK must be aware that any free trade agreement will have to ensure a level playing field, and encompass safeguards against unfair competitive advantages through, inter alia, tax, social, environmental and regulatory measures and practices.  Today it is too early to tell much more about our common future, but we will make our guidelines more precise when the time comes, namely when sufficient progress in the first phase is achieved. Leaders responded with the urgency that the situation requires. There will be very little time to conclude withdrawal talks within the framework foreseen by the Treaty. Time is of the essence here, and much is at stake. Next Monday, the Council will adopt a set of negotiating directives, proposed by the chief negotiator on the basis of the guidelines we adopted on 29 April. These cover the three issues I have just mentioned, plus a number of other matters that need to be addressed in the first phase of the negotiations. Since the referendum in June last year, we – the EU27 – have been united, consistent, and demonstrated solidarity with one another. What was, and remains, most important for me, is that our conduct in these talks will show the European Union at its best: in terms of unity, political solidarity and fairness towards the United Kingdom. Finally, I can only praise the European Parliament and its leaders for the role they have played. Sincere thanks and appreciation for your constructive assistance. This bodes well, not only for the future of the negotiations, but our future as a Union of 27. (Applause)

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. - Mr President, Mr President of the European Council, dear colleagues, As is customary whenever I address this house, I will speak in all three of our important working languages. I will start in English by congratulating President Tusk on last month’s European Council. I have attended more summits than I care to remember and never have I seen agreement reached so quickly. I can assure you that this does not happen by accident. It is in fact testimony to the work of all Member States and all EU institutions, the work they have done together since last June. Michel Barnier and his team have been up and running across Europe to make sure every voice is heard. I would like to pay tribute to him. I won’t wish him luck for the negotiations, as I know he will leave nothing to chance. This is exactly the same approach that President Tusk and I have always taken. The Council Conclusions from April and the draft negotiation mandate proposed by the Commission earlier this month speak for themselves. I am confident that the draft mandate will be adopted by the Council next Monday, 22 May. The process shows how united and prepared the European Union will be. It underlines how deep our commitment to transparency already is. This is why I see no need this morning to go into any more detail on the negotiations. Michel will do this later on this morning. This negotiation is now in the hands of our capable divorce lawyers. Mr President, Ladies and Gentlemen, I would like to stress that on the sidelines of this European Council, we have been able to conclude three important agreements which confirm that it is often in the margins that the best pages are written. The first agreement between Denmark and Europol is particularly important for the security of citizens, as it will allow a sufficient level of cooperation to be pursued, in particular on the exchange of operational data. The second agreement concerns Portugal and Spain on the issue of the temporary deposit of nuclear waste at Almaraz and, finally, the third agreement with Slovenia and Croatia makes it possible to find operational and field solutions to better manage border controls and the application of Schengen rules between these two countries. In each of these negotiations, the Commission has built bridges between sometimes distant positions by encouraging the continuation of the discussions until they bear fruit. Without the Commission, these three agreements would not have seen the light of day. It is often said that the Commission should take care of its own problems and that it should not take care of the problems of others, but if it does not take care of the problems of others, they remain whole. In this, these three agreements say much more than long speeches. Europe is this constant effort to build bridges, seek agreements or find compromise solutions. This is also the task that the Commission has declared itself ready to take on and will continue to apply. I would like to thank this Parliament very much for the constant support it gives us in this mission. Herr President, meine sehr verehrten Damen und Herren! Diese Einigkeit, die wir beim Europäischen Rat unter Beweis gestellt haben, wird während der gesamten Brexit-Verhandlungen unser Leitprinzip sein. Dies ist im Interesse der Bürger und der Bürgerinnen, so wie es auch in ihrem Interesse ist, dass wir uns nicht auf die Brexit-Fragen exklusiv konzentrieren, probe unser Programm umsetzen. Das werden wir auch mit Hilfe des Parlaments tun. In der ersten Hälfte des Mandats der Kommission haben wir, die Kommission zusammen mit Ihrem Parlament, viel erreicht - viel erreicht auch dadurch, dass wir stets an einem Strang gezogen haben. So haben wir nicht nur den Investitionsplan in kürzester Zeit zum Erfolg werden lassen. Schon jetzt hat er Investitionen in Höhe von 183 Milliarden in 28 Mitgliedstaaten mobilisiert. Wir haben auch die Europäische Grenz- und Küstenwache eingerichtet, mit der wir unsere gemeinsamen Grenzen auch gemeinsam besser schützen können. Gleichzeitig haben wir mit dem Handelsabkommen mit Kanada einen großen Schritt nach vorne gemacht. Dieses Abkommen sichert Arbeitsplätze und stellt klar, dass europäische Normen und Standards international Geltung erhalten. Das sind nur drei Beispiele, um Ihnen in Erinnerung zu rufen, dass wir mit vereinten Kräften vieles gemeinsam schaffen können. Diese Einigkeit im Denken und im Handeln wird auch in der zweiten Hälfte der Amtszeit dieser Kommission an den Tag zu legen sein, beispielsweise im Zusammenhang mit der Errichtung eines wirklichen digitalen Binnenmarkts. Wir haben dazu bereits alle 35 angekündigten Vorschläge auf den Tisch gelegt. Einige davon müssen allantdings noch in trockene Tücher gebracht werden. Dazu brauchen wir die aktive Mitarbeit des Parlaments. Wir müssen die zweite Halbzeit dieser Kommission, die ja auch die zweite Halbzeit Ihres Mandates ist, dazu nützen, Ergebnisse zu liefern, damit die Menschen wieder spüren, dass Europa ihnen etwas bringt. Daran werden wir uns bei der nächsten Europawahl messen lassen müssen. (Beifall)

name: Manfred Weber
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, my honorable Presidents, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, congratulations on taking one of the quickest decisions in the European Council on such an important issue! One can only congratulate them. I would like to do this primarily in the direction of Donald Tusk, but also of course in the direction of Michel Barnier, who was commissioned by Jean-Claude Juncker to take on this task. The preparatory work was excellent, the matter is in good hands with Michael Barnier. The preparation in Parliament - Guy Verhofstadt and Antonio Tajani - our preparatory work was valuable for the process. We are united, we are united, we can be proud of the fact that the European Union, the 27, stand together. We have made a clear statement about how we envision the method of first talking about the exit, then about the new relationships. We have given the cherry-picking, which some in London still imagine, a clear rejection. Anyone who leaves the European Union can no longer take advantage of this Union. And we have formulated a clear expectation, namely that over 78% of Europe's citizens expect the Brexit negotiations to first talk about EU 27 interests before we talk about other issues. That gives clear backing for this mandate, which has now been decided. Therefore positive. We in the EPP Group are pleased about that. One thing is still important to me, namely to describe that the family sticks together. We were with the group in Ireland last week to signal to the Irish citizens, in view of the conflict over the question of how the border will be shaped in the future, that they cannot stand alone, that they can build on solidarity in a network of 27. It is an important reassurance for the people there that they are anchored in the family. I would like to But today, because we are agreed on Brexit, above all take a look at the political situation in Europe. And I would like to remind you that a few months ago - at the beginning of the year - all the right-wing members met in Koblenz, the nationalists, the anti-Europeans and Marine Le Pen, for example, announced that 2017 would be the end of a world and the birth of a new world will be. So she announced it there. She's not even there today. I don't know what she's doing, but she's not here today. I want to look at it again. What actually happened in 2017 since we had these noble announcements from the anti-Europeans? I hold that Farage's party - UKIP - is leaderless, has no chance, is politically dead in Great Britain. I experience that Nigel Farage is cowardly because he does not run for the British House of Commons at all, does not care about responsibility, does not want to take any responsibility at all. I see that his policies are causing borders to be drawn up again, namely in Northern Ireland and Ireland. I think he still tries a lot to talk to his friend Donald Trump on the phone. I don't know if the talks are still going on because Donald Trump is doing a lot more other things than worrying about Nigel Farage now, but obviously Nigel Farage's approach has failed across the board. The history books will say that he wreaked havoc on his homeland with his way of doing politics. Then to the other participants in Koblenz: Wilders remained far below his expectations in the Netherlands, the AfD in Germany does not know how to deal with the neo-Nazis in its own ranks and cannot find a clear line of demarcation. And then of course France: Le Pen failed, historically it had the second worst result in all runoff elections in France retracted. Le Pen refuses the rule of law, hides here in the European Parliament from the French judiciary. Le Pen can no longer get her own family involved in politics, and 56% of French say they are afraid of the politics Le Pen makes. Ladies and gentlemen, this is what is left of this populist approach that we saw there. Populism has failed, and 2017 is an opportunity for us to make a new start for the European Union. A good balance so far for Europe! 2017 is a key year, yes! That is why the first meeting that we have now experienced on Monday between the newly elected President of France and the German Chancellor, because the Franco-German partnership is so important, is a positive sign, a sign of departure, a sign of hope. I would like to thank that we all agree that for the next two years we will not focus on Brexi, but on the future of Europe. Last but not least, I would like to say: when we see this momentum that we now have for 2017, the most important thing is that we finally talk positively about our European Union again, talk about what we are achieving. Let's look at the world situation: We are now debating in America whether the Paris Agreement will be terminated. It was we Europeans who put climate protection on the world agenda. Last year, thanks to the work of the Commission, we had more economic growth in this European Union than the Americans. All over Europe we have the principle that we have health insurance, we take care of everyone who is sick. And in America, Obama Care is being phased out and 24 million people are losing direct access to health insurance. And we have shown in Iran that we have big questions, namely the question of nuclear weapons, too Can solve diplomacy.I think that we Europeans shouldn't just talk about our crises from time to time, we should talk about our successes.That is what convinces people best of Europe.(Applause)

name: Roberto Gualtieri
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the rapid adoption of the guidelines for the UK withdrawal negotiation is a very important achievement, a sign of unity to which this Parliament is proud to have contributed with its resolution and significant involvement in the work. which led to the drafting of the final text. Anyone who thought we would split up made their accounts wrong. The European Union now has a clear, balanced and fair line towards Brexit and an excellent negotiator that we strongly support. We want a fair deal, which protects the interests of citizens, respects the principles and obligations arising from our treaties and allows us to have the UK as our close partner in the future, even if of course a non-member will not be able to. never have the same benefits as a Member State. To obtain these results it is essential to make the best use of the little time we have available and therefore the negotiating sequence indicated in the guidelines is essential. First of all, ensure an orderly withdrawal of the United Kingdom, making substantial and sufficient progress on some fundamental issues as soon as possible. We know them well: citizens, financial settlement, safeguarding the peace process in Ireland. On citizens, which is priority number one, we appreciate the very clear words of the guidelines and the proposed directive. We are talking about all British and European citizens who live and have lived, who work and have worked in the UK or in the Union. We are talking about a set of interconnected rights, which also concern social security, the freedom of movement of workers, the recognition of professional qualifications. We are talking about rights that must be guaranteed forever to those who are entitled to them, with full reciprocity, without discrimination and under the jurisdiction of the Court of Justice. European. Our Parliament is determined and no discussion on future relations with the UK can begin, no agreement can be approved if these conditions are not respected. And we are convinced and confident that whichever government emerges from the elections, on the basis of these principles, constructive and efficient negotiations can begin, allowing us to give certainty to European citizens and businesses and to define a positive framework for future relations between the Union European Union and the United Kingdom. The European Parliament and our group are ready to actively contribute to this result and also, above all, to seize the great opportunity we have to work together for a revitalization of the Union. We are not satisfied, we are proud of the state of the European Union but we are not satisfied, we want the Commission and the Member States to be courageous and make significant progress on the path that this Parliament has helped to identify. More investments, more reforms, more solidarity, more democracy. We are ready for an ambitious journey and we ask everyone to do their part.

name: Raffaele Fitto
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, sometimes, especially in politics, words have their weight and those spoken in recent weeks, if followed by facts, would be a real boulder on relations between the European Union and Great Britain. The Brexit negotiations cannot be marked by a spirit of retaliation and punishment against the UK and its citizens, who are preparing to leave the European Union but not to leave Europe. Whatever the views in this House, we need to be clear and unanimous on one point. It is in the interest of both sides to come to a fair and win-win agreement. Our citizens must be our priority, it is on their rights that we must reach an agreement as soon as possible and then examine fundamental issues such as trade agreements, because it is not simply the regulation of a relationship between the European Union at stake and a future third country, but there is much more. At stake are issues that directly affect jobs, lives, families, the safety of people in an era marked by diverse and lasting terrorist threats. This we must always keep in mind. It will not be an anger-driven Brexit that benefits both sides. Brexit is not a punishment, it should be based on the creation of a relationship with the United Kingdom that allows us to re-evaluate the functioning of the European Union, which allows us to understand why British citizens felt they were better off outside the European Union than inside. Despite the election results, and I also want to say this for the things I heard this morning, which may have made many in this House breathe a sigh of relief, let us ask ourselves why millions of British citizens first, Dutch and French then, but not only that, they felt the need to vote for parties or instances so strongly anti-Europeans. This is the question we should ask ourselves in this House. It is therefore time to look in the mirror, let's not make the mistake of telling ourselves that people want us to continue on this path, to continue in this way, people want a change of direction and concrete answers. So the theme is to take the opportunity of the negotiations that will take place between London and Brussels to discuss ourselves, the fate of the European Union, and to do this, as a group of conservatives and reformists, we have long supported the need to review the treaties, that is, to establish new rules of the game to make this Union more open and flexible. Now we read that the French President Macron and the German Chancellor Merkel want to change the treaties, but that is not enough, it is necessary to say in which direction the treaties must be changed. If the direction is "less Europe, more flexibility, more fiscal competition, more respect for national parliaments", then the direction is right. If, on the other hand, the direction were once again, as we unfortunately fear, that of "more Europe regardless, more rigidity, more fiscal homogeneity, more centralist impositions than Brussels" would be the worsening of the existing. Let's put aside feelings of rejection and self-preservation and see how we can really change, how we can get out of Brexit stronger and more efficient and with renewed confidence, especially on the part of our citizens. This is the work and commitment that we as a group of conservatives and reformists will carry out.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I think on Brexit everything has been set: we have a mandate and the European Union, the 27 other Member States and the three institutions have a unified position. Everything is also going well with the negotiation directives that will be approved on Monday. So I think there is only one thing to do now: to start the negotiations, and to start them as fast as possible. Yes, we have to wait for the outcome of the British election, but after 8 June let’s start.  I want to talk about something that is related to Brexit, and that is the future of the European Union and the reform of the European Union, because it would be a mistake to put all our energy only into Brexit in the coming years. At least the same energy, if not more energy, has to be put into the reform and the future of the European Union. Three times in a row now, the nationalists and the populists have been beaten – in Austria, in the Netherlands and in France – and I don’t think that happened by accident. I think that Brexit played an important role in this. People all over Europe have been shocked by the decision of Great Britain to leave the European Union. Don’t misunderstand me; people are today very critical towards the European Union – and for good reason – but what they don’t want to do is what Britain did: to leave the European Union. It’s very clear that the Austrians didn’t want an Auxit, the Dutch didn’t want a Nexit and the French didn’t want a Frexit. They say: reform the European Union, yes; leave the European Union, no bloody way. That is the message of the people of the European Union today.  But there is one mistake we cannot make, and that is to think ‘oh, it’s over; populism and nationalism have been defeated’ – and I have heard this reaction all too often in European circles – ‘Macron won, Le Pen lost, relief, let’s go to the normal agenda and let’s do business as usual’. Well, I think that is the one mistake that we cannot make. People voted for Macron for change and not for the status quo; not for a standstill. They voted for a radical change in France, but also in Europe, and so the best thing to do is in fact to back his reformist agenda – a reformist agenda that we all know now. A reformist agenda with the new European budget, minister of finance for Europe, European treasury, European investment bonds and the transnational lists that he is proposing.  I have to tell you, Manfred, that I was relieved to hear on Monday the positive reaction in Berlin: a reaction a little bit different from the ‘nein, nein, nein’ of Mr Schäuble and of a lot of German press since the arrival of Mr Macron. I like more Merkel’s ‘Wir schaffen das’, as she repeated at the press conference with Macron. So I think it is really time now to use this Brexit negotiation for a new vision, Mr Tusk, and for a new future for Europe. It is, in fact, a future that our young people want: look at what is happening – Pulse of Europe in more than 100 cities all over Europe, in the squares, young people are coming together and asking for more, and a democratic, European Union. What do you call this? I call it audacity. To paraphrase Danton: ‘De l’audace, encore de l’audace, toujours de l’audace et l’Europe sera sauvée.’

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mister President! I would like to share this hope and this euphoria that it is enough to be more courageous when it comes to rescuing the European Union, and there is no doubt that we are still faced with this question. The perspective of many people on the consequences of Brexit is important. It is also important that conclusions are drawn from this, also on the part of the citizens themselves, that they say: We have to get involved. We have to show ourselves which EU we stand for. We cannot just leave it to the institutions, the governments. It is our EU, it is our living space, our future, and we have to fight for it. I would ask that we use the entire debate on Brexit, including the negotiations on Brexit, to also realize that it would be too easy to stand up after the elections in France and the Netherlands and to say: Authoritarian populism has failed. It didn't fail! We still have to see what a high proportion of people are willing to choose this form of authoritarian national populism. And here we can only counter something by saying: This European Union has a value in itself, but we have to constantly renew it. There is no social system that has a claim to eternity. If we do not protect it, if we do not stand up for it, if we do not renew it and if we do not repeatedly take up the questions that concern many people, then we will fail. Incidentally, Brexit also reveals the points at which we can definitely start positively. Who of the many people who have made decisions knows - that goes as far as the trade unions - that we have a social security system that we have to expand, not to cut back. When we talk about the Freedom of movement is important, then it must not only apply to posted workers. Then in future it must also apply to everyone who lives in the European Union, and we must not begin to want to secure the social systems only for the citizens of our own nation, to want to isolate them. We will only achieve a change in the European Union as a possible social union by opening up the national social systems - then we will also come to a common European pillar. I would also like to give this to those who are now placing the European pillar in the foreground, because what we are seeing there can only be the very first approaches, it does not go far enough at all, because ultimately the counter-movements are already emerging Member States are coming. If, for example, the CSU declares that it does not agree with parental part-time work, that it would like to block it in the Federal Council, then I consider that to be a huge problem. How do we want to solve this if z. For example, the reaction in Germany to the offer to Great Britain even before Brexit was that we in Germany are also thinking about how we can reduce the claims of employees in our country to child benefit and already have the corresponding plans in the drawer. We have to rely on precisely these points. Let us develop it together into a solidary, social EU in which the question of sustainable economic development must of course also be in the foreground, but not against the people, but with them. And that is my reply to you, Mr Fitto, because that is a different concept for the EU from the one that you are promoting.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is fortunate that the Council and Parliament have been able to largely agree on a mandate for negotiations with the United Kingdom, one without revanchism or naivety. We are particularly pleased that the preservation of citizens' rights, endangered by Brexit, has been put at the top of the list of priorities. But what does Brexit tell us? Did we learn a real lesson from this? I hear people reassure themselves that we have avoided the worst in Austria, the Netherlands and France, but I would like us to avoid any triumphalism. National populist forces are now reaching considerable electoral levels. When we add that to abstentions and invalid votes, we can see to what extent the confidence of our fellow citizens in their institutions and in their political representatives is shaken. The cause, besides a feeling of loss of identity, downgrading or fear of downgrading. Even quite recently, the International Monetary Fund confirmed to us that globalization and especially technological change are the main causes of the loss of the share of labor income in wealth, a wealth which is increasingly unequally shared. In the face of this, a shy realization seems to be emerging, even in Davos, even in the WTO and even in the Commission. We are beginning to understand that our economic system leaves many fellow citizens by the wayside. But do you seriously think that, for technological change and globalization to work for the benefit of all, it is enough to give each and everyone a training that makes them employable and that then it suffices to "activate" the workers without employment, that is to say to put them under pressure, this same pressure which pushes them more and more to vote for the parties which surf on anger and stir up fears? Rather, we think that in a world where increasing inequalities seem to be inevitable, where machine work increasingly replaces human work - an MIT study shows us that each installed robot eliminates seven human jobs - and where technological platforms "à la Uber" are increasingly precarious work, we must completely rethink both the organization of work and our taxation and ensure robust social protection for all, and not just - if you will allow me - shareholders. Likewise, rather than a race to the bottom under corporate pressure, globalization must aim to increase, level up social, environmental and democratic standards. It is under these conditions that we will show that we have learned the lessons of Brexit. It is on this condition that we will not content ourselves with containing, but that we will stem the dangerous tide of withdrawal into oneself, because then our fellow citizens will regain confidence, certain that their interests are defended. It is then that, armed with this regained legitimacy, we will be able to proceed with a deeper integration of the European Union, which is the only way for us - I mean the only one - to take our destiny back in hand.

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, imagine you invited a very important guest round for dinner, you had made all the preparations, there were some very important confidential conversations that needed to be had and you thought everything had gone well, and yet within hours your guest had told the outside world that you, the host, were deluded – that you were living in a different galaxy. And then all the contents of the conversation were blabbed to an opposition newspaper, and to add insult to injury, you say the food was actually not very good either. And then a few days later, in a display of extreme petulance, you even deride the national language of the host – which, by the way, is looking a bit silly, because last Saturday’s extravaganza known as the Eurovision Song Contest saw 90% of the songs sung in English.  If you were the host and you had been treated like that by somebody that you thought was important and somebody you thought you could trust, I think you would be asking yourself whether you were dealing with a reasonable person. I do not know, Mr Juncker, whether this is how you carry on in Luxembourg – I doubt it, because in any other part of the civilised world, frankly, that behaviour would be considered bloody rude and the act of a bully – but I will tell you something: your attempt to bully the Brits through this negotiation is not working. Sixty-eight per cent of the British people now want Brexit to happen, and all of that on top of a ludicrous ransom that Monsieur Barnier wants, which I am told has now doubled to EUR 100 billion.   Either we get some grown-up reasonable demands from the European Union or the United Kingdom will be forced to walk away before the end of this year. We cannot spend two years with this farce. There is a big, big world out there. I very rarely agree with Marxists, but I am beginning to think that perhaps Mr Varoufakis is right when he says about negotiating with the EU that it is a technocracy that is desperately clinging on to its own exorbitant and illegitimate power. You may have crushed Greek democracy two years ago, but you ain’t going to do it to us.

name: Marcel de Graaff
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (NL) Mr President, on 29 April the Extraordinary European Council confirmed that European integration has brought peace and prosperity to Europe. How often do the elite keep repeating this myth? Prosperity in the EU has been developing dramatically for ten years. The high unemployment is hopeless. The debt mountain sky high. There is no prospect of improvement. Ukraine is at war on our eastern border thanks to EU interference. In Turkey there is a dictator who receives billions in support from the EU. The state of emergency has been in force in France since November 14, 2015. The UK has reached the right conclusion and has left. And the EU should too. Let the EU disband itself. The biggest issue of the British is mass immigration and the closing of national borders. When will that happen in the EU? When will the NGOs that are doing good business with people smugglers in Libya be prosecuted? When will the economic migrants be dragged hard back to the Libyan coast? I say to Juncker: close national borders and resign.

name: Steven Woolfe (NI).
text: – Mr President, we now know how the EU 27 leaders plan to negotiate with Brexit. On first glance it appears reasonable but, like everything the EU says, on closer inspection you can see the malevolent intent of an EU that tempers no opposition to its control. Like a playground bully, it says no Member State can talk to the UK separately, like an emperor it grants Spain a veto over Gibraltar, and like a jilted spouse it says the UK cannot go out and get a new trade partner until the divorce is finalised, or else. But for those in this Chamber who want to bully us, threaten us or demean us, may I remind you of the English poem by Rudyard Kipling about a Norman king warning his son about taking advantage of the English: ‘The Saxon is not like us Normans. His manners are not so polite. But he never means anything serious till he talks about justice and right. When he stands like an ox in the furrow – with his sullen eyes set on your own, And grumbles, “This isn’t fair dealing,” my son, leave the Saxon alone.’ So when a French President says Brexit is a crime, we will say: we will not be imprisoned by your rudeness. When a Maltese President says the UK deal must be an inferior deal, we will say: no deal is better than a bad deal. When a German President says that without the EU, Britain cannot have its voice heard in the world, we will say: listen to the sounds of a free Britain, an independent Britain, an outwardly looking Britain, trading, growing and expanding in the world, looking forward and not backwards.

name: Herbert Reul (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Mr Presidents, my dear colleagues! The assessment of Brexit is clear. The point now is to deal with it properly and properly, above all effectively. I think the way it's been going so far can also become a model for how we work together. Barnier and the troop prepared it thoroughly. Parliament, Council and Commission have looked for common ground and found common ground. Thoroughly prepared, been concrete, worked practically, formulated common ground and then in the end also strong in the negotiations. If we did the same with other topics, we would give people what they are looking for. You are not looking for a new dream or any new concept or any reforms. I don't think so, they are looking for the result. They are looking for successful European politics, they want to see that the worries they have are resolved by us and dealt with as far as we can. Besides, we cannot solve everything; part of the responsibility also rests with the Member States. But the prerequisite for this is that the European institutions and above all the Member States work together and find common solutions. The answer that can now be derived from Brexit and from what the people who take to the streets and think Europe is great again is: We have to make new plans. Or as my colleague has just said: organizing even more regulation is totally wrong. We have to deliver very specific results. We have to prove that European politics serves the prosperity, the well-being of the people in Europe, that it makes sense to go this way. The Brexit negotiations as they begin now are a very, very good contribution to this. That is sober, that is pragmatic, that is not pretentious, there is hardly any dream dances on the way, there is also no insulting British on the move.In this sense: it can become a model or model for the way in which we will work together in the future.Thank you for the kind interruption, Madam President.The previous speakers were able to talk for hours longer.Maybe we do the same with the upper class as we do with the others.(The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: blue-card question. – We are often warned that maybe the interpreters have got it incorrect, but I don’t know if they got it correct when you used the word ‘troops’. If you did, I do not think it is an appropriate word, when you talk as a German MEP talking about negotiation with Britain about their freedom and sovereignty, to use the word ‘troops’ given the damage troops and wars have caused to this continent. Were the interpreters correct? If they were, please withdraw the word ‘troops’. We have had enough troops and enough war on this continent.

name: Herbert Reul (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Madam President!Colleague, if I really said that, I definitely didn't mean it, and then I apologize.That's crystal clear.I believe that the European Member States, organizations and institutions work together.I didn't mean anything more.

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we have a clear and consistent line to deal with Brexit. So this is good news and it creates good conditions for our negotiators to start their work. In this way we can also devote more energy to dealing with our own future. In both things, Brexit and our own future, the concern with citizens should be our central focus. When it comes to the roadmap for the future of European Union, the starting point to define the roadmap is to build up a convincing social pillar addressing the concerns of our peoples, but particularly young people, when they are dealing today with the so-called ‘digital revolution’. We need to make sure they have a proper contract and full access to social protection. We need to build up welfare systems for the 21st century. Then we also need to address our citizens’ concerns when we set new trade agreements in order to protect proper social and environmental standards. We need a new generation of these trade agreements. Again, we need to address citizens’ concerns when managing the migration and refugee crisis because we know that the real solution for this is to address the root of the problem by supporting neighbourhood development and peace building. All of these must be translated into a community budget of the future. Our task is immense, and that is why we should work now with a real focus on a scenario which is not one or two of five, but should be a simple one: let us work together for much better solutions on the relevant priorities.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR).
text: - Madam President, today I will follow the example of Mr Juncker and address the hemicycle in French. The UK wants a clean and serious partnership with the European Union. We want full agreement on our economic and security relations. We want the European Union to be well and prosperous after our departure. We want to protect the rights of European citizens who currently live in the UK, as we are convinced that our partners will also want to protect the rights of UK citizens in Europe. When it comes to payments, of course we will respect our legal obligations, but you won't have to invent such huge numbers to fill in the gaps in your budget. We do not want border controls between Northern Ireland and Ireland. However, it is difficult to imagine how this will work without knowing what kinds of commercial relationships we will have. The sooner we start negotiations on a free trade agreement, the more likely they will be successful. Madam President, let us work together to build a new relationship that benefits all our citizens.

name: Catherine Bearder (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, five million European citizens are living their lives in constant frustration and a legal limbo. It is a state of anxiety for thousands of EU and UK citizens, with 7% reporting depression, some even suicidal. This is intolerable. The two parties in Brexit need quickly to agree to guarantee EU citizens’ right to reside. This is about treating people with dignity, allowing them to plan their lives, their learning and their loves. The British Government must stop blaming and start acting governmental: no posturing, no calculating, a ‘right out of the gate’ comprehensive agreement. All that is needed is one bold and generous political act, and British agencies must tear down the barriers they have erected which are causing daily frustration and fear for so many people. Outside the convention of ‘nothing is agreed till everything is agreed’, we need a comprehensive right to reside agreement first and we need that very, very quickly.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the Council’s guidelines on Brexit give support to the Good Friday Agreement in all of its parts, and that is crucially important. This is a commitment by the EU to not allow for any hardening of the border between the north and the south of Ireland. It is a commitment not to allow Irish and EU citizens like myself to be dragged out of the EU against our will. It is a recognition that the north of Ireland is not an internal matter for the United Kingdom, and a commitment that the people of the north will never again be left at the mercy of a ruthless and reactionary British Government in London.  Now that we have the guidelines, we should be putting some flesh on them regarding no hardening of the border in Ireland and fully upholding the Good Friday Agreement in all of its parts. There should be no weakening of this commitment in the negotiation directive that is to be adopted next Monday. Brexit is incompatible with the Good Friday Agreement. Brexit is the worst thing to have happened in Ireland since the last disaster in Ireland, which was the British partitioning of Ireland.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – As someone who does not want to see a hard border on both sides of the Northern Irish/ Irish border (as you know, my wife’s family are Irish citizens), I understand much of the emotion that runs around that place. But surely we need to look back to the common travel area agreement which was first made between the Republic of Ireland, the United Kingdom and, indeed, the other islands across the British Isles. The first one was made just after the birth of the Irish Free State, so why can we not negotiate a new common travel area after Brexit on a bilateral basis? We do not need to worry and concern so many people. This special relationship, I believe, is between Britain and the Republic of Ireland.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: blue-card answer. – Can I say to you that the Common Travel Area does not resolve the Brexit disaster that will happen in Ireland, and you should know that better than most. So be very clear. You talk about renegotiation. Last week, Tony Blair talked about renegotiating the Good Friday Agreement. That is a no-go area and the Common Travel Area does not solve the problem. You are deluding yourself if you think that is the solution. The only solution to the Brexit problem is that we have designated special status for the north within the EU, or Irish unity.

name: Alyn Smith (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I would pick up on Mr Guy Verhofstadt’s point about how eurosceptics and populists have been beaten three times in recent elections. Actually, it is four: in Scotland, we saw them off handsomely with 62% of the vote in favour of remaining within our European family, and we remain in favour of remaining within our European family. Scotland will not be silent, passive, bystanders within this process. I would also urge you that while the people of Scotland want to work with our friends and colleagues across the EU, there is a deliberate wilful agenda within UK politics to misrepresent and demonise this process and the personalities involved within it. We have heard it today: ‘do not give them more ammunition, do not give them what they want’. This is them getting their excuses in early – ‘Brexit would have gone great except for those bloody foreigners’; that is the narrative they are trying to kid the British people with. Do not give them what they want; it is not in Scotland’s name. As for our guidelines, I read them with a heavy heart, but I see little to dislike. I would urge the suspension of the ‘nothing is agreed till everything is agreed’ principle for citizens’ rights. You could give real impetus to this by committing to an early agreement on this issue, and we could make that work now for all of our citizens.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD).
text: - Mr President, well, it is in this Chamber that there is an unspoken motive in the air, like making the exit mechanism for the British as difficult as possible so that others never and under any circumstances even think that it is possible to leave the European Union. It reminds me of the times when the Lithuanian people had already expressed their desire to be free and independent. Lithuania also talked about the orderly withdrawal from the Soviet Union and many other things were talked about. How many billions does it owe for the occupation, how much it has obligations to its great homeland, and how they will have to be covered if Lithuania actually leaves. Most surprising is the provision advocated by the Council: if the United Kingdom is no longer subject to Union agreements after accession, what is the logic and reason for requiring Britain to comply with all its international obligations as a member of the European Union after accession.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! I don't understand why Britain's exit from the European Union cannot be negotiated as it would among adults. They act like taking something away from a small child and throwing stones at Britain. That's the wrong way. True political greatness is much more evident from the fact that democratic referendums are appropriately acknowledged. Mr Weber, who today again incited against patriotic parties and who actually belongs better to the Greens than to the European People's Party, I would like to write one thing in the register: Netherlands minus 50% for the government, plus 30% for Geert Wilders, France from the state 34% for Marine Le Pen. And Mr Weber's party did not even play because the candidate François Fillon drowned in a swamp of corruption. Make no mistake! These patriotic parties are now on their way to the middle station, and they continue undeterred to the top.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: - Madam President, despite the injections of optimism for the future of the European Union that have been heard in here, the sharp contrasts are present and sharpening. The Brexit Council guidelines aim to shield the European Union's position in the international competition of its groups with Great Britain, the United States and China. Whether there will be trade agreements between the European Union and Great Britain before or after the settlement of their accounts is not in the interests of the peoples. Because they will be asked to pay any bill again, whether the monopolies of the European Union or of Great Britain benefit more. After all, in the name of new sacrifices to favor British capital after Brexit, ballots are being set up in Britain to gain the consent of the British people to its new massacre with new anti-labor measures. Similar measures apply in the European Union. Only by overthrowing capitalist power or liberating a country from the European Union or NATO and any imperialist alliance can it free the people from the shackles of exploitation.

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE).
text: - One day in Irish Wicklow was enough to make tangible for us the consequences or costs of Brexit for a country which, after joining the European Union, became a symbol of economic success and reconciliation under the patronage of Brussels, supported by a program that is rightly called PEACE. Ireland is a good case study of the no-fault costs of Brexit, but also the tip of the iceberg. Each country has its own Brexit agenda, there are ramifications everywhere, from Gibraltar to Poland. For my country, of course, the most important thing is the status of the hundreds of thousands of people who came to the Islands in search of a better life through work, not through the exploitation of social systems, but fell victim to a lying referendum campaign. There are different agendas, but the Union of 27 countries very quickly found a common negotiating platform - this is a good sign, it is a sign of unity in the face of this big challenge, which are the consequences of Brexit for the European Union. We are now estimating costs, but not only costs, because - as Max Weber or Guy Verhofstadt said - in 2017 we look at Europe with greater optimism. There are fewer potential followers of Brexit, there are more and more people who understand the value of a common Europe in the global world, so there are also good consequences.

name: Richard Corbett (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the European Council guidelines set out much more clearly than anything the British Government has produced what the issues are in these negotiations. We still do not know, nearly a year after the referendum, what the British Government hopes to achieve in terms of access to the single market and the Customs Union, in terms of how it intends to protect British farmers if they are no longer part of a common market with an agreed system of subsidies across Europe, or what is going to happen to British fishermen. We do not know what is going to happen to British participation in the various technical agencies – the Aviation Agency, the Medicines Agency, chemicals and so on, whose certifications are a requirement for selling in the single European market. We only have silence from the British Government, yet there are nearly a thousand issues, more than a thousand issues, that need to be settled in this negotiation. We still do not know what the British Government’s intention is. Far from providing strong and stable leadership, Ms May is actually providing desperate and deluded leadership to the British people.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: - (NL) Mr President, since the Brexit vote, we have seen people digging in on both sides of the channel, unfortunately. Propositions are involved. And people who you would hope to be self-contained and reasonable would also add fuel to the fire. I am thinking, for example, of Commission President Juncker. But, mind you, Brexit is going to hit the lives of many people hard. It's not an abstract discussion of the order of negotiation or anything. For thousands of Europeans, it is about the question: "Will I lose my job, yes or no?". Let me give you an example. Fishing may be a small sector, but the consequences can be disastrous for many family businesses and coastal communities out there. The Dutch, for example, fish 50% of their catches in British waters. This access must be guaranteed. The European Union is there for the people, not the people for the European Union. Therefore, let everyone involved be constructive in order to reach a reasonable compromise. We really need each other before, but certainly also after 2019.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Mr Weber said that the winds of change are blowing through Europe. I do not disagree with him – change is on the way. Mr Fitto from the ECR mentioned change; Mr Verhofstadt mentioned change; and apparently there is a process underway to decide what that change will be called the White Paper on the future of Europe. However, to know what the winds of change are and what direction they are going in, you must consult with the people. We were told last March that we would be consulted with. We were told that there would be a series of Future of Europe debates to harvest and harness the opinions of the desired way forward. Last week, I met Commissioner Hogan, and he knew nothing about this process. Yesterday, I asked Jean-Claude Juncker at the GUE/NGL meeting where this process is. Nobody can tell me. If the winds of change are coming, surely we should talk to the people. Perhaps Donald Tusk can tell me where these meetings will take place and when the consultation will take place, because, if you are serious about it, you have got to talk to us. Have you any news, because no one can tell me?

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF).
text: – Madam President, everyone seems a bit embarrassed by Mr Juncker and his chief of staff, Mr Selmayr, including Donald Tusk, Ms Merkel and Mr Barnier. You also think that we are being observed by other planets, as quoted in the French press (I can read French). You accuse Ms May of living on another planet, but I think it is you, Mr Juncker, who is just living on your own Juncker planet. You are an embarrassment, Sir, and you should step down. Mr Corbett praises the EU for their negotiating stance, but nobody is listening to his leader back at home. You are going to be annihilated in the polls. You are being run by a Marxist, so nobody is listening to you. Ms Bearder sounds completely and utterly mad, and her party is going to be wiped out at the next general election. But the good news is that 70% of the British public support Brexit. We are a resilient bunch. We won the war for you in this place in World War II. We are not going away, so negotiations in reality will take place with the EU 27. It is business, not you career politicians, that actually [...] (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE).
text: - Madam President, there is no happy divorce, but the process can be less painful if everyone behaves with fairness. The government of Theresa May understood this: in the Council, its representative abstained on the decisions intended to apply after 2019. And now, in quick succession, he vetoed two decisions which are fundamental for the Union, and for her alone. The revision of the multiannual financial framework is postponed and, most recently, the British minister opposed the creation of a European operational headquarters. Considered for many years, this creation is a first step in the implementation of a Europe of defense. Why do you want to weaken the Union the moment you leave it? Our common interest is to have a strong Europe, a privileged partner of a strong UK in all areas. If this attitude is repeated, the 27 will have to get used to working together, not only on the Brexit negotiation, but also on all matters which will no longer concern the United Kingdom. This is not desirable for either side.

name: Jens Geier (S&D).
text: - Madam President, dear Presidents, dear colleagues! Isn't it amazing how insulted some British colleagues in this House, especially those on the right-hand side of this House, are now doing because they claim that EU politicians are attacking and insulting Great Britain as a nation? I believe that is not the case. I myself - and I think that applies to many of my colleagues - at most am always shocked at how unprepared and irresponsible British policy in the Brexit camp is still handling the negotiations and is not prepared to publicize the British To tell the truth that you cannot keep all the advantages of the EU and leave it at the same time. It's so easy when you think about it, but obviously still too complex for the Brexit camp. We are now experiencing a situation in which the British government has taken hostage the compromise that has already been agreed for the MFF revision because it has found a rule to allocate six billion euros to these decisions for the political goals of the European Union, doesn't have to agree. I hope that the British Government will be very true to its word and, after the general election, will allow this positive decision to be put back on the agenda. And from here I urge British politicians not to take the MFF compromise hostage.

name: James Nicholson (ECR).
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to say I welcomed very much Mr Barnier’s visit to the Republic of Ireland that last week and his very clear message on how difficult this process is going to be. Let us be under no illusions: solving the problem of the border, be it a hard border or a soft border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland, is going to be massive. Be under no illusions about that, though I welcome the attempts and his clear spelling out of that problem. But I want to also make clear that politicians in Dublin or Brussels do not speak for the people of Northern Ireland. Northern Ireland will speak for itself, and the people will decide for themselves. They are an integral part of the United Kingdom, and they will decide where their future will be – nobody else and none of this process will do so. While I make that very clear, I do so with a degree of sincerity, so that everyone understands where we stand. But I am extremely concerned at the way in which this process is going. I am very concerned that we now have megaphone diplomacy across the English Channel, instead of cool heads sitting down and realistically looking at how we are going to solve these problems in the future between us. We want good relations between the United Kingdom and the rest of Europe, and I sincerely hope that both sides can realise that as this process goes forward and work to achieve that.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, you cannot be talking about Brexit as if those who have been governing for years had no responsibility, when Brexit is a direct consequence of the policies of Mr Cameron, but also of Mrs Merkel or Mr Juncker. In short, of the great coalition that governs Europe. His austerity policies resulted, in the UK, in labor reforms, higher university fees, or more privatization of healthcare. They bet on institutional racism, pointing out the migrant as the cause of all the evils. And now that the exit is being negotiated, their main concern is how Brexit will affect business. For us, the red lines are different and very clear. In the first place, guarantee the rights of those who are in the United Kingdom working, Spaniards and from many other countries, and vice versa, also of people from the United Kingdom who are living in other countries. And, secondly, to guarantee the rights of cross-border workers, as well as the future of the entire population of Campo de Gibraltar.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: - Madam President, not everything is Brexit: on 4 December last year, we Europeans beat the extremists in Austria; on March 15, in the Netherlands; On May 7, we did it again in France. The political color of those who won does not matter, what matters is who we beat: we win those who call Europeans from other countries foreigners; We win over those who want to build walls again and close borders; We win over those who campaign by appealing to fear, hatred and resentment. The political battle that Europe is waging is not left against right, it is not Christian democracy, social democracy, liberals, progressives or conservatives. The political battle that Europe is waging is populism against representative democracy, it is Europe against "Anti-Europe." This year and next there will be elections again in Germany, Austria, the Czech Republic, at least in Italy. That is why we must learn the lesson: we must change the Europe of institutions for the Europe of science, education, welfare, security, the rule of law, legal immigration, plurality ... Too many times we have confused Europe with its institutions. Europe is not its institutions, it is much more. The time of institutional inertia has passed with Brexit.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: - Ms. President! We all know that Brexit was a victory for populism, demagoguery and lies. There are also MEPs sitting in this House who took an active part in deceiving the electorate and believing that selfish national interests were more important than common European values. And, of course, to see how deeply this campaign and referendum divides British society. That is why I wish the people there to be able to overcome the division, because further hatred and enemy search will not heal the wounds that have arisen. After April 29, we can see more clearly the principles, the course and the stages of the negotiations. I consider it particularly important to maintain a close partnership with the United Kingdom in order to preserve the integrity of the single market and the freedoms that come with it. But above all, the situation of European Union citizens living and working in the United Kingdom and of British citizens living in the European Union needs to be clarified. They have been living and working in a high degree of insecurity since 23 June 2016. We must strive for the most detailed agreement possible on the various civil, economic and social rights, based on the principles of reciprocity and equal treatment, because even if this kind of legal continuity cannot be guaranteed, we will finally pull the ground out of all forms of future cooperation.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would have liked to see the United Kingdom remain within the European Union but the citizens have decided and this must be respected. But now it is important that we stay close, because we will have to fight side by side, the European Union and the United Kingdom, all the challenges we face, from economic ones to terrorism. So it is good that in first place there are the four million people who, as President Tusk recalled, on both sides will suffer the consequences of Brexit, but we must be on the side of all citizens, always, for this we must return to roots of the European Union and therefore, as we negotiate Brexit, we must renew the pact. The pact was for peace, for well-being, for solidarity. Today, however, we see too many, too many selfishness. We live these days as days of daily life, we must instead be aware that we are living in a historical moment and that the decisions we make today will have a long-term duration, so it really takes courage.

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D).
text: - Madam President! We talk about Brexit, and we remember: EU bashing was a popular sport in Great Britain for years. Actually, we were responsible for everything that didn't go so well. And now: The EU wants to punish the British. Oh man! Of course, I understand the concerns of many people. Living and learning to work all over Europe is one of our greatest achievements. And yes, we say: it might not work in the future. Because you're out. Get out of the internal market and thus out of the European freedom of movement, out of joint research projects and out of the common fight against organized crime and terrorism. And yes, you can terminate a contract, but of course the financial commitments you have made continue to run. But that's all, if we say that, no punishment. Rather, we name the consequences - the consequences of a resolution that reads: We want out, we want out of the EU and thus out of all areas. Hence my request to Theresa May: finally put an end to this negative legend! Pour pure wine for your citizens! Only in this way can a good new start be achieved for future relations between the EU and the United Kingdom.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen! I was in Northern Ireland and Belfast last week and in conversations with civil society I noticed the extent of desperation there the more they think about the consequences for them. I hope that there will be a bit of realism in London after the elections, that you know that if there is a hard Brexit, it will be a disaster for the people in Great Britain and especially in regions like Northern Ireland. For this reason it is necessary to be prepared to also constructively accept the responsibility that has been taken on, including the financial costs and the rights of citizens, and much more such as the Irish question. In any case, we should constructively achieve a result that is only possible with realism, in order to keep the damage for both sides under control, and we should not inflate ourselves nationalistically. I also learned that Europe can win elections again. Europe needs to be told to campaigners, and Macron and others are an example: Europe can win elections. And that is why we must all together, including us Germans, help to make Operation Macron successful, in order to advance Europe.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Of course, I agree that the priority of today's Europe is Brexit and resolving issues, but I think we have other challenges, that we face other priorities.It is important for us to realize that terrorism has not disappeared from our lives, that it is still with us.We also need to dust off the 4 freedoms that are the basic pillar of the EU.See if they are really respected in all areas.I believe that one of those fundamental challenges is the challenge of common security, perhaps common defense for the future.Borders that are still leaky and migration that is pushing our outer border.Last but not least, our common challenge is also to partner with the countries in our neighborhood.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are all sorry for Brexit, but we must be realistic, remain lucid and decide in the best interest of the common good. The fate of the European Union is at stake as well as that of the United Kingdom. The particular interests of the Member States cannot prevail at any stage of the negotiations and to this end it is good that they are conducted in a transparent manner and as a single package. Yes, the hope is that relations with the United Kingdom will remain close, but we must pay attention to the messages we send out. The four freedoms of the single market are indivisible and convenient choices are not admissible. A country outside the Union that does not respect its obligations cannot have the same rights and enjoy the same advantages as the Member States. Negotiations may also establish transitional arrangements, but extending legal uncertainty beyond measure will not benefit the interests of the Union which, even without the desire for revenge, must first of all return to giving a precise direction to its political action.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr Tusk and Mr Juncker, again "spectators in the same work"! Once again we heard big words calling for the continuation of the same policy, "business as usual". Mr Tusk and Mr Juncker, you have dealt little with the causes that led citizens, and especially young people, to a harsh critique of the banking system, the Brussels bureaucracy and the European and global establishment. The people of Europe, Mr Juncker, are calling for a change in production model. They demand a fair distribution of the wealth produced in the European Union, social justice, a social Europe and the abandonment of austerity, because only then will there be an army of unemployed and millions of poor people. They demand the citizens of Europe, Mr Tusk, a Europe of solidarity, a Europe of nations and homelands, a Europe that respects the national sovereignty of its Member States, a Europe of peoples and not of banks and creditors, a Europe that supports the principle of Community preference and abandons globalization, TTIP and CETA, which lead millions of European citizens to marginalization.

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE).
text: - Madam President! I think we all regret Brexit. But if Brexit was good for something, it was for people to really think about what Europe actually means. Not only in Great Britain was Googled afterwards: What does the EU mean, what does it mean to belong? And since then we have really seen many pro-European movements among the population that we as politicians might not have been able to initiate. In Germany there is Pulse of Europe, where people take to the streets on Sundays and demonstrate peacefully for Europe, so to speak. Elmar Brok has just said: Macron won elections with Europe - so it works. I really want to go back to what Birgit Sippel said: It is actually the case that no punishment is being carried out by Great Britain - it shouldn't be like that, it shouldn't be like that, but the fact that the exit is still being negotiated hard must become. And I also think that what Ms. Sippel said is just as crucial: The truth must be told, because before the referendum, the British were not told the truth about what could potentially mean Brexit. That is precisely why, I think, it is so crucial that at least one is open to one another now, at least in order to be able to interact peacefully in the future.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, the decision of the British people must be respected without intimidation or pressure on the negotiations. Any agreement between the Union and the United Kingdom must ensure that social rights, labor law, public health and environmental standards are not compromised. It is very important to guarantee all the rights of European citizens living, working or studying in the United Kingdom. We welcome the reference to the Good Friday agreement, the support for the peace process and the reference to the fact that there should be no hard borders. However, on the other hand, the Brexit decision should concern European leaders, as it reflects the serious problems of the Union, expresses the dissatisfaction of the citizens for the neoliberal policies promoted and the abuse of the rights of workers and peoples. That is why Brexit should not be used as a pretext to legitimize the deepening of the neoliberal model and the multi-speed Europe.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Madam President, the post-Brexit negotiations enable the European Union to protect, among other things, the rights of its approximately three million citizens who live, study and work in the UK. The vast majority of these people are young and fear that their lives will be ruined. They feel very insecure and that is why they need to be protected. Those who want to work in the UK in the future should not be expelled or hindered. The same, of course, will be the case for British citizens living in other European Union countries. Finally, regarding some positions that have been heard here that 'supposedly' nationalists have been defeated, at a time when in all the countries where elections have been held these factions have either increased their numbers or doubled them many times, this view is a strange one. form and perception of mathematics, such an unreal form that if the ancient Greek mathematicians, Pythagoras and Euclid, two and a half thousand years ago had it in mind, they would probably make their own "math-exit" to be able to preserve the their dignity.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I welcome the more conciliatory approach I have detected here this morning. If you continue with that, I think we can have mature and sensible negotiations and a proper conclusion. I would also like to thank Mr Barnier for coming to the EPP Bureau meeting in Wicklow last week and for taking time out to speak to the Dáil (the Irish Parliament), and indeed visit the North. In relation to the North, if the European Union, Ireland and the United Kingdom do not want a hard border, then why should we have a hard border? I just want to correct one thing: it has been incorrectly stated that Tony Blair said we needed to renegotiate the Good Friday Agreement. What he said was that the Good Friday Agreement came into being on the assumption that both Ireland and the UK would be in the European Union, and that we needed to reword it when the UK leaves. He did emphasise that he was not talking about changing the substance of the Agreement.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: - Madam president. Mr Tusk, Mr Juncker, there is no use lamenting Brexit if we are unable to draw the lessons and point to those responsible. It is useless to celebrate that in Holland and in France there was no nexit or frexit, because on both occasions, as in the United Kingdom, the extreme right, charged with hatred against Europe, grew spectacularly. Due to an unfortunate campaign in that referendum, the Europeanists voted very little and very weakly, while the anti-Europeans went to vote with great force and with great anger. And the reason is simple, and it is because the European Union has turned its back on citizenship, and we still have time to give an answer to those millions of European citizens who reside in the United Kingdom and want their rights protected and, reciprocally, to British citizens residing in the rest of Europe, many of them in Spain. I am thinking of the young; in those young people, many of them Spanish, who work in the United Kingdom and want the European Union to protect their rights. Because, otherwise, the threat is a growing disconnection of youth and European citizenship, which will leave the European Union without a future.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, Brexit is a big blow to the European Union because it has shown that the affection of a good part of citizens cannot be bought with European funds, group tours of European institutions and funding of NGOs that spread a positive story about the European Union.The result of the referendum was a great sobriety, after which difficult words fell.Unnecessary, but somewhat understandable.I am glad that things are slowly calming down, because if it is already leaving the European Union, the United Kingdom is not leaving the European continent.Our cooperation continues, only in a slightly different form.This form should be defined as soon as possible to the mutual satisfaction, but we must avoid harsh words and blackmail.Let us keep in mind that the destinies of millions of people depend on this agreement, and let us not make the already unenviable situation difficult for them by irresponsible behavior and collecting cheap political points.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, it is customary to say that the worst blind person is the one who does not want to see. To those who are quick to see in the elections in France and the Netherlands an expression of popular support for the European Union, we recall that the parties that defended and applied the policies of the European Union were heavily penalized by voters. It is true that some, covered in new clothes, now want to perpetuate the same old policies. Sooner or later, they will have the fate of their predecessors. As for the worrying advance of the extreme right, it must be measured not only by the electoral expression of the parties that represent it, but also by the dissemination of its principles, values ​​and conceptions, and its assimilation by other forces from the political spectrum from the right to the social- democracy, discourse and community practices, acceptance of the restriction of rights, freedoms and guarantees, including economic policies that favor big capital and generate profound social injustices. In the history of peoples, there are no dead ends. The alternative to the extreme right is not, cannot be, the policies and politicians that open the door to the extreme right.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Madam President, today I have sat in the European Union Chamber here in Strasbourg, listening to the debate on the conclusions of the European Council meeting of 29 April this year. Quite frankly, the level of ignorance displayed in the comments made by MEP colleagues has been astonishing, and also frightening. But I am not surprised: as a Member of the European Union Committee on Constitutional Affairs, all I see and hear is the one perspective of pro-EU, and calls to penalise the United Kingdom. There is never any balanced or non-partisan exploration of the Brexit aspect, the contribution the UK makes financially, defence- and security-wise, or why the vote went the way it did. Now 68% of the United Kingdom want Brexit concluded, and I have every faith that after 8 June the United Kingdom Prime Minister, Theresa May, will deliver and put the United Kingdom, its citizens, its economy – and rightly so – in the forefront of this.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Mr Tusk, you started the presentation with something that I really like and I ask for and we ask for it too: that the citizens, the four million citizens, should not suffer and I think it is a wise decision of the Council. . The second important point is related to the agreement that will be between the United Kingdom and the European Union. No one should be punished, but we must be careful: yesterday we debated globalization here. It is very important that this agreement does not suffer the internal market of the European Union. There must be an agreement on the win-win principle. Companies in the European Union should not suffer. Last week, President Juncker was in my country and saw that Romania is pro-Europe.
