So we need to protect the citizens and make a trade agreement that benefits both parties, and we really don't need the citizens who voted to stay in the European Union in the UK - because here it is spoken as if all citizens from the UK would have wanted to leave - I want the citizens of the UK to be protected as well.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I think it is very simple: I think the best trade agreement for the UK is actually membership of the EU itself, but they have excluded that option so we have to find a fair deal now for everybody. I also think it is very important that the EU is reflecting on the future of Europe, and we must deliver better and take people’s concerns much more seriously. First, we need to end social dumping in Europe and ensure decent salaries and workers’ rights throughout our Union. Secondly, we need to end tax dumping: we see multinational corporations and rich people evading taxes on a scale that is damaging our welfare state in Europe. Finally, we need to transit our economy, for our society to become sustainable, responding to the climate challenge, ensuring our environment and ensuring that we manage migration and our welfare state in a much better way. If we do that, we will have a stronger Union and I hope that we will have a close relationship with the UK; we need a fair deal with them. I think they are punishing themselves by saying no to being a part of Europe.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Ms. President!I do not dispute the representation of the principle that the Brexit negotiations should not be punitive against the British.However, in order to make our own citizens clear, it must be made clear that in the eyes of all anti-integration politicians and the European public, irresponsible anti-EU political tactics and threats have a specific price for the nation's historical chances, economic and political development.At the same time, I would like to draw attention to another context: namely that the European Union's principle that the Union's institutions must look after the interests of all European Union citizens, including the British, also applies during the Brexit negotiations.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: - Madam President, indeed British citizens have decided to leave the European Union, to varying degrees moreover, since Scotland and Northern Ireland did not vote in this direction, which is sure tocomplicate negotiations.We deeply regret it.I would nevertheless like to recall here the destructive role played by UKIP in this operation and I would like to be remembered for our duty to fight all the extremists who actually want to destroy this organization which arose out of the will for peace in Europe.Now we have to settle scores between the European Union and the United Kingdom.Neither British citizens nor European citizens should be victims of this Brexit.Mr Chief Negotiator, it is just as important to preserve the European institutions as it is to preserve citizens' rights, in particular those linked to freedom of movement.

name: Michel Barnier
text: chief negotiator. - Mr. President, good morning to each and every one of you. My first words will be to thank your Parliament, its President, but also Guy Verhofstadt, later, for your numerous expressions of confidence in the mission entrusted to me and for the spirit of cooperation that reigns. from the start between us. And I would like - as I have just done for Parliament - to say a personal word of thanks to President Tusk, to his cabinet and to the General Secretariat of the Council because, from the start - it is no accident that we are so quickly reached an agreement in the European Council - patient, tenacious and sincere work of cooperation is being carried out between us. Here's how we're going to build that unity along the way. President Juncker, who was the first to trust me, then recommended that the European Council, through negotiating directives, adopt in detail the guidelines and modalities of this negotiation. On May 22, in a few days, the General Affairs Council will have to confirm this negotiating directive. President Tusk has made it clear how we are going to undertake this negotiation in stages and in sequences, under the authority of the European Council. And he made it clear that we must first find an agreement on the principles of the three big topics, ladies and gentlemen, on which the sovereign decision of the United Kingdom to leave the European Union today creates a very big uncertainty. We must remove this uncertainty as quickly as possible for the citizens first, for the beneficiaries of the European budget and for the borders, in particular in Ireland. Frankly, this sequencing is not done to create problems or to punish the UK in any way. This sequencing is done to organize and solve problems, as it is written in the treatise: "to organize the withdrawal ordered taking into account the future relationship ”. The orderly withdrawal is precisely these three major subjects and a few others, such as the governance of the agreement or administrative and judicial proceedings. Ladies and gentlemen deputies - I tell you as a negotiator - this sequencing has another interest: to create the bases of confidence. We need to build from the start, solving these problems for citizens, for beneficiaries of structural funds and for borders, the foundations of lasting trust which we need to build the future relationship with the UK. This is the condition and I repeat to you that our objective is to reach an agreement. The options of no deal or a bad deal are not mine. We want to achieve an agreement with the UK, not against it. Moreover, I would appreciate it if the British side would get into the spirit of reaching an agreement with the European Union and not against the European Union. We will begin this negotiation as soon as possible, the day after the election Theresa May called on June 8. The fact that the elections take place just before the start of negotiations clearly gives our British partners the stability and visibility that we also need. This is, I believe, one of the elements of the success of this negotiation. The trust that I mentioned and that you all recalled has a counterpart on our side, it is that we will practice with you, with the other institutions, with the Council, transparency and be permanently available for involve the institutions and your Parliament throughout the round of negotiations. This is how I will be at your disposal, that is to say at the disposal of the entire team that you have appointed with Guy Verhofstadt and yourself, Mr President, to discuss before and after each of the negotiating sessions and, in the same way, the whole task force team that I was able to put together thanks to the daily confidence of President Juncker and all the Commission services will also be at your disposal. Likewise, we are ready for very high transparency on all negotiating documents, which will be made public. I would like to telegraphically respond to several of the questions that have been raised by all of them. On citizens' rights, Mr Weber, Ms Grapini, Ms Gardini and even Mr Fitto - who is not here - spoke of a fair and balanced agreement. At the start of this negotiation, we have an ambitious position set by the European Council, which is fully legitimate, since we demand that European citizens and British citizens affected by Brexit can continue to enjoy the same rights. This will apply to citizens, to their families, and it will be all rights: right of residence, freedom of movement, right of access to social security, right of access to the labor market. We are talking about the rights that will be acquired until Brexit day, of course, and we will also ensure that these rights are effectively guaranteed. We will not be able, on this very serious subject, which affects the daily and personal life of many families, to be satisfied with a simple declaration of intention. On the financial regulations - and I'm glad Mr Farage is here because he quoted me - I have never quoted, Mr Farage, any figures as far as I am concerned. Because these figures will depend on the methodology on which we have to agree and they will also depend on the effective date of the UK exit. It’s not Mr Barnier who is going to set a figure. We will work, as the European Council wishes, to find with the British, serenely, calmly, an agreement on the commitments that have been made. There is no penalty, there is no exit bill. We have made, particularly in this period of the current financial perspective, financial commitments together, at 28. We assume them financially together, at 28, and we benefit together, at 28, for all regions of the Union European, for universities, laboratories, students, farmers. It is a question of settling accounts as one does in any separation, no more, no less, and I will do it without emotion, without spirit of revenge, without punishment, by sticking to facts, figures and commitments. that were taken, no more, no less. On Ireland, where I had the privilege of visiting last week and being received by both Houses of Parliament together - Mr Kelly and Mr Nicholson spoke of this visit which touched me a lot and which was very useful - it is a unique situation which calls for unique solutions, which must not call into question the integrity of the internal market. We will do everything to find a solution which clearly and fully preserves the Good Friday Agreement in all its dimensions, which I recall - but Mrs Anderson or Mr Brok raised this issue - that the United Kingdom is co- guarantor. I just want to say a word about the transitional periods that Mr Caputo mentioned. We may be working on transitional periods after Brexit, after the UK departure, namely phase-out and phase-in periods for the future relationship. But the real transition period is now, before withdrawal, between now and the day of withdrawal. And I recommend all economic players, in particular, to use this period well so that the withdrawal, on the day it will occur - probably in March 2019 -, is as orderly as possible. But I would also like to say clearly to Mr. van Dalen, who mentioned earlier some specific questions such as those of fishermen - whom I know well from having been Minister of Fisheries in my own country -, to Mrs. James or to Mr. Vilimsky, something that everyone should understand: it was the United Kingdom that decided to leave the European Union and not the other way around. And many of us regretted this decision, but now we have to implement it. This decision has consequences and those who would say or who say that everything can continue as before are not telling the truth. We are going to have to unravel - because this is the UK's decision - forty-four years of integration, of economic, financial, technical, legal, human, social relations. Forty-four years! No one should underestimate either the consequences in all areas, or the legal complexity of this separation. I really recommend this if we want to tell the truth to citizens, and it is our duty to explain it to them. I also recommend calmly, pedagogically, democratically, that we explain what Brexit means - as I did in my speech, Mr Nicholson, last week in Dublin - what it means to be a member of the Union ”and what“ no longer being a member of the Union ”means for the daily life of citizens, consumers and businesses. We must tell the truth to citizens. And I also recommend that we take the time to explain to those who talk about no agreement what it means - I mean in the conditional - that there is no agreement at all. I recommend that we take the time to explain this to citizens, and not just to the UK. Ladies and gentlemen, we will work, as the Council wishes, in stages, to build a new partnership, a new relationship with the United Kingdom. Ashley Fox earlier raised this issue with great wisdom. This relationship - he is not too early to sketch the outline - will include a free trade agreement, free and fair trade, cooperation agreements, particularly in terms of universities or research, and a partnership, as we wish, in security and defense. There are two important points for this future relationship. We will never accept that a free trade agreement leads to unfair competition or to the lowering of our social standards. This is a point that the chairperson, Ms. Zimmer raised, but also Ms. Rodrigues, Mr. Sylikiotis and Mr. Kofod. We will not agree to lowering social, fiscal or environmental standards in the European Union, nor will we want to agree to haggle over security on trade issues. Richard Corbett talked about the complexity, especially of agencies, but I won't come back to that. I would just like to conclude with a more political word as we prepare to begin this negotiation which has not yet started - and the clock is ticking, time is running out to get to a good deal. I would like to come back to the point that Mr Niedermüller, Mr González Pons, and Mr Lamberts alluded to earlier. There are the consequences of Brexit - and I will have, on your behalf, to deal with most of those consequences in this negotiation - and there are the lessons of Brexit, which are different. I think that, in this regard, we have to listen to a number of reasons which have been expressed by British citizens, as indeed in other countries expressed in protest votes a feeling of incomprehension, of anger , social suffering and the feeling of being excluded from progress. I think, ladies and gentlemen, and I say it like the politician that I always am, that we should not confuse populism with popular sentiment. And I believe we all have an interest in listening to popular sentiment in this matter, as one of the lessons of Brexit. Finally, I would like to say to Mr. Gualtieri and Mr. Weber, who spoke about unity, that this unity that we have built together, under the authority of President Tusk and with the confidence of President Juncker and that of President Tajani, is important to me as a negotiator - because I need it - and that I will be careful to ensure that it is maintained, nurtured, cultivated, throughout the process. This unit must be able to be used - if I may say so - by heads of state or government, by institutions to do other things, because Brexit is not the whole radar screen of Europe. There are so many challenges to take up, such as those mentioned, in particular by Mr. Lamassoure, on defense, security, border management, the single market or even the euro zone. So I wanted to say as a negotiator - it is very important that everyone understands this - that we need this unity that we have built on negotiation. This unity is going to be useful for the rest of the European agenda and you and EU leaders, mobilized on a positive and proactive agenda on the other challenges, will strengthen the unity which I also need in the negotiation. This is an interactive unit that we need and that is why I really thank you for your trust, ladies and gentlemen.

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Members for their words of support in today’s debate. Until today, I had not witnessed such unity on the matters that I report here before Parliament. Our unity is the most important condition for a positive outcome from the negotiations. Thanks to this unity we will also be able – together with the leaders – to deal in the coming months first and foremost with the positive agenda for the Union of the 27.  I agree with my friend, Guy Verhofstadt, that this should be our priority – not Brexit. Today I will meet President Macron in Paris, and I am really happy that – also thanks to you and to this debate – we will be able to devote our meeting to the future of the 27 and not only to Brexit.

name: Le Président. –
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: written. - Finally, on April 29 the 27 unanimously adopted the global principles of the EU for the next Brexit negotiations and on May 22 the opening of the negotiations will be authorized, although officially the negotiations will begin after the British elections of the next 8 of June. I am pleased that the guidelines adopted by the European Council reflect the position of the European Parliament and, in particular, the priorities of the Socialists in relation to a phased negotiation, in which priority is given in the first phase to providing the greatest clarity and certainty potential legal advice to citizens, businesses, stakeholders and international partners on the immediate effects of the UK withdrawal. Furthermore, I am pleased that for the Council it is also essential to guarantee reciprocity for the rights deriving from EU law, on the date of withdrawal, of EU and UK citizens and their families who are affected by the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the Union.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – The deal that is negotiated ensures that neither European citizens and nor the British people are affected negatively. However, the only way we can ensure a fair deal is to ensure full transparency and public participation. We have to ask citizens what their concerns are, we need to be listening to students who want to safeguard their education, we need to act on the concerns of European workers who are based in the UK, who have settled with their families and created lives that cannot be torn apart by this decision. There are families that will be divided if there is a hard border between Ireland and Northern Ireland. We stand with these families and we are emphasising that we will support them. We must safeguard their interests, and make sure that the decisions being made not only take their needs into consideration but put them at the forefront of our debate. Brexit gives us the opportunity for a fresh start to revitalise Europe. The future of the EU and the reform of the EU should be a priority. We need to use the Brexit negotiations to make sure that we ensure a better future for Europe and our youths.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – Although it is difficult to forecast the results of the negotiations between the UK and the EU, Brexit will definitely allow the UK to reduce ambition in its climate, energy, environment policies – possibly in the form of the targets/standards. Or targets remain unchanged, yet the EU cannot exert its enforcement powers anymore, which can result in implementation deficiencies. This is particularly true in the areas of biodiversity, water and waste management, air quality and energy transition. As for the elements of the circular economy, the UK might be reluctant to put in place measures for cutting the use of natural resources, for waste reduction or for better recycling. Any steps in this direction would send a bad signal to specific Member States who consider some of the EU law too much of a challenge. Thus, the erosion of environmental standards in the UK after Brexit may have a harmful spill-over effect for other regions of Europe. Therefore, I call on the Commission to give environment policies priority during the negotiations and make sure that environmental and human health considerations play an important role in the future relations between the EU and the UK.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: written. - Finally, on April 29 the 27 unanimously adopted the global principles of the EU for the next Brexit negotiations and on May 22 the opening of the negotiations will be authorized, although officially the negotiations will begin after the British elections of the next 8 of June. I am pleased that the guidelines adopted by the European Council reflect the position of the European Parliament and, in particular, the priorities of the Socialists in relation to a phased negotiation, in which priority is given in the first phase to providing the greatest clarity and certainty potential legal advice to citizens, businesses, stakeholders and international partners on the immediate effects of the UK withdrawal. Furthermore, I am pleased that for the Council it is also essential to guarantee reciprocity for the rights deriving from EU law, on the date of withdrawal, of EU and UK citizens and their families who are affected by the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the Union.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing.- On 29 March, Donald Tusk received a letter of notification from the United Kingdom officially announcing its intention to leave the European Union.This was followed by the first meeting of the 27 members of the European Council on 29 April.In today’s plenary, Donald Tusk personally reported on the outcome of the meeting, where work was under way to develop a guide to Brexit.The 27 members of the European Union look forward to the start of negotiations in full agreement, which should take place as soon as possible.We will wait patiently for the parliamentary elections in June, but then the negotiation process must begin.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: In written form. - The Council of 29 April laid the foundations for a difficult process for the European Union. Britain's exit will have a long-term effect on both the United Kingdom and the Union and its citizens. The choice, expressed in a referendum 11 months ago and confirmed by Britain's political elite, must be respected, despite the false allegations used in the campaign of right-wing and far-right political forces. As a representative of European citizens, I strongly believe that the European Parliament must uphold the preservation of their rights in Britain, including us Bulgarians. This, of course, can and should be reciprocal. Britain will remain a neighbor of the EU, which means that relations and relations with the Union must remain close, stable and predictable. In this process, the European Union must show unity and the ability to protect the interests of all EU Member States.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: written. - Finally, on April 29 the 27 unanimously adopted the global principles of the EU for the next Brexit negotiations and on May 22 the opening of the negotiations will be authorized, although officially the negotiations will begin after the British elections of the next 8 of June. I am pleased that the guidelines adopted by the European Council reflect the position of the European Parliament and, in particular, the priorities of the Socialists in relation to a phased negotiation, in which priority is given in the first phase to providing the greatest clarity and certainty potential legal advice to citizens, businesses, stakeholders and international partners on the immediate effects of the UK withdrawal. Furthermore, I am pleased that for the Council it is also essential to guarantee reciprocity for the rights deriving from EU law, on the date of withdrawal, of EU and UK citizens and their families who are affected by the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the Union.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: written. - The European Council outlined on 29 April. objectives as a basis for the Brexit negotiations. I welcome the desire to create legal certainty in the negotiations, to ensure the status of citizens and the viability of companies. Whatever Brexit thinks, we now have a historic opportunity to reduce costs and governance in the EU as well. At the same time, we can show that everyone is involved in the savings. Several Member States have already stated that they do not accept the granulation of Britain's net contribution to others. For example, in March 2017, the Swedish Prime Minister Löfven stated that Sweden wants to reduce EU spending by the amount of Britain's net contribution. Good examples of savings are the many benefits offered by the EU, which the Member States cannot even dream of. The EU levies a very low tax on its tens of thousands of workers, often less than half of what Member States levy. In addition, EU child benefits and housing benefits are paid. Also, various transitional allowances, amounting to hundreds of thousands of euros, when, for example, a European Investment Bank resigns to a lower-paid job after a couple of years of work, are unreasonable. Completely additional costs are also caused by the two seats and, of course, the ever-increasing number of agencies and their staff. The EU needs to be more precise in its spending. We need to make sure that the EU does not move towards increasing economic solidarity and federal development. The EU must respect the principle of subsidiarity, that decisions are taken close to the people, in the nation states. Brexit offers a real opportunity for self-examination and correction of EU casting defects. We cannot afford not to use it.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing.- I am pleased that the European Council has adopted the position of the EPP and will put the rights of our citizens in the UK first and foremost in the negotiations on Brexit.Our separation must be friendly and fair.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: in writing. - I welcome the Council's Brexit guidelines. The unanimity of the EU members at such an important and difficult moment for the Community is crucial. Three issues remain the most important: 1. Guaranteeing the rights of those who have built their lives over the years on the basis of the rights resulting from UK membership in the EU. I am referring here both to the British who exercise their right to live, work or study in the rest of the Community, and to citizens of other Member States living in the United Kingdom. 2. Ensuring the stability of the functioning of economic entities through an orderly exit of Great Britain preceded by transparent negotiations. 3. Financing agreement committing both the United Kingdom and the European Union to fully meet the obligations previously entered into. The European Parliament's Committee on Culture will, in particular, follow the arrangements for the possibility of continuing cooperation between universities, with the aim of ensuring the possibility of further funding for joint research projects, study stays and student exchanges. The effects of Brexit on functioning cultural entities cannot be underestimated either.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. - Until the United Kingdom leaves the European Union, it remains a full member and is subject to all the rights and obligations set out in the Treaties and EU law. What happens when he leaves the Union? A State which is not a member of the Union and which does not fulfill the same obligations as a member may not have the same rights and benefits as a member. The United Kingdom cannot just pick a raisin from a pie. The main purpose of the first phase of negotiations on the UK's withdrawal from the EU will be to provide citizens, businesses, stakeholders and international partners with as much clarity and legal certainty as possible as to the immediate consequences of the UK's withdrawal from the Union. An agreement on the future relationship between the Union and the United Kingdom can only be concluded when the United Kingdom becomes a third country. Of course, the way he speaks must take into account the framework of his future relations with the Union. An overall understanding of the framework for future relations will therefore be defined during the second phase of negotiations under Article 50 of the EU Treaty. Given the unique circumstances on the island of Ireland, it will be necessary to avoid a fixed border, while respecting the integrity of the Union's legal order.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: written. - The quick adoption of the guidelines for the upcoming Brexit negotiations are an important sign of the unity of the EU. The negotiations over the next few years will be a challenge that we can only master as a strong community. The most important thing is to give the 3.3 million EU citizens in Great Britain legal certainty with regard to their right of residence, access to the labor market and the continuation of their studies. However, these negotiations must not paralyze the Community, because Europeans rightly expect us to provide solutions to the big problems. If we get bogged down in quarrels with Great Britain, that doesn't change anything for unemployed young people in Europe. Because it is precisely in the fight against unemployment that people want more Europe and a stronger Europe-wide approach, as a current Eurobarometer survey shows. Our job must be to protect the European citizens in Great Britain from the consequences of the Brexit adventure. Brexit will hit UK workers most of all. The existing rights of British employees with regard to working hours, vacation entitlement, equal pay, parental leave and agency work have been strengthened by EU directives. The exit from the community is likely to further promote anti-labor policies in Great Britain.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for a debate on Council and Commission statements on preparations for the G7 summit (2017/2574 (RSP)).

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I will speak on behalf of President Juncker and the Commission on the preparations for the upcoming 43rd G7 Summit.  This is the sixth time that Italy has taken over the rotating G7 Presidency, and every time it has hosted leaders in some of the finest cities Italy and Europe have to offer. Venice, Naples, Genoa, L’Aquila and Taormina will be no exception. This year’s leaders’ meeting will have a new and different feel to it. There will be new and fresh faces around the table and together they will tackle some new and not-so-new questions, many of which go to the very heart of the debate on harnessing and shaping globalisation which we had yesterday in this House.  The EU’s position, going into the G7, is very clear. For us, working together with our biggest partners around the world in a rules-based system is a necessity. We believe in open societies and multilateral solutions, we believe in free and fair rules-based trade, and we see the benefits that it brings. Around one-third of our national income comes from trade with the rest of the world. For the EU, global trade has boosted EU economic growth, with every EUR 1 billion of additional exports supporting 14 000 jobs.  Cheaper imports benefit poorer households first and foremost, but it is not just about economics. The wider need to work together on issues which affect the whole world has become more acute, even since the G7 last met in Japan in 2016. Whether it be fighting climate change, tax evasion or international terrorism, whether it be promoting trade links, sustainable development or global economic growth, the questions of today are global in their very nature.  The G7 Summit will be a crucial moment to deepen our cooperation in all of these areas, but we cannot ignore some of the drawbacks of a more interconnected world. We need to tackle them head-on, because many people around Europe and in other parts of the world are concerned. They worry about high levels of inequality, job losses, and factory closures. They see identities, traditions and ways of living changing in front of their eyes. We have to respond to those concerns.  That was the thinking behind the ideas presented in our reflection paper on harnessing globalisation. We are not naïve free-traders; we believe in open competition based on level playing fields and that is why, when we had to,  we have shown our teeth with anti-dumping measures in response to market distortions or unfair practices. We will not hesitate to do so again and, in order to better equip ourselves, we will need to accelerate our efforts to equip the Union with modernised tools to tackle unfair trade. But Europe must also make the positive case for its place in a global world. When others step back from free trade, the European Union must step forward. Partners such as Japan, Mexico, Mercosur and India are willing to do likewise.  Take for example the ambitious EU-Japan deal that we are negotiating. This free trade agreement would send a powerful signal to the rest of the world that two of the largest economies are resisting protectionism, and that openness to trade and investment remains one of the best tools to harness and shape globalisation and create more economic growth and jobs. EU exporters to Japan still have to pay close to EUR 1 billion annually on customs tariffs and the vast majority of these tariffs would be removed with a trade agreement. EU exports to Japan could increase by more than a third. At the same time, more than 600 000 jobs in the EU are linked to exports to Japan, with Japanese companies alone employing more than half a million people.  These are compelling reasons why we aim to reach an agreement as soon as possible and, in any case before the end of the year. Together we must make sure that the rules of the game best serve and protect our citizens and our societies. That is the message the European Union must bring to Taormina and to our partners from across the world. That is what the European Union will fight for at every level.

name: Carmelo Abela
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, good morning to you all. I would like to thank you for the opportunity to intervene on the subject of the preparation of the G7 Summit which will take place in Italy next week. The G7 leaders, as well as Presidents Tusk and Juncker, who will represent the European Union, will be faced with difficult discussions on various topics of global importance. The international political environment is currently particularly charged, and the truth is that global cooperation can no longer be taken for granted. I refer in particular to the political transition in the United States, which seems to present us with challenges even with respect to basic policy principles which were, until recently, well rooted in the G7. I believe that the mission of European leaders is clear. The aim is to secure the G7’s commitment to keep the global economy open and keep multicultural multilateral cooperation on track. It is also crucial to give a clear signal that securing balanced and inclusive growth remains a top priority. Even if the global economy is showing positive momentum, political uncertainty surrounding the outlook is still very high. Against this background, I believe that the G7 should, in particular, confirm its determination to work together through strong, multilateral institutions, confirm the agreement to use all policy tools, fiscal monetary and structural, to strengthen the recovery and foster inclusiveness, and also to better share the benefits of growth and globalisation. But allow me to expand on a selection of issues of particular relevance to us. I will refer, in turn, to trade, climate, migration and foreign policy matters.  On trade, it should be the European Union’s priority to confirm the G7’s longstanding view in favour of open trade and multilateralism. Indeed, as recalled by the European Council of 10 March, the EU remains strongly committed to a robust trade policy and an open and rules-based multilateral trading system, with a central role for the WTO. The EU will also continue to engage actively with international trade partners, advancing on all ongoing negotiations for ambitious and balanced free trade agreements. I may add that, regarding the latter, the European Council has welcomed your positive vote on the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) and looks forward to its provisional application. As you know, in this House there are strong concerns over the negative effects of trade, economic integration and technological change. We have to take these grievances seriously. However, the solution is certainly not to close our economies. Instead, we need to improve the daily lives of citizens by ensuring that the benefits of globalisation are more widely shared. Beyond that, we must also be able to better communicate the actual benefits of trade to the wider public. This is also something for the G7 to consider.  On climate change, the global community needs to act urgently and move forward with the implementation of the Paris Agreement. The European Union is committed to ambitious global action against climate change and we insist on maintaining global ownership of the Paris Agreement. The EU, and its Members, are playing their full part in implementing the Paris Agreement, both through the development of our domestic policies and in keeping to our commitment to global solidarity. In this context, it is also worth noting that, on 6 March, the Foreign Affairs Council resolved to reinvigorate EU climate diplomacy and to maintain climate change as a strategic priority in diplomatic dialogues.  The Paris Agreement is a major achievement of the international community. It is proving, and it needs to prove, that the transition to climate resilience and low emissions economies, is irreversible. Progress on ratification has been extraordinary, making it possible for the agreement to enter into force less than a year after the COP21 in Paris. In parallel, countries have already started to implement their climate policies, while non-state action by cities, businesses, investors and civil society has continued to expand. The Council is aware that climate will be one of the most challenging issues at the G7 table, particularly in view of the positions expressed by the new US administration.  My third point is on migration. Dealing with the migration crisis has been at the core of the political debate in the European Union, including here in the European Parliament. Naturally, we tend to focus on our crisis in our part of the world, but managing migration is not a European phenomenon, nor solely a European responsibility. It is a global responsibility, requiring collective solutions that are in full respect of our obligations under international law. The G7 is a privileged forum to forge partnerships and launch collective initiatives for an equitable and fair sharing of responsibility. The areas on which we can work together with G7 partners include assistance to most—affected countries of transit, resettlement efforts, the exchange of best practices on return and readmission, as well as increased cooperation on the fight against smuggling and trafficking. We are also committed to taking an active part in the follow-up to the UN Summit on Addressing Large Movements of Refugees and Migration, held in September last year. The EU intends to play a prominent role in the process leading to the establishment of the UN Global Compact on migration and refugees in 2018. We ask all G7 members to engage equally in the consultation phase, as well as in the negotiating phase next year.  Before concluding let me make a few additional remarks on foreign policy matters. The summit will address a number of issues relating to our neighbourhood.  On Syria, we should stress that no effort can be spared to bring the Syrian conflict to an end. All parties, in particular Syria and its supporters, must allow humanitarian access to all people in need, and all parties must ensure full compliance with the ceasefire.  In Libya, it is urgent to advance on the part of inclusive political dialogue and national reconciliation in the framework of the Libyan political agreement.  On a more positive note, one can mention Iran. We support the joint comprehensive plan of action on the Iran nuclear issues, which is an important contribution to the international non-proliferation regime. Continued and full implementation of this plan of action is essential to build confidence that Iran’s nuclear programme is exclusively peaceful in nature.  As for the situation in Ukraine, the EU continues to stand united in the conviction that the conflict can only be solved by diplomatic means. It is necessary to ensure full respect for international law, and especially the legal obligation to respect Ukraine’s sovereignty, territorial integrity and independence. We condemn the illegal annexation of the Crimean peninsula by Russia and we reaffirm our policy of its non-recognition, as well as that of sanctions against those involved. The duration of these restrictive measures is clearly linked to Russia’s complete implementation of the Minsk Agreements.

name: La Présidente. –
text: I will open the debate by starting with the group speeches but due to the schedule and the delay we have taken, I will not accept a blue card in this debate and I apologize for that.

name: Françoise Grossetête
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, this upcoming G7 summit wants to lay the foundations for renewed trust between citizens and those in power. I would say that we also need to build trust between partners, especially as we see more and more of them choosing the path of isolation. The difficulties we experience come from our collective inability to solve problems. All this is a source of democratic mistrust and confidence cannot be restored with incantations. It will only come back with convincing results and concrete commitments. The challenges we face have changed scale, while our modes of governance are still very limited at the territorial level. First, I expect our leaders to ensure that all parties, including the United States, live up to their commitments under the Paris Agreement and adequately finance the fight against climate change. I then expect them to collectively prepare for the risks of the 21st century, whether responding to pandemics or cyberattacks, as the news reminds us that cybersecurity is the Achilles' heel. of the digital transition. I am still waiting for them to take strong and coordinated measures to fight against tax fraud and tax evasion, symbols of this globalization which we spoke about yesterday morning, which is deepening the inequalities that our fellow citizens no longer support and fueling this crisis of trust. Finally, I expect our leaders to put aside the small accounting measures and finally take the measure of the technological revolution that is overwhelming us, with its benefits and risks. Without thinking at the global level, there will be no effective strategy vis-à-vis artificial intelligence or genetic engineering. Together, we must rebuild the foundations of our common home.

name: Pervenche Berès
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Madam President, the European Union has a work program for this meeting in Taormina: the defense of the interests of Europeans. As such, the Commission must defend the general interest of the Union. However, given what is happening, especially in Washington, we can see that this mandate requires very strong elements. First of all with regard to the defense of the Paris Agreement: reducing inequalities, combating populism also means fighting climate change and supporting the ecological transition on the basis of what has been concluded with success during the Paris agreements. However, we can now see that a bad wind is blowing in Washington, which aims to call into question these agreements on the grounds that we would not ask the same of a partner like China. It is up to the European Union to say loud and clear that this agreement is in everyone's interest and that it must be implemented today. Another bad wind is also blowing in Washington, which would like us to organize banking deregulation, even though the great crisis we are experiencing - from which we have not yet fully emerged - was born out of the madness of the American banking sector, and who would like all safeguards, such as speculation for own account, consumer protection or the impossibility for market operators to act in their own interest before acting in the interest of their client, to be put back involved by the new US administration. On these issues, too, we expect the European Union to speak out with a loud voice.

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President, the G7 summit must address the major challenges facing the global economy, such as the adverse effects of globalization, poverty, unemployment and the public debt crisis. The G7 summit must make a decisive start on the issue of settling the Greek 'alleged' debt. A debt that is shameful and illegal, since it was created by the collusion of lenders and local Greek oligarchy and the loan funds were not allocated for the benefit of the Greek people and the country. The G7 must realize that the Greek people do not tolerate the method of the lenders to throw the burdens on the backs of the Greek family in order to pay any loss of the lenders from the conversion of interest rates from floating to fixed. We remind the G7 that the Greek people are being severely affected by the huge migratory flows. The G7 must realize that its decades-long policy of market opening and free trade has marginalized millions of citizens.

name: Charles Goerens
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, as the United Kingdom is about to turn its back on the European Union, it seems useful to me to reflect now on the weight of Europe in the future G7. Indeed, Europe will be doubly affected by Brexit as it will only have three member states in the G7. So the European Union as such will weigh less in this forum. Over the years, we have seen the Union assume more responsibilities within the G7. Would it not be wise, therefore, to gradually prepare it to represent all of its Member States exclusively, rather than remaining attached to this baroque construction? Because of two things one: either Italy, Germany and France fully recognize themselves in the positions articulated by the Commission within the G7 in the future - in which case a single European representative would suffice for this table - or the actors diverge on issues on the agenda, which would seriously undermine the credibility of our Union. I would like to ask the Commission and the Council Presidency what they think of a single representation by the European Union in the G7 and whether, if so, they would agree to initiate reflection on this matter.

name: Eleonora Forenza
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this year the G7 is taking place in my country, in Italy, and my memory cannot fail to go to the G8 a few years ago, when Carlo Giuliani was killed in the name of the safety of the great. This year the G7 took place in the meeting of Ecofin ministers in my city, in Bari, a city that has been completely desertified and militarized, again in the name of the safety of the great, transformed into a red zone. The representative of the Council spoke to us earlier about migrants. Well, in Taormina the landings of migrants have already been blocked to always guarantee the safety of the seven great ones of the Earth. So I would like to ask if it is not possible to discuss, within this G7, a concrete reduction in military spending, given that here we are used to discussing, in this forum, a stability pact, but military spending is always an overshoot. possible under the stability pact. I would also like to ask, I say very briefly, whether we should continue to have a unilateral reading on the question of sanctions against Russia or whether the complicity of the European Union with the pro-fascist government of Poroshenko can be questioned.

name: Sven Giegold
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! The discussion about globalization is currently reaching a new high. It is of course extremely worrying when the United States withdraws from key international cooperation projects. The EU Commission has presented a reflection paper on the status of the globalization debate, and it basically suggests two things. On the one hand: to heat up the process of economic globalization even further with a new generation of international treaties and, on the other hand, to make social, ecological and democratic corrections. The question is this: while at the same time you are clearly trying to push ahead with bilateral trade agreements, which do not provide for binding social and ecological standards, you are not consistent in the ecological, social and democratic corrections that the globalization process needs. Two examples: firstly, the European Parliament has proposed to you to prescribe binding human rights standards for the textile sector along the entire supply chain. That means that everything that is imported into Europe must correspond to our values. We do not need a Buy European Act, we need binding social and ecological standards. If you come up with such suggestions, you will become credible. It is the same with the fight against financial crime. Six officers sit in the basement of the Eurojustice General Directorate in the Financial Crime Task Force. Make sure that the resources that a clean financial market needs are finally made available. Then you will become credible.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the theme of this presidency of the Italian G7 is to build the foundations of renewed confidence. Judging by the leaders who will speak, I would like to say that before asking to renew it, they should at least demonstrate that they deserve trust. It rests on three pillars, one is climate change, there is talk of ambitious action to implement the COP21 in Paris, with Trump who would even want to disavow what little he has achieved and Italy, President, with the highest number of deaths in Europe for air pollution, 84,000 in 2012, and with catastrophic sites such as Taranto and Civitavecchia. We talk about economic and social sustainability and the reduction of inequalities and how they want to be achieved, as you told us before, with wild free trade. Inequalities are in fact growing, while the energy transition and the fight against tax evasion still remain a mirage. Lastly, innovation towards the production revolution, with Italy, my country, the last European country of the G7 for investments in the sector. In short, the Italian government of Prime Minister Gentiloni, rather than shooting slogans, should demonstrate that it has the skills and the will to lead by example, doing homework. In this way they gain trust and credibility, not least in order not to leave the whole Union in the hands of France and Germany.

name: Matteo Salvini
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it seems to me that Europe is governed by inability, bad faith and hypocrisy. Talk about work when, with your rules and your currency, you have brought 35 million unemployed to Europe. Talk about trade and renew the sanctions against Russia which are costing billions of euros in lost exports to our economy. Talk about rights and think of removing the duties that protect our companies from unfair Chinese competition: steel, paper, glass, ceramics, textiles. Talk about the fight against terrorism and do not lift a finger to stop the landings of thousands and thousands of fake refugees and real criminals, who the day before yesterday were wandering, for example, through the streets of Modena asking for money, documents, housing and work. You knew, Commissioners, how many Italians and Europeans would like money, documents, housing and work, but they are refugees in their home. Talk about rights, today is the international day against sexual discrimination, well do business with Saudi Arabia, Iran, Pakistan, Nigeria, where homosexuality is subject to the death penalty. How much hypocrisy, Commissioners! Come to the G7 in Sicily which has 50 per cent youth unemployment, come to a Sicily where agriculture and fishing have replaced the economy of landings and clandestinity. I don't know how much it will cost, I don't know what good you will eat, I don't know where you will sleep, certainly not in some reception center, I know for sure that we think, as a League in the future, of a G7 of the people and not of the powerful. You have brought home a result. For a week no one lands in Sicily anymore. But how? As a League, I have been asking for years for naval blockade, blocking of departures and landings and deaths, and you tell me that it cannot be done, that landings cannot be blocked and borders cannot be controlled, and now to defend the asses of some powerful one for a week no longer lands? Shame on you!

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Madam President, the Union's participation in the G7 summit is completely unprotected. The Union has no statehood, no elected government and the irony is that any agenda it can present is invalid for two reasons: - first, such an agenda has no moral and democratic legitimacy if the European Parliament has not been informed and approved the agenda. - Secondly, four of the seven members of the G7 are also members of the Union, ie Germany, France, Italy and the United Kingdom, unless the Union has a different agenda than that of its Member States. This session will therefore discuss social sustainability and the reduction of inequalities. As the policy of the European Union imposes memoranda and impoverishes peoples, demands austerity and fiscal sacrifices, keeps banks profitable at the expense of citizens and serves globalization by abolishing national entities, identities and borders, it is dishonest and condemnable to speak in such political terms.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I think that the G7 meeting is the moment for truth and the moment of truth in the relationship between the European Union, European Union big countries, Japan, Canada and the United States. We have here the first big opportunity, especially the President of the Commission and the President of the Council, to face Mr Trump and to explain to him the why the European Union, security – especially a firm and tough attitude towards Russia – and free trade are so important to defend democracy, the rule of law, human rights and a fairly balanced globalisation process. We can’t miss this opportunity. It is essential that we ensure that Mr Trump can understand – because of the attitudes and of the policies of his allies that are here; these countries are the greatest allies of the United States – that he has to be very firm on Russia without any ambiguity, very loud and clear, and at the same time that he has to defend our way of life, and that means also free trade and a regulated globalisation.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D).
text: - Madam President, if a progressive, a socialist, reads the Bari declaration adopted last week by the finance ministers and central bank governors, they will agree on the most important measures proposed for the G-7: policiesto increase growth, fight against inequality, efficient tax systems, fight against tax evasion and avoidance, end the gender gap, end competitive devaluation between countries.If we agree, then two questions: why since 2014 we are repeating the same thing without taking effective measures, conclusive decisions?And the second question: why if four of the seven countries that make up the G-7 are members of the European Union, and they are the most important members, we are not capable of applying these policies in the European Union?Is it a problem of cynicism or is it ineffectiveness?

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, dear colleagues, one of the issues that is growing and that needs to be addressed on the global level by the G7 is cybersecurity. As of today, WannaCry, the biggest ransomware attack ever, has affected more than 150 states and more than 200 000 users. The attack does not only concern regular citizens, but can endanger people’s lives and the functioning of a state and collapse economics. The last attack, for example, affected hospitals in the UK. Next time, it could be a banking system, a wider healthcare malfunctioning or something else. It is time to make cybersecurity a priority for all, because a weak link in one country is a threat to everyone. It is the responsibility of G7 states and the EU to take all necessary steps to develop cyber defence and avoid possible new attacks. This is why the development of cyberspace security has to be a priority also in the EU and NATO cooperation.

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to focus on climate change and the role of the G7, because I think it cannot be stressed enough how important the G7 has been in history in setting the global climate change agenda. In 2009 – back then it was a G8 – it was the first time when the global players were setting the agenda for the 2°C target, which ended up in the Copenhagen agreement. Then, in 2015, the phase-out of fossil fuels was adopted by the G7: that was setting the agenda for the Paris Agreement later on in the year.  That shows how crucial this G7 will be on what is going to happen with the implementation of the Paris Agreement. We know that the United States is trying to push back and trying to get the significance of fossil fuels back on the agenda, whereas we all know that Paris requires a phase-out of fossil fuels. So we cannot give in, in any way, to what the Americans are asking. We cannot slow down; investors are watching to see what will come of it. But this will also set the agenda for the G20 later on in the year.  What the G7 is going to say will either make sure that Paris will be implemented as agreed, or it will put the wind in the sails of conservative countries like Saudi Arabia and Russia. So, the conclusion of the question is very simple, and I would like to have an answer on that. If we cannot get those conclusions with the United States, will we push for a G6 statement on climate?

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in Sicily, my region, youth unemployment is close to 60%, the infrastructures are ridiculous, there are the railways of a hundred years ago, motorway bridges that have fallen, the territory, agriculture and fishing they are systematically looted by multinationals, there is mass emigration, there is poverty and there is social exclusion and in such a context the great of the Earth have decided to build a golden cage in Taormina, spending 40 million euros of public money, of which 10 only for meetings, creating inconvenience to the population and carrying out a "dust under the carpet" operation, effectively blocking landings for a period of time. Now, these gentlemen probably only get together to decide how to do further damage to our planet and they do it by cutting down ancient olive trees, creating another helicopter landing pad to be more comfortable, a useless runway. I say that probably if they wanted to solve some problems they should travel from Trapani to Pozzallo by train, they should meet at the ZEN in Palermo or at the Librino in Catania, or go in front of Niscemi's MUOS.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Madam President, dear colleagues, let me say that I support and appreciate the subjects on the agenda of the G7 meeting as they were presented by the Council and committee. These are well-chosen topics that are reflecting the concerns of citizens and challenges ahead, but the most important subject is actually in the title of the G7 meeting – the issue of trust; an issue of future beneficial and sincere cooperation among the leading economic countries of the world and also about leading democracies. I hope that the partly new composition of G7 leaders will make a clear statement on this direction and will also commit themselves personally to going forward in the route of sincere cooperation and respect for the most important values. Our countries and the EU should play the leading role, because these are the values that we are representing, and we should convince the others.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the G7 is meeting in Italy and I am very proud that my country hosts it in an unstable world context, with growing tensions but also with interesting signals, such as China's proposal for a new one " Via della Seta ", which can create new international collaboration in addition to trade. Leaders today know that they represent only a part of the political and economic power of the planet, because today the G20 is the largest and most representative forum, but the specific responsibility of the G7 of the European Union is precisely that of representing the most developed democracies and then we must be aware that that leadership, which is no longer taken for granted, which is no longer based on the strength of numbers, must today be based on the strength of our values, on multilateralism, on openness, on respect for international law, so unilateral actions or offensive attacks are not acceptable to the international community. But this leadership must also be entrusted to the rules, as many of my colleagues have said, for a transparent taxation at a transnational level, so that there is a theme of redistribution, of social justice, and these new rules are found. The European Union stands out among the protagonists. In the inaction, in the uncertainty of prospects and commitment of large countries and great powers, today it is Europe that must then fill this role.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Following on from what my friend Mr Eickhout said, I think climate change is going to be a hugely important issue here at the G7 summit, and especially the role of the larger—than—life character President Donald Trump. The Paris agreement is a global agreement, and if the United States were to pull out of it this would undermine it completely. And this is a man, Donald Trump, who claimed that climate change was created by the Chinese to attack US manufacturing competitiveness, who claimed that global warming is an expensive hoax, and who claimed that wind farms are bad for people’s health. But I think that, as a businessman, he is person who is subject to change, and I think the G7 is a great opportunity to convince him that what he has said in the past is not actually true. And in the interests of US citizens and world citizens, we need to adopt the climate change agreement in Paris and implement it, and the United States has to do so above all else.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D).
text: - Madam President, with a view to building the foundations for renewed confidence, this year's G7 Summit has a duty to encourage governments to adopt policies aimed at meeting citizens' legitimate expectations in terms of economic, social and security.in a world crushed by conflict.Externally, there are many urgent issues to be addressed, including ongoing violence and recent chemical attacks in Syria, support for Ukraine's sovereignty, the threat of nuclear weapons in North Korea, migratory flows, global and regional security, the fight against Daesh.and violent extremism.We need a coordination of efforts, the promotion of rules-based international order, the fight against terrorism and violent extremism in an increasingly insecure world.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: - Madam President, the very title of laying the foundations of renewed confidence says what should be the main topic of this summit.Paolo Gentiloni, Theresa May, Donald Tusk and Emmanuel Macron will meet for the first time.This is an opportunity for our leaders, Mr Tusk and Mr Jean-Claude Juncker, to say on what foundations our European policy is based, that we respect the rule of law, democracy, human rights.All the topics you listed: managing migration flows, open trade, strengthening multilateral institutions, then the concrete implementation of the Paris Agreement, but also foreign policy topics that primarily concern Syria, Libya, Iran, the situation in Ukraine, are topics that will be discussed.I believe, to talk seriously at this summit and I expect positive results, but above all concrete proposals so that our citizens can really feel the benefits of such meetings.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: – Madam President, just yesterday we debated how the EU can successfully harness globalisation. The upcoming G7 summit will be a prime opportunity to put words into practice, to show European leadership and to stand firm on our values and principles, insisting that a rule—based international order remains one of the key priorities for us. Indeed, the very reason why this is a G7 and not a G8 summit is that one key nation continues to disregard international rules and agreements, with the central theme of the G7 summit being how to rebuild trust. I believe that the EU should use the G7 summit to recommit to the biggest economies on the plan to achieving the sustainable development goals – all of them, comprehensively. Rebuilt trust requires visible action from the EU on the problems facing Member States and the people of Europe.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Vice-President, unlike a colleague who said that the European Union has nothing to do with the G7, I believe that we must be present, the European Union, at the G7. Yes, the European Union is not a country, but we put some values ​​together and we want to be represented and, as my colleague said earlier, yesterday we debated a lot of globalization, I think it is very important to see how we relate to other powers in the global world. Russia is participating. Do we have to see what we do with the relationship with Russia, what we do with the relationship with China, with the United States? There are embargoes between the European Union and Russia, European Union producers are calling for opening up to other markets. Here are a lot of things not only about security, but also economic issues and I welcome the presence, but we are also waiting for a concrete information with what was discussed and what results will be there. We look forward to you and wish you success!

name: Carmelo Abela
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for your comments, all of which were noted by the Presidency of the Council. As you know, the Presidency does not participate in or attend the G7 but the European Union is represented by the Commission. As I said earlier, these are challenging times, on several fronts, and most of your comments confirm this: that we are living through challenging times, especially on account of still high geo-political and political uncertainty. I therefore look forward to a strong message of confidence and reassurance by G7 leaders as well as to their guidance. We need to preserve the spirit of cooperation in the G7 and also to continue to provide multilateral answers to the challenges we face. This also means maintaining and building on the achievements of the past and not giving in to protectionism and isolation. Finally, I believe that it is through cooperation and working together that we can aspire to tackle the issues that are of concern for our citizens and our respective countries.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, to be very concise and short, I would like to thank honourable Members very much for their comments and remarks. Most of them were very supportive of our agenda. The next G7 meeting should, first and foremost, be about revitalising multilateralism. We have not lost it completely yet, but we have seen some tendencies, at least in rhetoric, to move away from multilateralism, and this is a very dangerous direction. That is why our agenda is so strongly linked to strengthening multilateralism. Many Members mentioned that implementation of COP 21 should be one of the priorities, and we fully agree. This agreement has already been agreed and now it is a matter of implementation. A bigger global challenge than climate change could not be imagined, and that is why we need a real commitment from the leaders to implement it. Finally, there is a whole range of issues, like the fight against terrorism or tax evasion, which must be addressed in global fora, but I hope that our leaders will send a strong message in favour of rules-based trade, because that is the way to govern globalisation. It is the way to harness and shape globalisation. Without rules-based trade we cannot include important values like environmental or social values in trade. This is the way in which we can enhance economic growth in a sustainable manner and make sure that our economic growth is translated to job creation too.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is thus closed.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. - The mission that the forthcoming G7 in Taormina sets out to do is to build the foundations of a renewed trust of citizens in the governments, towards which - as the Italian presidency affirms - skepticism about their ability to resolve is growing day by day the problems related to everyday life, and among these safety, environmental sustainability and economic well-being, represent in themselves the testimony of the failure of a top-down, elitist and self-referential method of solving the problems of the whole world. A model that has been going on for years and that has not been able to spare the whole world from wars, terrorism, economic crises and pollution. I believe that the time has come to imagine a new, truly multilateral, inclusive and bottom-up method to deal effectively and with maximum transparency the problems posed by globalization, the harmful effects of which on ordinary citizens are caused by the excessive power of a few powerful people. now obviously concerned about the fact that they will no longer be able to appear credible in the eyes of the people.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The upcoming 43rd G7 summit will be very important one for many reasons. One of them, is that this summit will be the first one for British Prime Minister Theresa May, newly elected French President Macron and US President Trump. Looking from this perspective, it could be argued that this summit will determine the international order in the upcoming years. Therefore, I urge the EU to pursue seriously its interests during the summit. I will emphasise economic development as a top priority (interest) for the EU. The EU also should push for peace solutions for the ongoing conflicts in its neighbourhood namely in Syria, Libya and Ukraine. Last but not least, the EU should discuss with other states from G7 its future relationship with Britain after Brexit.

name: Le Président. –
text: Dear Colleagues, I now have the great honor and pleasure of welcoming the Secretary-General of the United Nations, Mr. António Guterres. Your appointment is historic. You are the first citizen of the European Union to hold this post. Our two organizations were born from the ashes of the Second World War and were built on the same values, with the same objective: to promote peace and prosperity through multilateral cooperation. Today, more than ever, we must work together to meet the expectations of our fellow citizens and deliver tangible results. We have to face common global challenges: conflicts, terrorism and radicalization, the management of migratory flows, but also climate change, poverty and unemployment. Our citizens expect a more present and efficient Europe on the world stage. We cannot continue to watch helplessly the bombing in Syria, the famine in Africa, the thousands of deaths in the desert and the Mediterranean, the trafficking of women and children, watching with indifference the growing violation of rights. fundamental, witness the decline of democracy in some countries, including Venezuela and Turkey, or the persecution of religious minorities. Yesterday we spoke about Africa with the Chairman of the African Union Commission, Mr. Moussa Faki Mahamat. I would like to repeat that Africa is a priority for the European Union. This is why trilateral cooperation between the United Nations, the European Union and the African Union must be strengthened, in particular on the prevention and rapid response to crises and conflicts. We must jointly find political solutions to the conflicts in Syria, Libya and Yemen as well as to face Daesh. Together, we must defend the dignity and freedom of the person, give prospects to new generations and implement the sustainable development program in the 2030 horizon to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals.Mr Secretary General, faced with these many challenges, you can count on the support of this Parliament for your program, which is also ours.

name: António Guterres
text: Secretary-General of the United Nations. – Mr President, thank you very much for your invitation and this opportunity to address the European Parliament. I have been a parliamentarian in my own country for 23 years, and during three I was with your neighbours in the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe. So allow me to say, dear colleagues: the United Nations was created after the Second World War exactly because the world wanted to avoid another tragedy of the same dimension. But I believe this was exactly the main motivation for the creation of the European Communities – with one very important difference: the European Communities and the European Union are clearly the most successful project of peace sustainability in the world since the beginning of history. And that is why I want to express here my very deep gratitude and appreciation for the strong commitment of the European Union and all its bodies to multilateralism, and for the very generous and extremely important contribution you give in development cooperation, in humanitarian aid, and also in the key central aspects of peace and security that are the core of the United Nations action. (Applause) You see the European Union involved around Libya. You see the European Union involved funding the AMISOM mission of the African Union in Somalia. We see the European Union in both financial support and training in situations from the Central African Republic or Mali, and we look forward to the support of the European Union for the initiative of the neighbours of Mali, the G5 Sahel. European contribution is today an absolutely essential part of what is necessary to make the UN effective, and I want to express my deep gratitude for that. (Applause) Dear colleagues, it would be possible to come here and make the case that the world has never been better. It is obvious that globalisation and technological progress have in the last decades created the conditions for an enormous increase in global wealth, for a meaningful improvement in the leading conditions of the majority of the population, even for a very strong reduction of the number of absolute poor – probably the Chinese contribution being essential for that. And some might even say, looking for instance at the number of soldiers killed in the battlefield, that this is the most peaceful period in human history. Now these indicators might be true, but they are far from revealing the whole truth, and I think it is important for us to recognise that we are facing a number of unprecedented challenges that require the EU and the UN to work together. Allow me to mention briefly four of them. First, conflicts. We are seeing a multiplication of new conflicts in the last few years, and old conflicts seem never to die, be it in Afghanistan, Somalia or the Democratic Republic of Congo. But the truth is that, not only do we have a multiplication of conflicts, but they change in nature. We practically no longer have wars between countries, even if there are some threats looming on the horizon, but most of the conflicts are internal – many of them linked to fragilities in the countries, but being internal, they quickly have a regional dimension and sometimes even a global dimension. At the same time, they tend to be asymmetric, more and more complex, more and more interlinked, and more linked with the new threat of global terrorism in the world. If one looks at the situation from Nigeria to Mali, to Libya, to Somalia, to Syria, Iraq, Yemen, Afghanistan – all these conflicts are becoming more and more interlinked. You see fighters going from one to another and then some of them going back to their countries of origin and potentially becoming threats to the security of those countries of origin, and we see these conflicts becoming more and more interlinked. They are indeed today a very relevant threat to our global security, wherever we live. At the same time, it is clear that power relations in the world became less obvious, and with power relations less obvious, it seems that there is no respect, and impunity and unpredictability became the name of the game. In this context, when one looks at the present trends of conflict, it is absolutely essential to create the conditions to reverse these trends, and for that it is clear we need to strengthen multilateral capacity to address conflicts, to solve conflicts and to prevent and sustain peace. And this is an area where the European cooperation with the United Nations is absolutely crucial. We need to strengthen our own capacity to solve many of the conflicts around the world. But that forces us to look into their nature. Look at Syria. These conflicts are conflicts where nobody is winning: everybody is losing. And not only is everybody is losing from the point of view of the citizens of the country – the enormous suffering of the Syrian people – but we see the impact on the destabilisation of the region. And with Syria, we see Syria clearly as one of the feeding factors of global terrorism. Now, the point is that we need to create the conditions to make those that are parties to the conflict, but especially those that have an influence on the parties to the conflict, to understand that, indeed, these are conflicts where nobody is winning, everybody is losing, and in which the contradictions of interest that might interest are much smaller than the absolute need to put an end to this nonsense and to eliminate these terrible threats for our own global security. (Applause) And there, as I said, we need to strengthen the capacity of the United Nations, both in conflict resolution – in preventing conflict – and sustaining peace, our new most important priority. But we will never be able to do it without a very strong support and commitment from the European Union. A strong and united Europe is an absolutely fundamental pillar of a strong and effective United Nations, and this is a very clear message I would like to address to you all. (Applause) But in these conflicts we also see horrible violations of international humanitarian law and human rights law, and that is why I would like to mention the second challenge, and it relates to the fact that we see the human rights agenda losing ground to the national sovereignty agenda. That should not make sense. National sovereignty is a central pillar of the United Nations Charter, and indeed national sovereignty is reinforced when countries and governments are able to protect their citizens and to preserve human rights in their territories. But unfortunately we have seen national sovereignty many times being invoked to justify the lack of capacity of the international community to address the terrible human rights violation challenges that we see in several parts of the world. It is my belief that we need to mobilise a broader coalition for human rights, and the broader coalition must be able to understand that we only stress national sovereignty by strongly promoting and protecting human rights all over the world. But for that coalition to be effective, I think we need two conditions.
