First, we need to have a comprehensive view of human rights – civil and political rights, but also economic, social and cultural rights. And second, it is important not to be biased. It is important not to have double standards or even agendas. I think it is absolutely crucial to understand that human rights are a value in themselves and they should not be used at the service of other political projects. (Applause) To be very frank, if we want to champion human rights, we need to have moral authority. The recent migration and refugee crisis in the world has undermined to a certain extent the moral authority of several countries around the world to champion human rights in an effective way. This is why I want to say how important it is from my perspective, the strong commitment of the European Union together with us in making sure that we are able to re-establish the international protection regime for refugees in line with international law, and to have Europe strongly engaged in a positive and constructive dialogue in the preparation of the global compact for safe, orderly and regular migration that I hope will be approved by the General Assembly of the United Nations in 2018. In relation to this I would like to make a few comments. First, it is essential that development cooperation policies are linked to our concerns about human mobility. It is essential that development cooperation policies are built in a way that allows for people to have the choice to remain in their countries, to have opportunities to be able to build their lives with dignity in their own countries – for migration to be out of choice, not out of necessity. (Applause) Second, I think it is essential to have a much stronger international coordination in cracking down on traffickers and smugglers that are, in my opinion, the worst criminals of today’s world. But third, I also think it is very important to create more opportunities for legal migration and more effective cooperation between countries of origin, countries of transit and countries of destination. I think that the European Union must be at the centre of this dialogue, and your role can be extremely positive to find the necessary consensus to make the Migration Compact a success. (Applause) This massive displacement we are witnessing in today’s world brings me to the third challenge I wanted to mention to you, and that has to do with the fact that, if one looks at the global mega trends that we face – population growth; climate change; chaotic urbanisation in many areas of the developing world; food insecurity, which unfortunately now has translated into famine in some critical areas where conflict and climate change have been aligning themselves to create terrible human tragedies; water scarcity – all these mega trends are interacting with each other in a stronger and stronger away in a world that is smaller and smaller, and they are having dramatic impacts in terms of the increasing fragility of states, the increasing displacement of people and the increasing human suffering in the world, and creating in several circumstances the potential for conflict over scarce resources. In this context it is important to recognise that climate change is the main accelerator of these factors, and, since climate change is the main accelerator of these factors, it is absolutely essential that the world implements the Paris Agreement and implements it with an increased ambition. (Applause) If any government doubts these objectives, that is a reason for all others to come together and make sure that we stay the course in relation to the implementation of the Paris Agreement and that we build a broader coalition with civil society, with the business community, with the cities, with the regions, in order to be able to make sure that our ambitions are met and that we are able to tame climate change to the benefit of our present situation, but also to the benefit of our children and grandchildren. In relation to this, it is also important to understand that it is not only the right thing to do; this is the smart thing to do, as green business is becoming more and more recognised as good business. Those countries that will not bet on the green economy will inevitably lag behind in development in the years to come. So it is the right thing to do, it is the smart thing to do, and we count on Europe to lead these efforts at global level. (Applause) But indeed, one of the key impacts of climate change is the acceleration of displacement, which is very much linked to the problems of migration and refugees that I mentioned, and this brings me to a fourth challenge. Globalisation has had an enormous positive impact, as I mentioned – together with technological development – in relation to wealth, living conditions, the reduction of poverty, as I said in the beginning of my intervention. But globalisation left a lot of people behind, and we see that in the rust belts of this world. We see that in massive youth unemployment in different parts of the world – even a little bit in Europe, to a certain extent compared with other areas – but very clearly in North Africa and the Middle East, which represents a tragedy for young people, a very strong limitation for the development of the countries, but more and more, a meaningful threat for our global security, as youth without employment, without jobs, without opportunities, is becoming, in some areas of the world, one of the key areas of recruitment of terrorist groups and one of the factors that facilitate the propaganda of extremist organisations. In this context, we need to recognise that globalisation and technological progress also have dramatically increased inequalities at global level and at country level. Eight persons in the world have today as much wealth as half of the world population. All these factors have contributed to undermine the trust between peoples and the political establishments at national level, but also the trust between peoples and international organisations like the UN and the trust in global solutions for our global problems. That is the reason why I am strongly engaged in the reform of the UN, to be able to make the UN more effective, more cost effective, but more than anything else, to make the UN closer to the aspirations, the needs and the perspectives of the peoples we are supposed to serve. That means, for us, the reform of the UN development system, to make it much more effective in supporting Member States in the implementation of the Agenda 2030 that we hope, as an agenda for sustainable development, can bring a very important contribution to re-establish the trust between peoples and the international systems based on making sure that no one is left behind, making sure that we have a more fair globalisation. At the same time, it means the reform of our peace strategy, operational set-ups and architecture in order to make us more able to face the challenges of today, namely of peacekeeping. We have more and more peacekeeping operations where peace is elusive and where peacekeepers see themselves in the middle of a conflict, with extreme difficulties to protect the people they are supposed to protect. This requires a strategic analysis and new partnerships, namely with the African Union, with several African regional organisations, but very central cooperation with the European Union in this regard, and reform of our own internal management system. Some of the rules and regulations that have been accumulated over decades in the UN seem to be created to make sure that we are not able to act effectively, and we need to make sure that we create the trust between Member States, namely Western countries and the G77, to understand that there is a win-win solution, making the UN more flexible, but at the same time with decentralisation, simplification of procedures, more freedom of movement of the secretariat, more transparency and more accountability to make sure that there is full responsibility for anything we do. Reform is essential at the level of the United Nations. I think reform is essential at the level of all international organisations, as is the understanding that we need to rebuild that trust, both at country level and at global level. All our societies are becoming multi-ethnic, multi-cultural and multi-religious. In my opinion this is a good thing, and I believe diversity is a richness, not a threat. But it would be naive to think ... (Applause) ... that diversity will be a success automatically. For diversity to be a success, we need a massive investment – a political, social, cultural investment by governments, by local authorities, by civil societies – in the social cohesion and inclusivity of our societies, to make sure that people understand that their identities are respected, but at the same time that they belong to the community as a whole, with all its rights and obligations. And at the same time, we need at global level to understand that diversity will not be automatically a source of peace and understanding; that we also need a massive investment, an investment in international cooperation, to bring people together, to make people know each other, respect each other, cooperate with each other, and to do it in a way in which it is possible to have everybody working together to face the global challenges that are in front of us and that no country can solve in an isolated way. It is in this context – and allow me to say a few words as a European – that I strongly believe that the values of the Enlightenment are the most important contribution that Europe has given to world civilisation, and that those values of tolerance, la primauté de la raison, must be a very solid cornerstone of our capacity to build a more tolerant, more fair, more just, more peaceful and more prosperous world. (The House accorded the speaker a standing ovation)

name: President. –
text: Secretary-General, dear friend António, thank you very much for your speech, thank you for your engagement in favour of human rights, and also as a European. We are proud to be at the centre of the debate as the European Parliament in defence of human rights and of the minorities in the world. We are ready for strong cooperation with you, with your organisation. Thank you very much. (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item is voting time.(Voting results and other details of the voting: see Minutes.)

name: Der Präsident.
text: - That closes voting time.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - President!The essence of the principle of subsidiarity is that decisions must be made closest to the people.In the case of Hungary, this should now mean that, apart from very exceptional situations, the European Union does not make decisions - but I will go on - there are situations where our own state does not force decisions on us, but we, the Hungarian people, raise them.our heads and take our destiny into our hands.To give an example: if there is a provision that doctors may not interview the press without the permission of a ministry, or I don’t know what kind of superior authority, then we have to come together with fifteen doctors from that hospital and say we have a press conference this afternoon, youyou are talking about appendicitis, you are about cancer prevention, you are about the flu, and we are unwilling to acknowledge that we are being forced to do such dictatorial things.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the application of the principle of subsidiarity is directly linked to the decentralized operation of the European Union in areas that do not fall within the exclusive competence of the Union. In this context, decisions must be taken as closely as possible to the citizens. The principle of subsidiarity is guaranteed by national parliaments, through the yellow and orange card procedure. Thus, the non-exploitation, as shown in the report, by the national parliaments does not mean a waiver of their right. Also, if a state, a government or a national parliament considers that the principle of subsidiarity is being violated, especially because of the memoranda imposed by the troika, as is the case in Greece, it may want to appeal to the Court of Justice of the European Union. Why doesn't the Greek government or the Greek parliament do this? A green card can also be applied by national parliaments to create a positive right to legislation. This can happen if it is institutionalized and deemed necessary.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, where are the richest countries in the world? Or rather, which states and territories have the wealthiest people? One thing you notice is that they are all small: it’s the Switzerlands, the Singapores, the Monacos, the Channel Islands, the UAEs, the Bruneis. Of the countries with the highest GDP per head, the top 10, there is only one large state – the United States of America. Why? Because it has pulled off the trick of administering itself like a confederation of tiny statehoods. As Aristotle observed, to the size of a state there is a limit, just as to implements, animals and plants, for they cannot retain their natural facility when they are too large. Ever since I’ve been in this Chamber, I’ve been told that the flow of history is towards federalisation and big blocs like the European Union, but I’ve got to say there’s no evidence for it. In 1946 there were 76 independent countries; today, there are 195. The tide is flowing the other way.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - I supported this report on subsidiarity and proportionality.However, I believe that it should not just end with the formal adoption of a report here, but at least for the Commission, those conclusions should be very important.The report says that up to one third of legislative proposals do not sufficiently substantiate subsidiarity and proportionality, and I personally do not consider it a mere formality to say whether or not we need a piece of legislation and whether it meets these criteria.So I hope that, when we have adopted this report today, that, at least for the Commission, the conclusions of the report will be important and that the rationale for individual legislative proposals will therefore improve in the future and better justify whether the legislation presented meets the conditions of subsidiarity and proportionality..

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Mr President, subsidiarity and proportionality are guiding principles of the European Union, but this House has been misguided and, in my opinion, has been misleading European politics on this point for quite some time, in my opinion. The European Parliament is the only European institution with Members democratically and directly elected. I have the honour of representing Slovak constituents. They expect that the EU will help them with issues where the EU can work better than they can alone. However, they do not welcome interference and intrusion into areas outside EU competence or where these actions are unhelpful or ideologically opposed. Unfortunately, that is what is happening in this House on a regular basis. I welcome my colleague’s report. I would like to call upon all Members of this House to respect existing principles. Taking competencies and responsibilities from the people will have a negative effect on trust in the European project.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - This report constantly emphasizes the need for consumer protection in the financial sector. I would be very happy if, instead of constantly attacking and condemning Hungary, the European Union would finally look at what had happened and how the various Western and non-Western banks had trampled on the European Union's consumer protection standards in terms of the situation of Hungarian foreign currency creditors. This should finally be addressed! And a little bit back to subsidiarity: we should also have so much self-esteem and self-awareness that, for example, Hungarian judges are starting to take the fact that here, please, the European Union directive more seriously, whatever the pressure is on them from all sides. on consumer protection. This is what we apply in legal cases, we consider foreign currency borrowers as consumers and not as debtors as some kind of debtor slave. Let's finally deal with this, not the many other things about Hungary!

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, there is a wealth of experience in this House. Looking around, I see colleagues who used to be doctors, soldiers, actors and ship’s engineers. There are obviously one or two duds, but also a lot of people who have brought real experience to the table. But almost no one here is a tech entrepreneur and even those who do have backgrounds in it are not in the same position to make decisions about regulation and investment as those who are directly involved with the sector. London has become, arguably, the world capital of the FinTech sector. What did the government have to do with that? It simply stood back and created a climate where the laws were enforced and where regulations were friendly. That is all you need to do. I promise you that there are a million guys out there who are much more interested and involved than anyone in this Chamber. It is not going to be our business once we leave, but if you really want technology of this kind to flourish in the remaining European Union, the best thing you can do is to stand back and let them get on with it.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Mr President, as I said in my speech yesterday, the development of technology in the financial sector is expected to boost trade and make it easier for consumers themselves. Of course, increased care needs to be taken on cybersecurity issues, especially in the wake of the recent cyber-attacks we have seen. At the same time, the technology itself must be neutral, proportionate and not lead to exclusion and discrimination. Technology must support not only the center but also the periphery. The provision of services must have zero or minimal cost in order to be open and accessible to all. Finally, it is necessary to hit technological illiteracy and train consumers in this field.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, this report focuses on FinTech, which is referred to as ‘finance enabled by new technologies’. New financial technologies are a source of great financial opportunities for the EU and its citizens, although to enjoy benefits without paying additional costs we need the right legislative framework in place. I voted in favour of this report as I see very significant benefits of FinTech, such as cost reduction, efficiency gains and enhanced transparency when it comes to investment and cross—border financial flows. Moreover, we need to see financial technologies as a tool for the EU to develop a digital single market and remain competitive at the global scale. However, I share the cautiousness of the rapporteur that there are still many grey areas with new financial technologies, and thus, while working on the competitiveness of the European economy, we also need to think about ensuring consumer protection, cyber security and the stability of the EU financial system.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - President! In the discussion, I spoke about the love of freedom of the Hungarian nation and people. Now I would mention another feature of ours: our patriotism. We are a patriotic people, and it has one characteristic, or two, that resembles family love. There are times when we are very dissatisfied with our family, or with our family members, we are angry with them. But still, if they hurt them, we will protect our family. If they are hurt by outsiders, we stand by our family and our family members. That’s why what they do is terribly counterproductive to you. The more they attack, the more they insult Hungary, the more we stick together on who we need to stand up for. The other is the family, by definition, an intimate, closed community. You want to force us to let wild strangers into our homes quasi. I’m not a bad person for thinking I don’t want to accommodate 10-12 strangers in my own family home.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Mr President, I strongly did not support this report because it expresses another inadmissible interference in the internal affairs of a sovereign state. Once again, we see a hypocritical attitude on the part of the European Commission. I believe that it is absolutely unacceptable for the Commission and the Council to take such a nominal and aggressive tone towards Hungary. Prime Minister Orbán's actions are supported by the majority of Hungarian society and in no way undermine the democratic foundations of the Hungarian state. This is not the first time that the European Commission has openly attacked a national government for inconsistencies in political views. National governments are much more legitimate representatives of European citizens than the President of the Commission. I'm sorry if you don't like it. I support the course taken by Prime Minister Orbán to defend the borders, and I do not think that the Hungarian Government is violating human rights. Nation-states have the right to defend their borders and repel aggressive invaders. The European Parliament's motion for a resolution mentioned eleven refugees, including Ahmed H. The man had thrown several objects at the border police. I condemn the attack on law enforcement officers and I believe that when we want order, we must guarantee it. For me, Hungary is a great example of protecting national interests within the Community, which is why I voted against.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman!The resolution accusing Hungary of discriminating against, undermining democracy, and launching a systemic threat to the rule of law is threefold scandalous.First, as an attack on the democratic elections and democratic politics of one of our peoples.Second, as an act of extreme political hypocrisy.Third, as an attack on European solidarity and security.The European Union authorities, which tacitly endorsed the introduction of censorship and the launching of persecution against defenders of life in France, now want to act as mentors and arbiters of democracy and the rule of law.But the most bizarre is the attack on Hungary for defending our common borders, and paradoxically, this attack is an honor for Hungarians and is proof that by defending Hungary, which defends us, we are actually defending Europe.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR).
text: - I must say that I am disturbed by the fact that the internal relations of some of the Central European countries have been discussed here for several times.It is not just Hungary that is grilled here repeatedly.It is also Poland, and next time at the additional Brussels meeting it will also be the Czech Republic, where the freedom of the media in the Czech Republic is to be addressed, which is definitely not endangered in my country.I cannot shake the impression that this is not a matter of freedom and democracy in Central European countries, but that it is an attempt to tighten our oxygen a little for not always listening and not listening in everything.That, for example, we have opposed the quota system for the redistribution of refugees and that we also have our own ideas about some aspects of European integration.If that is the case, I can assure you that these methods will be counterproductive and that the EU will not do any good advertising in our countries.Thank you and, of course, I voted against this resolution.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, qualifications differ across the European Union and this causes many difficulties in terms of accessing knowledge and possibilities for workers and learners. A few years ago, Parliament and the Council adopted a recommendation on the establishment of a European qualifications framework for life—long learning, with the aim of improving the transparency and comparability of qualifications in Europe. But this framework objective has not yet been fully achieved, so also during yesterday’s debate we raised a lot of questions to the Commission, and we have to support all those recommendations which would really bring closer this European qualifications framework and would also be a big opportunity for this European qualification framework to become reality. We also have to focus on issues around immigration.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, recognition of skills and qualifications is an important tool to facilitate educational and labour mobility by nationals, mobile EU citizens and third country migrants alike. The establishment of the European Qualifications Framework for Lifelong Learning with the aim of improving the transparency, comparability and transferability of qualifications in Europe, was an important and essential step forward in achieving this objective. Unfortunately, the implementation of the current framework has not taken effect. At each stage of the recognition process different types of obstacles still persist. We are witnessing slow implementation with weak coherence in Member States, variability and weak coordination across Europe, weak engagement of social partners and civil society, and a lack of clarity regarding the recording of skills outside formal education. Furthermore, the challenges that education and training systems face as a result of a high level of migration to Europe should be addressed at both European and national level.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, I voted against the report and, as I pointed out in my speech the day before yesterday, the recognition of professional qualifications is necessary to ensure free movement and to protect workers themselves against the arbitrariness of employers. However, it is not a panacea and of course it will not in itself reduce the unemployment that plagues the European Union. In order to create jobs, the Union leadership must change course, abandon austerity and the policy of violent fiscal adjustment, change the productive model and lead to a fair distribution of wealth. But the report ignores these and ostentatiously ignores them precisely because it does not uphold these values ​​and principles. On the contrary, it wants to gild the pill by presenting as a solution to the problem of unemployment not the condemnation of austerity and violent fiscal adjustment, but the maintenance of austerity itself.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - I supported this material.I believe and hope that the material on the European Qualifications Framework can help to bring the various qualifications in Europe closer together in certain areas and, above all, that this can lead to greater labor mobility.This means that people who obtain similar qualifications anywhere in certain parts of Europe will be able to find employment in another part of Europe and will be recognized in that part of Europe by a qualification from another EU country.So I think that this material is good for increasing employment and, especially for young people, it can help them to have a chance to find work not only in their home country, in their home country, but also in other parts of the EU.If this material contributes to this, then in my opinion its purpose will be fulfilled and I will consider it good.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: This concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Der Präsident.
text: - The next item on the agenda is the hot topic debate under Rule 153a of the Rules of Procedure on the powers and control of the European Central Bank (2017/2690 (RSP)).I would remind Members that there is no catch-the-eye procedure in this debate and that no blue cards will be accepted.

name: Joachim Starbatty
text: Author. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! I see Parliament is full to the brim. Why are we doing this Draghi is the most important man in the euro area. The development of the Eurozone and the fate of millions of people depend on his decisions. To whom is he accountable? He then refers to the independence of his mandate. Yes, but he does not have the mandate to expropriate savers. He does not have the mandate to force insurance companies into the red. He doesn't have the mandate to make our banks struggle to cope with the Americans. He does not have the mandate to undermine the sustainability of pension funds. Nor does he have the mandate to create asset bubbles in our country. And how does he ward off these attacks? He says: I have to expropriate the savers so that their deposit systems are safe. How does he justify that? He says: With my cheap money policy, I am pushing the economy that would otherwise fail. And because the economy picks up and employment picks up, savers also benefit, and this is why their deposit systems are safe in the long term. That is his rationale. We know, however, that a zero interest rate policy and negative interest rates are putting banks and companies at risk. If the interest rate no longer reflects market conditions, but is simply pushed down to encourage companies to invest, then we know that this underpricing of risk leads the company to invest in risky ventures and thus get into difficulties for the future. But not enough! He also decided and enforced the massive purchase of government bonds. A total of 60–80 billion a month, a total of 2.3 trillion! And with it he floods the markets and also saves the euro zone, because he reduces the interest rates for the countries in need. But with With this zero interest rate policy it cannot “strengthen” the economy, so to speak, but it will simply drag ailing companies and ultimately banks along with it, so that we will have zombie companies like in Japan. Above all, he cannot bring out the difficulties of the euro zone with his cheap money policy. The trouble is that we have an incorrect exchange rate. All economists and intelligent politicians know that the euro in the zone is undervalued for Germany and overvalued for Spain and Greece. What is the consequence? Germany's exports are subsidized and exports from the debtor states are taxed. This thing is causing Germany to go from export to export record while the other countries import goods and export employment. You cannot cover up a wrong exchange rate with a cheap monetary policy, that is simply impossible! That is why we only have the consequence that the agony of different countries will now continue. What is Parliament's job? Parliament's job would be to point out to Mr Draghi what his mandate is. Namely to maintain monetary stability. What is this Parliament doing? This Parliament is closing its eyes to reality. This Parliament does not want to see that this policy is against the good of the people. This Parliament is sticking to a bad policy. That is why I ask Parliament to close its eyes and meet people ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Carmelo Abela
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, I would like to thank you for the opportunity to intervene in this topical debate on the subject of the powers and control of the European Central Bank. As we all know, the Treaty has bestowed independence upon the European Central Bank to conduct its monetary policy and to pursue its primary objective of maintaining price stability in the euro area as a whole. International experience has indeed shown that monetary policy tends to be more effective in supporting a stable price level when it is shielded from short-term political influence. The Presidency believes that the accountability of the European Central Bank for its monetary policy is commensurate with its independence and can be inferred from the Treaty. When it comes to the ECB’s accountability for its banking supervision tasks, this is specified in the regulation on the Single Supervisory Mechanism. In this context, the Presidency sees no reason to question whether the ECB adheres to the accountability obligations towards the EU legislators. Similarly the Presidency does not have grounds to doubt that the ECB acts within its mandate. Against this background, the Council has not debated the subject of the powers and control of the European Central Bank and the issue does not feature on any upcoming Council agendas. However, I am grateful for your invitation to attend and I look forward to hearing your views – or more views – during this debate.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, Minister, honourable Members, you are having a debate today about the powers and accountability of the European Central Bank. On behalf of the Commission, I would like to limit myself to a very few remarks on this matter. The ECB and the national central banks are independent when exercising the powers and carrying out the tasks and duties conferred upon them by the Treaty. The principle of central bank independence is enshrined in the Treaty itself. It is put there to protect the ECB and the national central banks in pursuing their primary mandate of fulfilling their price stability objective and thus creating the foundation for a healthy and stable European economy.  Independence and accountability are of course intertwined. The ECB presents to Parliament an annual report on its activities and you hold a general debate on that basis. The quarterly monetary dialogues you organise with the ECB President provide a further forum for in—depth discussion. I understand you have regularly made use of this possibility over the past year.  The Commission has full trust in the ECB to exercise its mandates under the Treaty. We welcome the constructive engagement that has developed between the European Parliament and the ECB over the past years.

name: Brian Hayes
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the fact that today’s debate on the ECB is happening on the same day that the Governing Council of the ECB is meeting does not say a lot for Parliament’s scheduling ability, especially as I understand the ECB was not even invited to today’s debate.  The role of the ECB within the new post-crisis supervision and architecture is absolutely crucial: crucial to prevent financial shocks in the future; crucial to secure the confidence of citizens. The decisions taken by the ECB, from quantitative easing to the various programmes of support are working. Growth has returned. Three million jobs have been created in the eurozone in the last year. Inflation is slowly moving towards the ECB target of 2%, and despite all of the Armageddon predictions, the euro remains and has not been fragmented.  The crisis came from light touch supervision. We are not going back to that. That is why we need a strong independent ECB, but that independence must also deliver accountability and transparency, and it is at that level that the ECB has much to do. I want the President of the ECB to appear before all parliaments of the 19 Member States of the eurozone; not just the big Member States. President Draghi has appeared before parliaments in France, Spain, Italy and Germany. It is time that engagement took place at all levels across eurozone countries. We cannot have an inside or outside track. All Member States must be treated fairly. Appearing before some parliaments and not others sends out the wrong impression.  The euro is our currency. We must defend it. The ECB is our central bank. It must treat all Member States with respect, and that is where the change needs to happen.

name: Roberto Gualtieri
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, it is no surprise that Mr Starbatty’s positions are in a minority in this House because they are factually weak and wrong. A broad majority of this House supports the ECB, its independence and its policies because the ECB is the main pillar of EMU and has been a fundamental anchor of its stability and integrity. That such a great responsibility would fall on the shoulders of the ECB was unavoidable, taking into account the peculiar construction of EMU, with the explosive components of monetary policy, coordination competence on economic policy, and a small budget for the single market but not for the single currency. With the soaring debt crisis these responsibilities have been successfully honoured in full compliance with the task and the powers conferred by the Treaties and the Protocol in order to achieve the primary objective of maintaining price stability and to support the general economic policies of the Union, which of course include the integrity of the EMU. The Treaties are crystal clear. In order to achieve its objectives, the ECB and national central banks can conduct open market and credit operations. So it is not surprising that the OMT programme has been declared by the Court of Justice fully compatible with EU law. In the post-crisis phase of low growth and low interest rates, and with the additional negative impact of financial fragmentation on proper monetary policy transmission, other unconventional policy tools have proven to be necessary to meet the inflation objective. I do not need to recall them, but is important to underline that, without quantitative easing (QE), Europe would have fallen into deflation. QE has been – and is – an economic success and for all stakeholders the potential negative side effects have clearly been outpaced by the positive ones. Moreover, economic data clearly show that the necessary sustained adjustment in the path of inflation has not yet materialised. Enhanced non-standard monetary policy measures are to continue until that time.  The ECB is, and has to be, fully independent. Nevertheless, we welcome and appreciate the accountability framework vis—à-vis the European Parliament and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the improvements in transparency of the ECB’s monetary policy. As far as the SSM is concerned, a stronger accountability framework is appropriate and we are in line with our interinstitutional agreement to fulfil our democratic role.  It is evident that the current EMU construction, while it is not unsustainable, is sub-optimal and we need to complete it. We cannot rely only on common monetary policy and national fiscal and economic policies. Instead of contesting the excellent job of the ECB, it would be good if political groups and Member States would contribute to providing the instruments and policies that we need in order to face our current challenges.

name: Sander Loones
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - (NL) Mr President, I often sit here in the European Parliament in my seat thinking: "If this were all a film here, what soundtrack would we hear, what music would be added to the images?" I think that would be Abba: "Money, money, money. It's so funny ..." [sings]. Wonderful things are happening here in the European Union, wonderful things, but there are also many things that go wrong, that really go wrong. And the question for all of us is, "How do we tackle those challenges?". Unfortunately, I find that the Union's answer is all too often: "Money, money, money". We just throw in a big bag of money and our problems will be solved automatically. Mario Draghi also seems to be a fan of Abba. The president of the European Central Bank creates some money and he pumps it into the economy. Is this good for growth? Yes, in the short term. We will buy something today that we would otherwise have bought tomorrow. Because saving does not yield anything anyway, we simply spend our money. But everyone feels that this is growth on credit, that that is not sustainable growth, that this monetary hocus pocus will one day have to stop. And that's not the only side effect of this policy. There are more. The purchasing power of the people is declining. Savings no longer yields anything. Pensions are at risk. Inequality is increasing, between the middle class and the people who are really rich, and certainly between people who are poor and rich. We create bubbles, in the real estate market, on the stock exchange. You can see that this is not a sustainable policy. And that surprises me very much how all the traditional political parties in this parliament defend this policy. We talk a lot here about tax fairness, about fairness. How the hell can you defend that while defending the European Central Bank's policy of increasing inequality? I really can't reach that. I think we, if MPs, if politicians better choose a different soundtrack, a different song, we better not listen to Abba, but listen to the Beatles better, we better not listen to "Money, money, money" but to "Money can't buy me love". I won't sing that, that's for next time, but I really think that's the answer. We will not buy love for the European Union with a bag of money. We won't do it like that. What should we do? Reform. The hard way. Save. Don't take the shortcuts, do whatever it takes. And there, too, the policy of the European Central Bank is detrimental, because it is precisely undermining that need to reform. What annoys me most, however, is the fact that the European Central Bank is not transparent enough about this - it has also been mentioned by my colleague. There is a lot of work to be done there. That is also the reason that we have set up an internet platform ourselves: "wonengeld.eu". We have our next event on June 26 where we will be debating precisely the mandate of the European Central Bank, in Brussels. You are already very cordially invited.

name: Nils Torvalds
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, by way of a metaphor the European Central Bank could actually be described as an operating system. You know from your own experiences with Windows that open-source operating systems (OSs) do not always run very smoothly. (Though if it was a Linux created by a young Finn with the nice surname Torvalds, it would probably be a totally different matter). Sometimes with a bad operating system, we have to run it in safe mode, and that is actually what the European Central Bank has been doing for the last few years. But my dear friend Loones is actually picking up the wrong music: ABBA is not qualitatively high music, it is dancing music for those who like it. It is high time to play Bob Dylan’s ‘The Times They Are A Changin’’. Why? With a forthcoming deal between France and Germany, we will have a time of change in the EU. That again will probably produce a turn back to interest rates. Those who are very interested in medieval politics know that in the medieval world interest rates were thought to be a sin. That is probably slightly the way in which the Central Bank has operated in the last few years. We need to go back to real interest rates, but as soon as we go back to real interest rates, we are going to have severe problems in those countries with a large state debt because what was 70%, 80% and 90% will all of a sudden be 100%. That puts on the agenda a new question: we need the redemption fund, because without the redemption fund those countries will be dragged down by an unsustainable state debt. When we speak about operating systems we know for sure that operating systems have bugs, and some of the bugs in the European system are actually not due to the European Central Bank. They are due to national states.

name: Fabio De Masi
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. -  Mister President! First of all, I would like to thank the previous speakers for not singing. The mandate of the European Central Bank commits to price stability. The ECB has violated the target of price stability of just under two percent inflation for many years, and if it was achieved in the short term, then only through higher oil prices. The ECB has also admitted why this is the case despite the large amount of cheap money: Because the trade unions do not enforce sufficiently high wages despite lower unemployment, because the rights of workers were constantly attacked by the Troika. The ECB is not only responsible for the supply of money, but also creditors and part of the troika. And that is exactly where the problem lies: It has castrated its own monetary policy, for example by repeatedly threatening to turn the euro off against Greece if governments do not implement labor market reforms, wage cuts, etc. There are similar conflicts of interest with banking supervision. There the ECB is the lender of the banks and the supervisory authority. That creates conflicts of interest. For example, it forced the Irish to knock out the ailing Anglo Irish with taxpayers' money. But one cannot, like Mr. Draghi in Jackson Hole, complain about the insufficient investment of the government and enforce cutback policies in Europe with the troika gang. Then the cheap money ends up in the financial markets, not in the real economy. For most Europeans, Aloe Blacc's song “I need a dollar” is a bitter reality. And that's why the ECB must stop blackmailing the member states.

name: Sven Giegold
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. -  Mister President! First of all, I think it's good that this discussion is taking place here, because many citizens are concerned with this question. And so it is right that we should discuss this here. I would also like to say, however, that the way in which you introduced this subject, Mr Starbatty, is something of a scapegoat strategy. We have a common currency, and it was created with a common monetary policy and few rules - incidentally, rules that can be traced back not least to the economic thinking that you taught in Tübingen for years. The point is: This thinking means: you can introduce a common currency with few common rules and few common politics. This lack of a common economic and financial policy, with a lack of enforcement of the few rules that we have, led to the very crisis that made it necessary for the ECB to act in 2012. The ECB just didn't break the rules; after the European Court of Justice, the ECB obeyed it, Mr Lucke. Rather, the point is that the ECB made sure that the euro did not fall apart. And now all sorts of people are criticizing the ECB for it. Part of that is then personalized, like you did, Mr Starbatty, on Mr Draghi. The fact is that the Member States are slender feet. Instead of getting the common economic and financial policy in motion that this currency needs, the ECB is now regularly called to account for it. This is a scapegoat strategy. On the other hand, it is necessary to get this common economic and financial policy in motion in the euro zone so that the ECB has the space to return to normal monetary policy. There are indeed many arguments for this. But of course that would contradict your ideology of renationalization, and that's why you're looking Better a scapegoat - but please not on the back of the unification of Europe!

name: Beatrix von Storch
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Mister President! So today we are talking about the power of the ECB. First, the ECB bought government bonds to protect first Greece and then Italy from bankruptcy. That is monetary state financing and therefore prohibited fiscal policy. Second: Mr Draghi's decision to do everything, really everything, to prevent exits from the euro zone is a clear breach of the law, that is forbidden geopolitics. Third, the ECB has bought assets worth more than four trillion euros. It turns the economy into a zombie like in Japan, that is forbidden economic policy. Everyone has accepted this breach of law for years because they think they can save banks and states from bankruptcy - they are wrong. That doesn't work, you can see that. Nothing is free. The hard working people who are losing their currency. You will pay the price, of course there is no avoiding it. The ECB acts like a criminal organization.

name: Marco Zanni
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the independence of the central bank, that is, the fact that the executive power does not have control over the money supply, is, in my opinion, a concept incompatible with democracy. Putting in the hands of an unelected authority the power to create money outside of any democratic control, leaving it to pursue a senseless goal such as inflation targeting, an instrument that has nothing to do with the dynamics of prices, i.e. money supply, it is insane and undemocratic. The rhetoric that has supported this undemocratic system for decades is based on an assumption that the crisis has disproved, that printing money creates inflation. The need to keep money creation away from politicians would stem from this, from the need to avoid the inflation that everyone now hopes for. I don't know if anyone has noticed that for some time Draghi has been printing and pouring into the eurozone system trillions of euros and what has been the result? Deflation. Inflation does not depend mechanically on printed money, but depends on the demand for goods, on the money spent, and in a depression like the one we are currently experiencing, a government can be sure that printed money is spent only if it spends it itself. Without monetary financing of the expenditure, which the treaties and the independence of the central bank prevent, it will be impossible to revive the economy of the eurozone states. However, in this Union of equal states, where one is more equal than the others, the powers of the state are independent but one, the power of the central bank, is more independent than the others and is therefore what actually commands, making and undoing puppet governments to pleasure. If a politician talks to you about democracy without rejecting this dogma, it is a politician who is lying to you. The central point for restoring a glimmer of democracy is to abolish it aberration and removing this power from the hands of non-elected bureaucrats.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: - Mr President, the publication of the Transparency International report is relaunching the debate on the powers and supervision of the European Central Bank. Thanks to the financial crisis, then that of the euro zone, the European Central Bank has considerably emancipated itself from its initial field of competence, to the point of being able to intervene, directly or indirectly, in the economic and social policies of States. , sometimes by practicing odious blackmail and even by starting to implement it: Greece is an emblematic case and it is not the only one. With the complicity of the majority of this Parliament, it has now acquired quasi-legislative power and control over the entire financial sector thanks to its new supervision missions. As for control, it is non-existent. It is not the ridiculous power of the European Parliament, or rather of a small number of its members, to ask questions or to access certain documents that can replace real scrutiny. By its total independence, its statutes engraved in the marble of the treaties and its irrevocable leaders, except by the Court of Justice, the European Central Bank escapes any responsibility as for the sanction of these actions. The monster has escaped its creators. As in Mary Shelley's novel, the only solution is to kill the monster.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first of all let me say that I was surprised by this topic – by the organisation [of the debate] but not by the result. There is a lot of cheap politicking, especially on this side of the Chamber, and not so much understanding or knowledge. Let me draw from my experience of working in the Central Bank for many years. First of all, central banking underwent a huge change at the end of the last century, going from secretive, non-transparent and politically influenced entities into highly professional bodies serving clear goals. Goals are set by the law as well as by instruments, targets and accountability principles. The establishment of the ECB, together with the creation of the euro, learned from all of this experience and benefited from best practice. That is why my view is very close to the one expressed by the Council and the Commission.  The debate today is not so much about the ECB’s position, but about monetary policy in the last few years; that should be understood. But while the legislator has given the Central Bank the targets, instruments and responsibility, we should not be surprised if they use it. It was an incredibly complicated time. Government fiscal policy did not support a way to get economies out of the crisis and I believe that central banks have done a great job, not only the ECB, but also the others. So, instead of blaming and criticising – especially personally – some people at the ECB, we should appreciate what they did, for the way our economy has got out of the crisis, for the jobs they saved, actually improving the situation in Europe.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, some people wanted to open a debate here that we conduct on a regular basis thanks to the annual report on the Central Bank or in the hearings with Mr. Draghi. But we have to tell the truth, because despite the geographic uncertainties it faces across the Channel and across the Atlantic, the monetary policy that is being conducted is an appropriate policy, whatever the economic challenges we are going through. The euro zone is therefore showing greater resistance than that which could have been anticipated. Its growth, it has been said, is expected to reach 1.7% this year and 1.8% next year. This good streak is not by chance, it owes a lot - as the Commission has pointed out several times this week in its economic forecasts - to the support of an exceptional monetary policy. Yes, the recovery remains too weak and the divergences remain too strong within the zone. But no, the central bank does not deserve to bear the burden of this responsibility. On the contrary, the financing conditions would never have been so favorable if they had not been pursued courageously, with independence, within the framework of a mandate which she was able to interpret in the interests of Europeans. On the supervision side, adjustments may be made necessary as part of the review of the European supervisory authorities. However, they should in no way call into question the single supervisory mechanism, the SSM, this fundamental device of the banking union which makes possible the direct control of around 130 banking groups - including as the Court has just recalled. about Baden-Württemberg's Landeskreditbank - totaling over € 21 trillion in assets, and undoubtedly represents a step forward towards the application of the coherent body of prudential rules in all countries of the eurozone. The supervision requirement is all the more critical today since the Central Bank will have to play a leading role in answering the systemic questions posed by the United Kingdom's exit from the European Union, in particular that of the supervision of British CCPs and that of the future of netting contracts denominated in euros. Beyond the risk of post-Brexit regulatory easing, the European Central Bank will finally have to tackle the thorny issue of non-performing loans, NPLs. In this regard, the publication, last March, of its guidelines on the handling of these bad debts is a step forward that will improve the daily dialogue between banks and their supervisors. However, it will be necessary to go further to resolve this problem by considering, as a priority, the establishment of a genuine European framework which would allow dedicated asset management companies to collect these non-performing loans.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: -  Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, I would like to address my colleague, Mr Gualtieri, to point out that this Parliament has adopted a report that was very, very critical of the European Central Bank. So the claim that the ECB's critics are in a small minority is not entirely justified. And there is a reason for that. Because the measures that the ECB has taken in the past are - I believe we all agree - have been extraordinarily unusual measures - measures that no other central bank would have taken ten years ago, with the possible exception of that Central Bank of Zimbabwe. We have to recognize that the question of whether the ECB has exceeded its mandate is a topical and relevant one. Nobody contests the independence of the ECB within its mandate. But the mandate must be verifiable. And the problem is we don't have a control mechanism. In Germany we have brought a constitutional lawsuit against the ECB. But in Germany you have to prove that the federal government is violating the democratic principle of the Basic Law in order to be able to open the procedure at all, in order to be able to take a promising action against the ECB's mandate being exceeded. That can't be a state. Parliament must put in place control mechanisms for the ECB and for exceeding mandates.

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, banking is extremely important, especially for its support for investment and consumption. It also has a special feature: when banks make a profit, it is shared by their shareholders; when they make a loss, it is borne by taxpayers. In Portugal, Portuguese taxpayers have already paid more than 20 billion euros in losses from private banking. There is another extremely important aspect, which is the ease / lightness with which private bank managers are called upon to perform public supervisory functions at central banks and the speed with which they pass to the management of those private banks. For all these reasons, for all these bad examples, it is necessary to extend the powers of the European Central Bank and strengthen its powers so that it can exercise strict banking supervision throughout the European Union. Only then will banks be put back to the service for which they were created and for which they are largely benefited by public authorities and European taxpayers.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, the European Central Bank is the umbrella of our common currency, the euro, and it needs both independence and transparency and democratic accountability. I am one of those who have often and harshly criticized the European Central Bank, but for the opposite reasons of those who go to the far right of this room and some Berlin conservatives to accuse Mr Draghi. Ladies and gentlemen, the quantitative easing program is a positive step and we in Greece are looking forward to making their decisions in the Eurogroup, so that Greece can also participate in the quantitative easing program. And I have to say that the European Central Bank has done more in recent years than governments have done to protect employment, given that we have an imperfect monetary union and an imperfect banking union. If we want development and social cohesion we must deepen ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr. president. Look, I have many questions about the Bank's democratic control: because of the letters that were sent, about the operation of the emergency liquidity line, about how the bond purchase program works ... But look, about the issues that you raise, on the legal question, both the Court of Justice of the European Union and even the Court of Karlsruhe have issued judgments saying that what the European Central Bank has done is within the legal framework of the Treaties. You have already lost that debate, the legal debate. The one with the arguments, too. But the legal one, too. And, if we get into the mandate debate, I have to tell you that the measures were indeed within the mandate, because what the European Central Bank prevented was deflation and some Member States went bankrupt. And that, obviously, was part of the mandate. Then we can obviously talk about the issues that were raised in the troika - on which, for example, the Court has also issued an opinion - and, also, about how the extraordinary measures are being applied, but I will finish with this. The debate on whether the measures of the European Central Bank fit into the Treaties, you have already lost that debate.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am very happy that my colleague Starbatty and his delegation have scheduled this debate, because it is essential in this House to talk about the euro, to talk about a currency that is creating enormous imbalances between the countries that they have adopted it. 19 countries that clearly have different needs in terms of monetary policies and, also denoted by the political clash in this House, on the different needs of their countries to adopt different monetary policies, of how a single policy is not able to solve problems in terms of inflation and the need for interest rates. Therefore, unfortunately, until there is a common economic and monetary policy, a solution will never be found. The problem is that, while trying to create this hypothetical and very utopian construction, there are some shocks and I thank the German delegation, which is one of the few delegations in this Parliament if not perhaps the only one, who admits that Germany it is accumulating a large trade surplus, in part due to a euro that is undervalued for its economy. Now, do we want to solve this question at the root? Can we find a solution? All right, let's give the countries that are in economic need and that have to make investment policies, by the countries in surplus, a share of what they are earning. Perhaps in this way we will be able to give a little more oxygen to certain countries that today suffer from an overvalued currency for their economy. Moreover, if Macron and Mrs Merkel say that the treaties can be revised, very well, let's review them, and let's review them for what are the economic constraints, because it is not possible that at this moment where there is a need for public investment there is no opportunity to revive the economy. I conclude by saying that a single monetary policy can never solve the problems of 19 countries who have different needs and this is the issue on which we must focus in this Parliament and the political discussion in the coming months.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF).
text: - (NL) Mr President, I would like to call on the EU-critical Members of this Parliament - fortunately there are more and more - to focus our euro criticism not only on the European Union itself, but especially on the eurozone. For much more than the European Union - we have seen that the United Kingdom has been able to withdraw from it, freed itself under the Treaty - much more than the European Union itself, the euro area is a prison, and more precisely a prison without door, which Mr Draghi recently underlined by saying that there is nowhere foreseen to leave the eurozone. If I then see what people have to do and do here, on a daily basis, to keep that eurozone stable, with Capital Market Unions, with European deposit guarantee schemes, with European unification of cover bond systems, with the further development of that banking union, if I see here how infrastructure , pensions, wage policy, pensions, all our budgets, being sniffed out by the European Union, when I see, after the Macron case, how here, until this morning, in great enthusiasm a new Minister of Finance for the entire eurozone, a new European Parliament , euro debt, euro bonds are being introduced, and when we finally see the arrogance with which the ECB is taking more and more power, yes, then we have to conclude that we are moving towards one socio-economic standard zone that suits the southern Europe - because the debt remains cheap and can continue to grow - which is good for Germany - because Germany's standard economy consists of hiccups within the eurozone about a currency that should normally be 30 to 50 percent more expensive in international trade. There is a monster covenant that rules us. The standard that has been set is: "If Marine Le Pen does not become president, if Geert Wilders does not become prime minister, then the European Union has voted for more social, economic unity, for more European Union.That is contrary to the European idea itself.The European idea is based on differences and not on the unity that one creates here.

name: Steven Woolfe (NI).
text: – The ECB is supposed to be independent, but as everybody in this room knows, it is merely a pure political vehicle for the monetary control of European countries. We could see that when Mario Draghi, the chairman of the ECB, said that he would do ‘whatever it takes’ to save the euro. Well, ‘whatever it takes’ cost millions of lives in poverty and unemployment in Greece. It was a transfer union from people in the North to try and save the South, but asked for austerity programmes even more. When we saw Cyprus depositors lose their money, and when we see the pension industry, the many young people in this audience today should be concerned that their futures are at risk because pension industries and insurance industries will not be able to pay for them in the future. He may have saved the Union for the moment, but he has left a time bomb of destruction under the European nations. It has not gone away, and I pray: do something now, before it explodes and causes all of Europe to have a problem once again.

name: Werner Langen (PPE).
text: - Mister President! I consider Professor Starbatty's fundamental criticism to be excessive and wrong. The ECB is independent, not bound by instructions, autonomous based on its mandate. We do not - and I am sure you do too - do not want a central bank that is subject to political horse trading. That is why this is important. Second: You can discuss the instruments and the goals critically, and you contradicted your colleague Lucke - or vice versa. You said the EP is closing your eyes. Mr Lucke said we had made a critical report. It doesn't go together. Third, of course there are problems with the ECB. The ECB thought it could stimulate the economy with monetary policy against the productivity advances in the IT industry and against falling oil prices - that was a mistake. But these are also design flaws. Why do we not have voting rights based on the liability shares? That is a question to ask. Why does the ECB define the inflation target itself? In the contracts it says “not less than 2%” - self-defined, by Mr. Trichet! Why was it not actually possible to separate states and banks? No, the loose monetary policy has brought the banks even closer to the states. So a number of critical points that can and must be discussed. In conclusion, I would like to say: Mr Draghi is here regularly, we also criticize him, and that is why the question of democratic justification is not appropriate.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the truth is that I appreciate this debate because it is a good opportunity to show that this Parliament does scrutinize the work of the ECB; that, together with these discussions, the regular follow-ups in the Commission - the annual reports - accompany the work of the ECB with a critical analysis. In any case, Mr Starbatty, you cannot tell us that the ECB is not complying with the Treaty or with its objectives. We have been in permanent breach of the inflation target for five years; we have been in serious risk of deflation; inflation has not reached 2% for, as I say, five years. So everything we have done - mainly since 2012 - everything the ECB has done has helped to achieve that goal. It is true that it could have done it before, as the Federal Reserve did in the United States, and have saved us a lot of costs and a lot of suffering in this crisis, but for this we would have needed a fiscal pillar in the eurozone. Something that we are going to have to build in the future. It is true, in any case, Your Honor, that monetary policy can generate some distortion, as we are seeing in the current account surpluses in some countries: in Germany, in the Netherlands; But, to correct those problems, we need an investment policy in those countries. In order to correct these imbalances, there is fiscal policy, which is still national, in many cases, and therefore the problems with current surpluses we have to correct with fiscal policy in the Member States. We can, in any case, also talk about reforms of the Treaties; And there, my group will be there to support growth, to see if that inflation target - as Mr Langen said - can go through budgetary control, and of course so that the benefits of the ECB, which are for all Europeans, go to contribute to the budget of the euro area.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the European Central Bank cannot be out of control. It must be accountable to the European Parliament, as its decisions have a decisive impact on the economic and social life of the peoples of the Union. At the same time, transparency in the functioning of the ECB and the elimination of conflicts of interest are required because the ECB cannot be both a monetary authority and a supervisory authority of the systemic banks and a member of the troika. I propose that the European System of Central Banks become more flexible and more decentralized. In this context, the national central bank of each euro area Member State must become the ultimate lender for that Member State and be able to pursue a monetary policy tailored to the needs of that Member State's economy, using a range of non-conventional monetary measures as tools. and in particular quantitative easing, up to the national central bank's shareholding in the ECB capital.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, in 2015, Mario Draghi claimed in a letter to me that the ECB didn’t prevent the burning of our senior bondholders in Irish banks, but then the Irish parliamentary banking inquiry found last year that the ECB had indeed blocked burden share. We’ve learned that Mr Draghi’s predecessor, in correspondence to the Irish Government, stated in black—and—white terms that the ECB threatened to cut emergency assistance to Ireland if the government didn’t request a bailout, and then demanded a series of austerity measures and a fire sale of public assets, against the opinion of even the IMF. Where exactly in its mandate does it say that the ECB has the power to do this? Its so—called independence is pure fiction. In reality, we all know that Mr Draghi is completely reliant on the Governing Council and the Eurogroup, an organ that doesn’t even exist in the treaties. So now we hear that new initiatives are being dreamt up by the Commission about introducing democratic oversight of the euro. They are meaningless unless they are about democratically and dramatically reforming the ECB, and a key part of that has to ensure that the ECB is accountable to national parliaments, as well as to this House.

name: David Coburn (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, honourable Members, even before the Brexit referendum, the ECB was trying a power grab of UK financial services, in an attempt to restrict clearing of euro—denominated derivatives to inside the eurozone. The EU – or ECB rather – was unsuccessful then, but the French and now a German MEP repeated the suggestion. In fact, Manfred Weber appeared to go further last month, and sought to exclude London from all business conducted in euros. What better example, honourable Members, can we have of the EU’s ability to cut off its nose to spite its face. London clears derivatives and currencies from all over the world without being in political union with third countries. For the EU to introduce geo-blocking of euro clearing would be a message to the whole world that the euro should not be regarded as a global reserve currency. Manfred Weber, as leader of Merkel’s Christian Democrats here in Strasbourg, should think twice about what the EU might lose if it seeks to punish Britain and the city of London. The EU will quickly discover that an economic blitzkrieg is a double-edged sword.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Ansip! By the end of the bond purchase program, that is to say by the end of this year, the European Central Bank will have invested 2,500 billion euros in the purchase of bonds and debt instruments. The bank’s total assets will increase to over EUR 4,500 billion by then. That's more than the Federal Reserve, that's more than the Bank of Japan, so an all-time high. Despite this enormous amount of money, however, the bond purchase program in the member states has not succeeded in implementing structural reforms or reducing indebtedness. But on the contrary. Take Italy as an example. The country has a 20% share of non-performing loans on its bank balance sheets, a national debt of 133% of GDP, that is 2003 billion euros, and the lowest economic growth in all of Europe - lower than Greece or Cyprus. The experts say that there are only two options when it comes to dealing with Italian debts: Either the member states help the Italians with communitisation and restructuring, or the ECB continues its crisis policy. In view of the improvement in the economic situation and in view of the inflation rate that we now have, which is already very close to the EU's price stability target, I would say that it is high time to introduce a monetary policy change so that the member states are actually warned implement their structural reforms.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Mr President, the European Central Bank pursues a policy of non-transparent inequality vis-.-Vis the Member States and primarily serves the interests of Europe's strongmen. It could play its role as a national bank of a sovereign state, that is, to devalue the euro or to service the debt of a state, in order to avoid inflation and maintain the creditworthiness of weak states. On the contrary, while it is an obvious necessity and usefulness of issuing Eurobonds, the Bank succumbs to the refusal of the German Government. Under the Treaty, the European Central Bank is not controlled by democratically elected representatives of the peoples. This independence has turned into impunity. Its prudential supervision of credit institutions and its contribution to the stability of the financial system is deliberately set aside for selfish purposes. For example, its guilty silence when the socialist Simitis government in Greece copperplated the deficit and public debt data to enter the eurozone. The mode of operation and accountability of the European Central Bank must change. The prosperity of the citizens of the Union is paramount, not the wealth of bankers and corrupt politicians.

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the title chosen for this debate, ‘Powers and control of the ECB’ is unfortunate, I have to say, as the ECB does not control, and nor should it be controlled by any political institution. The European Central Bank’s political, institutional and legal independence is fundamental to the fulfilment of its mandate, and I think we should be very clear on this. The ECB has remained an indispensable actor during and after the euro crisis of the past years. During this time, the ECB has acted within and on the verge of its mandate, in order to enable price stability and to achieve its monetary policy objectives. We have seen in January 2015 that the inflation rate was minus 0.6% and now we are seeing that we are very close to the 2% target. But of course with great power comes also great responsibility and democratic accountability. The ECB is directly accountable to the European Parliament. In the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs we have constant dialogue with the President and the Vice-President, but clearly more has to be done. Number one: cooperation of the ECB and the European Parliament can still be further developed through more far-reaching communication between the two institutions and, number two: trust of the European citizens in the euro and in the ECB is of great concern to us. The public has to be able to understand the monetary policy of the ECB as transparency is vital for the credibility of the euro area and the trust which the people have in our common currency.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D).
text: - Mr President, as you would expect, this debate on the ECB's powers and control has become a way not of building solutions to reinforce the Central Bank's transparency and accountability, but of combating the Bank's expansionary monetary policy European Central. We know the argument well. All European responses to the crisis were initially accused of violating the institutions' legal treaties and mandates. Monetary policy is no exception. The truth is that the situation of the European economy today would be much worse without the ECB Thes contribution, and a precipitous decision to withdraw the stimulus to the economy would be an error, a grave error, which would jeopardize the recovery of the European economy. Of course, those who fight the ECB thes expansionary monetary policy think more of their own interests than of the common interests of Europe, but it must be those that we must remember that it is not the ECB thes mandate either. The ECB mandate is to uphold the eurozone as a whole, and we hope that it will continue.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: - (NL) Mr President, you must obey the law all over the world. This also applies to the ECB. But unfortunately the ECB is in breach of the EU Treaty on at least two counts. Article 123 of the Treaty states that the ECB may not buy up debt securities. The bank has been doing that for years anyway. And they use a trick for that, namely by not buying those debt certificates directly. As a result, the ECB is not violating the letter, but it is clearly violating the spirit of the Treaty. Article 127 of the Treaty requires the ECB to allocate resources efficiently. The ECB has now bought up € 2.500 billion in debt securities. As a result, interest rates are so low that pension funds run into problems, Member States do not implement reforms and the value of the euro is also historically low. The ECB's policy of "pumping free money into the economy" thus violates this article of the Treaty as well. How would it happen, Mr President, that so many citizens increasingly distrust the EU? Three guesses…

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, what is the life and state of the European Central Bank? In 2011, the then President of the European Central Bank, Mr. Trichet, threatened the elected governments of Ireland and Greece that he would cut off liquidity to banks if they did not take further austerity measures. In 2015 in Greece, a coup d'etat was imposed by Mr. Draghi on capital movements to punish the Greek people who sought salvation for their catastrophic austerity and unsustainable debt. The European Central Bank is therefore a mechanism for enforcing financial blackmail and coups, in order to punish people who question austerity and privatization with suffocating economic conditions. Memorandum governments can succumb to these blackmails, but the Greek people with closed banks in 2015 said a resounding "no" to the Draghi-Juncker ultimatums. Today the Greek people are on a nationwide general strike, they are fighting against the austerity measures, they are fighting against the constant memoranda of the troika where the European Central Bank also participates.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF).
text: - (NL) Mr President, the euro would deliver many things: full employment, permanent growth, a healthy investment climate. But in reality, the euro only provides discontent, instability and a flow of money from North to South. We have a negative interest rate that makes victims among anyone with savings.
