And this is all done under the direction of the ECB. This bank is supposedly independent and not political, but in practice it is only concerned with keeping those Member States going that lack the political will to tackle budget deficits. However, the ECB's sole task is price stability. The fear of deflation has completely disappeared, inflation is now approaching 2 percent and core inflation is also stable. The United States has meanwhile hiked interest rates, because the crisis is over. Brussels has also said this: the crisis is over. And so now we will know. Will the ECB ever raise interest rates again? I am convinced that will not happen again. The ECB is no longer a central bank. It has become one big money press for the southern euro countries, at the expense of, for example, the Dutch pension funds. The bill for the Netherlands is therefore increasing. Madam President, we no longer have a choice: the Netherlands must get out of the euro.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D).
text: - Thank you very much, Mr President, two things are important, I think, to be clarified: firstly, if we are talking about a much more successful, much more important, much more attractive euro area, then we will have to talk about solidarity within the Union. euro. We will have to talk about member countries of the monetary union, of the euro area that are in solidarity with each other, surplus countries, deficit countries. We must understand that within the euro area we cannot have countries that are doing well and countries that are doing badly without repercussions. Secondly, I have heard it said that the European Central Bank is not fulfilling its mandate. I think it is fulfilling its mandate very well, but unfortunately it is a limited mandate, unfortunately it only refers to price stability, to inflation in the euro area. I believe that we need a much stronger European Central Bank, a European Central Bank that also talks about economic growth, that also talks about the fight against unemployment, a European Bank that deals with citizens first and only then with banks.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: - Mister President! The European Central Bank is abusing its position in the long term because it provides countries with loans that private investors no longer trust, and at interest rates close to zero. One day this devastating policy will end in disaster and people will say: Look, the market has failed. However, the truth is that the market has been overridden. The example of Italy shows what the debt policy is doing: interest rates have fallen steadily over the past ten years, debts have increased immensely. Today Italy and, more recently, France have more absolute debts than Germany, although their economies are noticeably smaller. The Germans are so stupid that they pay for it all. Target 2 claims: new record, foreign claims in the form of foreign assets: also a record: liability with the ECB - another record. And as if that wasn't enough, the new political superstar, Mr Macron, is calling for Eurobonds, which means even more debt. And then we just wonder where all these extremists come from.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, let's be honest: the European Central Bank is, at the same time, the central bank with the greatest powers and the least control in the world. The problems arising from the powers of the European Central Bank have three different orders. First, it is the conflict of interest between the different functions of the Central Bank that, from the outset, deals with monetary policy, is a supervisor, in short, a policeman and a thief, and nobody controls it. The second problem has to do with the ECB's mandate. The ECB's mandate makes it an unimputable bank in the face of the economic and social consequences of its monetary policy. The third problem is - beyond the limits of the ECB's mandate, which simply do not exist - that the ECB acts in all areas that it sees fit to act, whether in the economic areas or in the social areas, going so far as to design programs of adjustment by financially putting pressure on countries with governments with a political orientation that is different from that of the ECB, as happened, for example, with Greece. So, talking about democratic control, Mr. President, just look at this Parliament. ECB officials come here to explain when they feel like it, say what they like; if they don't feel like saying anything, they fill us with emptiness and emptiness. But in reality, the ECB has no control and, as I said, it has the most power and the least control of any central bank worldwide.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, an independent central bank is key for credible monetary policy. Independence goes hand in hand with clear accountability arrangements and independence does not exclude lively discussion about how the ECB carries out the tasks and duties conferred upon it by the Treaty. Today’s topical debate was part of this discussion. I am sure your monetary dialogues with the ECB President will provide many opportunities to discuss your views directly with President Draghi also.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - The question of the distance between citizens and European institutions involves its institutional architecture, which is based on the euro and European economic governance. It does not seem that the shortcomings of this governance - which I have repeatedly emphasized here in terms of the necessary implementation of the transparency of tax treatment - have been filled neither by the 2014 Investment Plan for Europe, nor by the ECB's quantitative easing. , which also proved to be an extraordinary tool for rebalancing the fundamentals. But the question is that of the centrality of the lacuna of a true European fiscal and anti-cyclical policy. The passive logic of merely monitoring the compliance of national fiscal policies with the rules of the fiscal compact must be abandoned and the question of the establishment, with active logic, of an anti-cyclical fiscal policy for the eurozone must be faced with courage. In my opinion, this change must have two privileged and non-replaceable players: the ECB and the European Parliament, to ensure solidity of intervention but also adequate democratic accountability and ownership of the citizens on the governance of the euro.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I do not share the discourse of those who defend that the euro was poorly designed: at least not from the perspective of those who created it. The independence of the ECB means that national financial systems and debt markets are at the mercy of international capital, which has complete freedom to decide which policies and investments are financed and which are not, ultimately giving it control over the economy and budgets of the ECB. Member States. In this sense, adding new levels of governance or strengthening the powers of the Central Bank seems to me only an attempt to formalize and legitimize the functioning of the ECB during the crisis: that the same blackmails Greece and Spain to apply labor reforms that go to private auctions of large multinationals to finance them at zero cost. I don't think this is the way. The ECB must subordinate itself to the public authorities, national and European, and go to the public debt markets when financial capital loses its predatory appetite for them. Only in this way will it generate the stability necessary to finance the social and public investment policies that Europe needs.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - The ECB is taking political decisions that are not its own, with little or no control from the European Parliament. Their actions in Greece or in the Spanish State are examples of how their decisions are neither neutral nor independent, and serve to favor the large banking employers and speculative markets to the detriment of the popular classes. The European Ombudsman has accused him of giving inside information to actors in the financial sector and Transparency International of overreaching by making "political" decisions. That is why we consider it urgent to put an end to the business that debt entails. That the ECB leaves the Troika and does not act on behalf of the financial actors or the interests of the strongest economies, forcing the States of the South of the Union to undertake social cuts to maintain the liquidity of their banks. Do away with revolving doors. To empower the European Parliament to exercise real and exhaustive control of the ECB. That the ECB really guarantees the end of the banking financial scandals and that in no case the losses in this sector end up compromising public services, pensions, natural resources or public goods.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the report by Jean-Maria Cavada, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on ensuring the cross-border portability of online content services in the internal market (COM (2015) 0627 - C8-0392 /2015 - 2015/0284 (COD)) (A8-0378 / 2016)

name: Jean-Marie Cavada
text: protractor. - Mr President, the French situation presupposes that we are available for comments, since we are in the process of forming a government with a strong European density. I come to the report and I would like to welcome this agreement because it takes us a very important step between the three institutions and will allow the application of this regulation, in a concrete way, at the beginning of 2018. This proposal was eagerly awaited by citizens. Europeans, who will now be able to travel by taking the services to which they subscribe in their own country. The regulations will apply to services provided for remuneration; therefore, the principle of maintaining copyright is sanctified and underlined by this text but we are introducing a new freedom which is quite important, that of being able to move temporarily and to temporarily benefit from the services available in our place of residence, in our country of origin. The definition and means of verification of the Member State of residence constitute a very essential provision for the operation of this system. The text is sufficiently clear: the service providers will have to verify the country of residence of the subscribers and the checks will be carried out in accordance with the rules of the European Union, namely in particular that they will not transgress the rules relating to the protection of individual freedoms. and at the discretion of the data. From this point of view too, this text is very balanced. Likewise, a verification exemption system is also provided for in the event of an agreement between the service providers and the rights holders, on condition that all the rights holders to the content used by the service provider are specifically included in the 'agreement and that there be no fraud in the State of residence. In order to prevent abuse, it will be possible for the service provider, if he wishes, to verify in a closed list of possibilities, in particular by means of the IP address, if there is no fraud to this agreement, so as to maintain the balance between the two aspects, copyright, of a on the one hand, and freedom of movement for temporary trips, on the other. I know the need for our digital single market to be able to reconcile the exercise of intellectual property rights and the freedom to provide commercial services. This regulation has therefore succeeded, in reality, a gamble which appears to many, for ideological reasons, to be difficult but which, with a little common sense and a will not to impoverish European creation, can be applied without any difficulty. Today, I hope that we can all complete this text so that we can start negotiations between the three institutions which allow rapid implementation. In this regard, I would like to thank the Commissioner for having taken a step towards the various requests that we had made in this direction and I hope that we will lead very quickly to the application of this regulation, probably in 2018, as I said so.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, we all know that those roaming surcharges will be abolished in the European Union very soon. The 15 June will be the end date of those roaming surcharges for European citizens, and if people do not have to pay those high roaming surcharges anymore, they would like to get more and more access to their legally bought digital content even when they travel in other EU Member States.  We know that 20% of European citizens spend at least ten days during the year in some other EU Member State, and many of those people travelling in some other EU Member State would like to get access to their legally bought digital content; to their favourite movies, TV series, music, video games, e—books, audio books, sports events, and football, all of which are really important. But today, they cannot do so. We have to provide legal access to digital content for our citizens. We know that according to public opinion polls, even 20% of internet users in the European Union are using VPN to get access to digital content. Even 68% of film viewers in the European Union say that they are using so-called free downloads. This is a problem. Authors are not fairly remunerated. So, I am happy that we were able to reach consensus in this cross-border portability proposal, and I am absolutely sure that all the European citizens will also be happy. I would like to thank the European Parliament, and especially the rapporteur, Mr Cavada, and all the shadow rapporteurs, and I would like to ask Parliament to vote in favour of this very important proposal.

name: Carlos Zorrinho
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Industry, External Trade, Research and Energy. - Commissioner, I would also like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on the joint work that has been possible. We all know that it is very important to define legally the procedures to ensure effective cross-border portability of online services and content, but that does not dispense with the harmonization and modernization of technological infrastructures at European level and a very strong fight against the digital exclusion, caused either by qualification problems, either due to problems of economic difficulties or geographical restrictions. This opinion, of which I was rapporteur in the ITRE Committee, contains very relevant contributions in legal and procedural terms. It allows you to differentiate between service payments and license fee payments. It ensures that creditors are bound by the contractual conditions established on the date of entry into force of this regulation. It ensures the duty of information regarding the quality of services. Establishes the definitions of subscriber, consumer, Member State of residence, temporary stay. Defines simplified verification mechanisms. It guarantees technological neutrality. All of this is very important, but, as the Commissioner also mentioned, to take advantage of this opportunity it is important to develop a European digital identity that is founded on digital inclusion and technological leadership and, for this, it is very important to integrate this regulation with the Telecom Package, with the rules for the end of Roaming or with the implementation of the WIFI4U initiative. Only in this way will we be able to make portability a measure that benefits everyone, that develops the market and that specifically benefits European citizens. Our ambition must be, first of all, to reconnect European citizens with the European project and to implement measures that influence and improve their daily lives. And this regulation under debate is a good example of such measures.

name: Marco Zullo
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on the excellent work he has done. Today Europe is increasingly aiming towards the mobility of citizens and therefore the impossibility of freely using digital services already legitimately purchased is a barrier that is no longer sustainable, so this regulation is good, which overcomes this difficulty for citizens. But I would like in the future to move towards a vision where there is no discrimination against citizens on the basis of the administrative borders of a Member State. As rapporteur of the IMCO commission I am happy that many of the principles we have enunciated have been maintained, therefore no time limit (to temporariness) to allow those traveling for work and also for study to access this service; absolute prohibition to trace the user's data; absolute prohibition of processing and storing user data and, therefore, maximum protection of users' privacy and above all, no additional cost to use this service.

name: Sabine Verheyen
text: Draftsman for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! With the regulation on portability, we are taking an important step towards realizing the digital single market. We have succeeded in working out a balanced compromise which, on the one hand, enables citizens to access their legally acquired content - even across borders - and, on the other hand, adequately protects the rights of rights holders, which also ensures cultural diversity in the future. The well-functioning system of European film funding and the principle of territoriality could also be protected by a flexibly designed verification system, and this was a particularly important concern of ours in the Committee on Culture, because we are convinced that we are promoting cultural diversity and strengthening the European film sector can only be achieved at the present time by maintaining the territorial principle and a long period of time is needed to be able to establish new structures here permanently. A large number of Europeans who are temporarily abroad within the EU for various reasons - be it for work, for study or for leisure activities - will benefit from this regulation because it enables them to use their home program, which they legally do acquired to take with you when traveling. This corresponds to our ideas of mobility and the freedom to access content. I welcome the fact that we have a clear legal framework here, which on the one hand takes data protection into account, but on the other hand also gives room for maneuver that is flexible enough to also implement various verification systems so that we can apply them here can still remain simple and guarantee the necessary legal security on all sides. I think, A good compromise has been achieved here, which takes us a significant step further.I would like to take this opportunity to thank the rapporteurs and the shadow rapporteurs very warmly for their work.

name: Angelika Niebler
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the European Commission, ladies and gentlemen! I, too, should first like to address my warmest thanks to our rapporteur. Monsieur Cavada, you did an excellent job! Not only did you ensure that we reached an agreement on this proposal in a short period of time, I also found working with you to be extremely effective. There are few dossiers in which we can achieve something for our citizens in such a short time. And that brings me to the topic. I am delighted that today we have really created something that our citizens can really experience and experience - the Vice-President of the Commission has already mentioned it: I am delighted that we will no longer have roaming surcharges on June 15, that everyone will have their own Smartphone can access its services in the European Union. And one step towards achieving something positive for our citizens in this Europe is the portability regulation, which we will vote on tomorrow. I very much hope that there will be broad support and approval from all sides. What has it achieved? If you go on vacation to another European country today and you take a book with you and you open this book and see that there are only blank pages there, then you would be disappointed and couldn't believe it. However, this is exactly what often happens nowadays with online services with subscriptions that you have ordered online, that you have paid for in your hometown and in your home country - games, films, sports coverage, etc. cannot be accessed. In the future, thank God, this will be possible with this new portability regulation. I'm from Munich. I am really happy that in future I will not only be able to watch FC Bayern soccer games at home. I have a Subscription that allows me to do this online, and in future I will also be able to watch the football matches of my home club when I have business here in Brussels or Strasbourg.This is something great.I am pleased that all citizens of Europe will be able to do this in the future.

name: Victor Negrescu
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, this report represents a new and important step towards facilitating the free movement of people and services in the European Union. It enables European consumers who subscribe to online contact services acquired legally in their Member State of residence to continue to access the service when they are temporarily in another Member State. I congratulate all colleagues who worked on this report and salute the important contribution of the Maltese Presidency in making this happen. To be more exact, the Portability Regulation ensures that consumers can use portable online contact services which offer access to music, games, films, entertainment programmes or sporting events not only in the Member State of residence but also when they are temporarily present in another EU country for purposes such as leisure, travel, business trips or learning mobility. We are speaking about almost 6% of the European population, around 30 million people, and the number could grow by 2020 up to 70 million beneficiaries. This regulation includes not only people who travel but also students studying abroad, people who work for a limited period of time in another Member State or cross-border commuters. I am glad to say that we, the European Parliament, secured in the trilogue important achievements, defended strongly also by my group, the Socialists and Democrats. I refer here to: the absence of specific time limitations; the deletion of the formulation ‘regularly returns’; the closed links for the means of verifications; the restrictive IP checking in binary format; the safeguards in terms of data protection; the promotion of study mobility as an example for the use of portability; or the provisions that allow the waiver of the mandatory verification of the Member State of residence. These are great achievements, and it is important to mention that the European Parliament promoted them, but we have also to be clear that this report is implemented without affecting either the copyright protection framework or the principle of territoriality. I really believe this regulation is an important step for building a common market, but also a common society where European citizens feel free to move in any Member State without restrictions or limitations.

name: Sajjad Karim
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to start first of all by thanking my friend the rapporteur Jean-Marie Cavada on delivering what is for European Union citizens a real breakthrough. For far too long we have tried to work towards deconstructing borders, only today to find ourselves in a situation where our citizens can physically pass through a border, but a big part of their life stops as soon as they do so because they cannot access the digital content that rightfully belongs to them. Therefore, it was essential that this matter was dealt with, and I congratulate you for the approach that you have taken and the well-balanced inclusive solution that you have arrived at. That balance has been struck between consumer rights and right holders. It was essential that this Parliament delivers a strong message of support to the rapporteur’s work. I will certainly do that, and my Group also, through the trilogue outcome, which we will be voting on tomorrow. I truly believe it is a digital single market success story. It strikes the right balance between providing online content to consumers while they are temporarily outside of their own Member State, whilst ensuring that sufficiently robust residency verification safeguards are in place for rights holders. I am happy to see that the verification methods strike the right balance between being effective but respecting data protection rules in order to avoid abuse. Service providers will do so by verifying a subscriber’s country of residence through payment details, an internet contract or an IP address check. Slowly but surely, the digital single market is being addressed and consumers and rights holders can both be happy with the outcome of this report.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, seamless access around the European Union to online content services is important for the smooth functioning of the internal market and for the effective application of the principle of free movement of persons and services. It is also important for many of us to fully enjoy our time with family and away from work. With the adoption of this regulation, we are helping to ensure people moving through Europe for leisure, business or learning are not blocked from their legally purchased content and, in many cases, access to their own language and culture. The ALDE Group promised all voters two major items during the European elections: an end to roaming and an end to geo—blocking. With this vote – the vote on the end of geo—blocking of legally owned content – we show that we keep our promises. We have allowed our citizens to take their internet everywhere with them in Europe and after today we will allow them to take their digital content too. We pay for this content and no—one should tell us where we can and cannot access it. Never again will you miss your favourite TV or radio shows just because you are travelling in Europe.

name: Martina Michels
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, dear colleagues! Yes, it is unfortunately true: up until now we have not even been able to use music, films or our favorite series that we have bought online across borders in Europe. Yes, the new portability directive will finally remedy this, which is why we will also agree. But it is also true: from a cultural-political perspective, this is just a mini-step. Because the current public debates alone show that some actors in the cultural small-state system want to go on sleeping. HBO / CBS or other platforms like Netflix have long since conquered the hearts of the audience with their own European productions. Wherever geoblocking begins to falter, major viable political solutions have so far been out of sight. Yes, it is about the business model of the large and small European film and music producers. This is not a conflict-free debate about opening up the territorial principle. But we must finally lead them and ask how European film and music producers can be successful across borders today so that European cultural exchange beyond festivals is part of everyday life.

name: Julia Reda
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Europe is a union, and yet we still have digital borders between Member States today. On this day we are creating a small exception to those borders. People will no longer be blocked from accessing the videos that they have already paid for just because they are visiting another country.  That is good. It is common sense and it is an important step forward, but this has to be the first step of many in the fight against geo-blocking; it cannot be the last. Geo-blocking will remain a widespread problem when this regulation is enacted. According to the Commission, almost 70% of video sites in the EU geo-block. Our own Parliament Research Service has estimated that people are actually willing to pay almost a billion euros extra per year if geo-blocking is abolished altogether. That is income, and that is an audience that we are currently denying our European creators.  Now the film industry has voiced quite a lot of concerns. Some feel that they have come to rely on geo-blocking as the sole means for their business model. Let us work together to find solutions to that, but the solution cannot be to accept virtual borders. The status quo is simply not working for consumers. It is failing at making Europe’s amazing cultural diversity accessible to all Europeans.  Let us be clear: geo-blocking is a form of discrimination. A common European public sphere cannot develop with geo-blocking in place. It locks European audiences out from European works and it locks artists’ international borders. ‘This video is not available in your country’. Let’s put these words where they belong, not on the screens of European internet users, but in the dustbin of history.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- I listened very carefully to your speech.I understand that we have taken a small step in the field of online services, but if we are to go into other fields of copyright, then it is somewhat in conflict with the principle of territoriality, which is entirely specific to this field of law.So can you cite a specific legal or other instrument, so that we do not have to violate this principle and at the same time comply with your understandable efforts to cross borders?

name: Julia Reda (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Mr President, thank you very much for the question. The Portability Regulation will ensure that, when you go on holiday to another country, you can access content that you have already had access to in your home country. But those who find themselves permanently on the wrong side of the border – for example, linguistic minorities or language learners – cannot benefit from that. I think the overall effect of geo-blocking on the film industry is negative. On average, a European film is only legally available in two to three countries outside the EU. This means that there are a lot of paying customers who do not have the possibility to access this content legally. We need to take into account the possible revenues that could be created if there was a legal offer.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, portability allows a person who has subscribed to an online service to continue to use it when they are temporarily traveling to another Member State of the Union. So in itself, the idea is interesting. Several observations should, however, call for caution. First of all, the proposed text is a regulation and not a directive; it will therefore be particularly restrictive for States. Then, it risks ultimately calling into question the right to geo-blocking, which is a component of the sovereignty of States. In addition, he suffers from a serious internal contradiction in not specifying the time limit for stay in another state giving rise to the right to portability. As a result, portability risks becoming a principle and not an exception. Finally, the text risks promoting global offers which will jeopardize the territoriality of copyright and which will lead to a reduction in the diversity of offers. Once again, the Union will thus promote the concentration of offers for the benefit of multinationals. For all these reasons, I will vote against this text.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: - Mr President, in the eyes of a young person, today's debate will seem empty and meaningless. In the age of the digital revolution, access to all kinds of web content services is extremely easy, long before the Commission decides to legislate on the subject. In any case, the report we are discussing today does not guarantee the personal data of the users either, it provides excessive possibilities to the companies while, on the contrary, it rightly states that a full release would have a very negative impact, both on the users of these services and on the national economies and especially in the production of music, television series, films and other genres related to artistic creation and copyright. I agree with the position on temporary access for those moving between the Member States of the Union, but I believe that it is necessary to set a specific day limit, as this will not be the only way to do so. Finally, you all have to admit that European citizens today face much more serious problems that need to be solved and do not need the Commission to legislate on issues of no real value that society itself has solved.

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! The fact that our common European market is still divided into 28 pieces is only gloomy proof that we still have a tendency to think limited to the borders of the country in which we live on a daily basis. But this regulation, which we will be adopting tomorrow, shows that we are slowly moving in the right direction, and I take this opportunity to congratulate both you, Mr President, and our colleague Jean-Marie Cavada and all colleagues who worked on this regulation . The world is changing faster and faster and one of the current challenges is to ensure that consumers can freely use the online services they have bought, also outside the country where they live, and today (we are adopting this regulation tomorrow) the consumer will no longer have a problem e.g. . watching his series, match or what he likes best, while traveling. And we urge our citizens to the so-called mobility during a business trip, vacation or otherwise spent time outside of your country. But this is just one step, the next steps are ahead of us: the portability of digital content will only be fully used when we do not have additional roaming charges in the European Union, and this is in a month. This will happen on June 15th. The next step will be to remove unjustified geo-blocking, etc., and finally our citizens will really be able to feel at home throughout the European market, as I wish all of us.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Vice-President Ansip, the regulation on portability of online content is one of the first concrete measures of the digital single market strategy presented by the European Commission. It constitutes the first stage of a wider path, aimed at eliminating all forms of unjustified geo-blocking and which will contribute to concretely realize the idea of ​​a common space of rights and opportunities for European citizens. The creation of a European digital dimension of the single market also starts from the recognition of the possibility of using online content acquired in one's country of residence, films, music, games and sporting events can be seen throughout the territory of the Union, even when outside our country of residence, on the occasion of travel, study or work. Although today only a limited segment of the European population is involved, the numbers are set to increase exponentially, reaching 72 million European citizens by 2020. The legal fiction underlying the regulation expands the opportunities for consumers without compromising the protection of copyright and the quality of the creative industries, an important element of the European development model. Our commitment in the internal market committee has focused precisely on finding the right balance between the need to provide consumers with an agile and effective tool, rigorous protection of privacy, legal certainty and the protection of copyright. I believe the final agreement effectively summarizes these considerations. It is only regrettable, Mr President, Commissioner, that once again the Council did not have the same ambition as we do in providing for a more streamlined verification system and a faster implementation period.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Mr President, Commission representatives, colleagues, first of all I would like to thank my colleague Kawada and the shadow rapporteurs for their hard and consistent work and for the result achieved. This agreement will be an important step towards improving the quality of life of the citizens of the Member States of the European Union. Probably each of them was in a situation where he had a subscription for an online service, temporarily moved abroad and did not have access to the service for which he paid and to which he was a subscriber. This challenge to the Digital Single Market Strategy not only creates an unfair burden on rightholders, but also causes legal uncertainty and somewhat restricts the free movement of people and the rights that flow from it, such as the Treaties of the European Union. I hope that, as a result of the tripartite meetings, we will see this significant change within nine months. A difficult agreement has been reached through difficult negotiations, which will not only address the challenges of portability, but also ensure that rightholders have effective safeguards in place to verify their residence so that they can reap the benefits of their subscriptions wherever they are. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question.- President!Honorable Member,I also share your joy, and I am extremely pleased with the results that you have listed, but I would like to ask if you share with me my concern that there is a service that is still stuck and not in the single European market.does it work according to the market?Namely, that if I call you from my own country on a mobile phone, it is definitely a foreign call.If I do the same from abroad, it’s much cheaper, of course, even though we’re talking about the same phones in the same way.I ask: do you share my concern that this should be changed?

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: answer a question asked by picking up a blue card. - Thank you, colleague, even if it is a joy - it is not a joy. These are normal things in political life. As for your question whether it should be reconsidered, in my opinion, yes, it should, but it is a matter of negotiations between the telecommunications operators with whom you have a contract. These are to some extent also private-legal relations. But sooner or later this question will be asked - to equalize the telecommunications operators that operate in the field of digital technology and those that provide cable service. So, yes, this will happen sooner or later.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the report on cross-border portability is a great step forwards for the Digital Single Market. With the increased mobility of Europeans and the abolishment of roaming charges, it was a logical step. The creation of this legal fiction will ensure that all Europeans who travel to another Member State will have access to the content they have paid for in their own country. It abolishes borders for all kinds of online services that many people use, be it for music, e-books or movies. However, our work is still not finished. Access to content across the entire European Union is still not possible. As a consumer, I cannot gain access to the French version of Netflix unless I am resident in France. Access to European works across the entire EU is still limited.  This is not the only point where the goal of a digital single market has not been reached. At this point we are regulating the internet through different directives and regulations. In practice, this is a real problem. Most of the legislation which is adopted in this House is handled by different committees and there is a lack of cooperation and communication. As a result, the outcome is sometimes completely contradictory. There is a real lack of legal certainty. It is unclear whether the e-Commerce Directive prevails or how the relationship works between the Portability, Copyright, AVMS and InfoSoc [Directives]. There should be clear coherence when we regulate the internet, and not an approach which consists of bits and pieces. The Portability Directive is a success, but the outcome will not be the same in other digital files. We have to stay focused on our Digital Single Market goals.

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Ansip, ladies and gentlemen! The portability regulation, which we now have to vote on, is a big step for consumers in the European Union. We can finally take the content that we paid for with us to the other EU countries, for example when we go on trips, when we study or work there temporarily. That is a huge gain, it cannot be downplayed, it must be made clear what the European Union is for us for. Nevertheless, we must of course continue to work together on the question of the digital single market. This means that further progress must be made in the area of ​​standards, including data protection and the issue of copyright law. We must also continue to work on the issue of cross-border access to services, with geoblocking, to dismantle the borders in Europe, but at the same time, of course, ensure that the interests of those who produce content, for example, are also protected.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this regulation will technically also be a step forward for consumers, but politically it is a failure which justifies absurd logic of maximizing profit even at the expense of privacy and European citizens. This is a very small advance which represents the minimum wage and betrays the vaunted goal of the digital single market. I turn to you, Commissioner Ansip, did you really imagine that you were creating the digital single market which was one of the five political priorities of the Juncker Commission? In fact, I cannot understand why we allow multinationals to freely circulate capital and to take advantage of European tax havens, even in an incorrect way, by subtracting precious resources from the community and by engaging in forms of unfair competition, especially towards small and medium-sized enterprises. , while citizens and consumers cannot benefit from the single market. For me this situation is unacceptable and I am fighting to change it. The Court ruling says that the clause that guarantees absolute territoriality is against the treaty, we have also heard this from other interventions. I do not want to maintain this status quo, which I find ridiculous, and which I also think is illegitimate and unfair for European citizens.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF).
text: -  Mister President! We are particularly familiar with the problem of portability of online services due to our massive travel activities. But it doesn't just affect us, it affects millions of people in Europe who cannot access certain services. If, for example, someone has signed a contract with Amazon Prime in their home country and wants to access this service elsewhere, they will of course be annoyed that this contract cannot be fulfilled by a contract partner in another country. So it is almost our duty to recognize and process such things in legislation and to make them workable for the people in Europe. However, it should be noted - and this has already been mentioned a number of times today: this also includes rights. There are holders of rights whose rights could possibly be violated. Special consideration must be given to this. So I say: the journey is only beginning with the matter of online portability.

name: Ева Майдел (PPE).
text: - Mr President, European citizens want visible and rapid results from our work. This regulation is a concrete response of the European Parliament to the citizens, but it is also a fulfilled promise that I made to our voters. In 2018, every European will be able to use their subscription to books, music, movies, TV series or sports programs, wherever they travel in the European Union without any restrictions on the content, without restrictions on the number of devices or their functionality. the service. And most importantly - no additional costs. This is a step forward in securing a single digital market for all Europeans. And that is exactly why I thank the rapporteur and my colleagues with whom we worked on this regulation in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. However, in order to have a truly and functional digital single market, we must continue to work with the same and, I would even say, faster determination on other files, including those on privacy and personal data in electronic communications. , The Electronic Communications Code, the Digital Contracts and Digital Services Directive, as well as the Commission's expected actions towards cybersecurity and online platforms.

name: Γιώργος Γραμματικάκης (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the regulation of the development of a single digital market has, in my view, been rightly a primary concern of the European Commission. Portability will ensure that European citizens traveling to other countries have free access to digital content and services they have of course purchased in their own country. It is therefore a first but very important step towards a better future in our digital world. So, as the Socialists' rapporteur on the Committee on Culture in this technical but important, I think, dossier, I would like to emphasize that this regulation concerns the portability of digital services and, of course, not the cross-border access to artistic content. The latter would have a negative impact on artistic creation and, above all, we all know it, on European cinema, because it would challenge the principle of territoriality, which is an important source of revenue for the financing, production and distribution of European films. It is worth noting, however, that preserving the principle of territoriality and promoting European works is also our top priority in the revision of copyright rules, which is fortunately well under way. So the balanced and correct result that has been achieved proves once again that the tension between consumers and artists is misleading and often national. Culture is indeed one of the foundations of the European idea, as long as it does not dwell on declarations but is confirmed, as with this regulation, on a daily basis.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! The use of online audiovisual services is an increasingly common way to access movies, broadcasts of sports programs or music. Unfortunately, the user of such a service still has to face various barriers that prevent him from using purchased subscriptions during a temporary stay abroad. I am glad that with this report we meet the expectations of consumers and enable them to take with us not only smartphones or tablets, but also the right to use online services which they have already purchased in their country of residence. Of course, this regulation only applies to specific cases and is not intended to change the current system of territorial licenses. All rights of authors must be properly secured and protected in this regard. I am convinced that this is a very important and necessary step in building the Digital Single Market and hopefully we will go further along this path.

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, this agreement on the cross-border portability of content is to be welcomed, because it corrects a flaw, a loophole in the European Union, which is an area of free movement of citizens, goods and services. We have the tendency in the digital world to create barriers that should not even be there in the first place. Maybe it is because of fear of losing control. When you buy a film on a DVD, nobody takes it from you when you cross the border. So why would we prevent citizens from watching a film that they are paying for at home with an online subscription when they are crossing the border? Abuses can always come along, and in this respect I hope that the service providers will use the most user-friendly means of verification, such as e-IDs for example, to check the home country of the citizen. I wanted the use of IP addresses, in that respect, to be stricter than that, and I hope that the enforcement of this law will safeguard the individual’s right to privacy. Last but not least, I think that taxpayers should also be able to watch the content that they have already paid for in their home country, for instance with a broadcasting fee. Although this is only voluntary, I hope that many public broadcasters will be innovative and proactive and deliver such a possibility for the users.

name: Michel Reimon (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mister President! I have a small tablet here that I like to use to watch an episode of a series in the hotel room late at night. When I open this in my hotel room here in Strasbourg, the first thing I see is a button I can press: View abroad too. I'm here at the seat of the European Parliament and I'm supposed to watch series abroad. I think that this entire discussion is still far too little about, it is not about an internal market and market regulation that we are doing here. The question is whether people who are here, who travel to the seat of a parliament that represents them, feel at home. Can I cross a border in Europe, can I use my devices, my culture, my technology as I do at home? And do I feel at home, or am I abroad if I only travel a few kilometers in Europe? In a digital world, this is a fundamental question, and we have to ensure, as with roaming, that European citizens - not just consumers - feel at home, and this regulation at least partially ensures that. It's good.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: - Mr President, this regulation on cross-border portability is a good job, because it brings concrete benefits to Europeans. My first words, of gratitude to Mr. Cavada and to the entire team that has made it possible for this Regulation to see the light. Those who have legally paid their music, cultural, sports, series and other services in their country of residence, when they temporarily move to another Member State of the Union, may transport all these contents. This complies with the free movement of services and also free movement, which is one of the main freedoms of the European Union, in such a way that online content will travel to any place in Europe with the person who has legally contracted them. It was, without a doubt, an urgent need. One in three Europeans asked for this to be regulated. In fact, the population wants to take advantage of all digital technologies to be able to enjoy cultural content. And it is a success story, because an intelligent balance has been made between the interests of the authors - who have a whole series of rights and who demanded the principle of territoriality, and also demanded temporality - and the interests of the users, who see the interest they had culminated today. Therefore, progress is being made in the digital single market and progress, as I say, in the free movement of goods and services.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR).
text: - (NL) Mr President, colleagues, soon anyone who has paid for an online service will also be able to consult that service when temporarily abroad, from Netflix users and football fans, from people who like to read an e-book to people who likelisten to music, from students to vacationers and business people.Finally I would say.I think it is a big step forward for consumers who can thus enjoy the benefits that the European digital single market has to offer.Incidentally, I am also very pleased that the special position of the audiovisual sector will be protected by the incorporation of solid control mechanisms.I think this is very important for the formation of the identity of language and cultural communities, of smaller language and cultural communities such as the Flemish one.

name: Marietje Schaake (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Every step towards a true digital single market in Europe is very much welcomed. After abolishing roaming costs, supportability is another concrete step that internet users all over the Union should enjoy. It is essential that in our policies we look at the public interest and at our principles, not at certain business models or niche interests. Watching the content you have paid for when on holiday or studying or working abroad is a no-brainer and this is especially important when it comes to publicly funded content.  Now we need to go on to NGO blocking and ensure modernised and harmonised copyright fit for the 21st century, enabling access to content, not punishing audiences. We have to address this and we will be addressing this through a variety of legislative initiatives: the AVMS directives, platforms, copyright reform and electronic communications code in the SETCOM legislative proposals, just to name a few. And the risk of course, is that the different pieces of this legislative puzzle won’t fit, and that the bigger picture gets lost. I think we should all be responsible to keep the big goals in mind.  At the digital single market mid-term, I therefore urge you to be more ambitious and focus on the coherence between the various initiatives at our tables. Of course, we support you as Members of the European Parliament, members of the Liberal Group, to ensure the public interest is preserved in a hyper-connected world. But I think this message is more directed to the Council that sometimes seeks to enjoy the fragmentation and the positions they have without looking at the common interest of a strong and well-functioning digital single market for Europe.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: - I would like to begin by thanking the colleagues in the Committee on Legal Affairs who took part in this proposal, in particular Mr Cavado. The introduction of portability represents an important step forward in the development of the digital single market. EU citizens rightly expect to be able to use the services they pay for, even when they enjoy free movement rights within the EU. Portability is thus not only a response to technological development, but also a response to the needs of European citizens based on increasing mobility between Member States. Today, when every practical example of the benefits of EU cooperation is needed, we should take citizens' expectations very seriously in these other areas as well and try to meet them. I thus perceive the successful introduction of portability as a very good, but still the first step in a wider effort to reform copyright, which will reflect the needs of the 21st century and use the potential of the digital single market.

name: Емил Радев (PPE).
text: - Mr President, congratulations to the rapporteur, Mr Kawada, on the work and negotiations on this report. I am pleased that an agreement has been reached that will allow our citizens to have access to online content such as music, games, movies, entertainment not only in their Member State of residence, but also when they are temporarily in another member country. Thus, when traveling for pleasure, on business or for educational purposes in the European Union, they will be able to enjoy their music and films for which they have paid in their country of residence. Until now, users who were temporarily in a Member State other than their Member State of residence often did not have access to online content for which they had legally acquired the right to access and use it in their Member State of residence. The fact that, under the new provisions, online content service providers should not charge their subscribers any additional charges for ensuring the cross-border portability of online content services will contribute to increasing the use of these services throughout the European Union. This initiative will also improve the free movement of people and services in the internal market. Of course, this should not be to the detriment of authors and their copyrighted works. Authors must retain their freedom of negotiation. Consumers and online service providers must continue to comply with copyright requirements.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D).
text: - Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate and thank the rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs for the work done. It is a real service to our fellow citizens. Next summer may be a bit early, but before long, when these citizens go on vacation to the European Union, they will be able to continue enjoying their favorite music, series and movies, since it This is what it is about. We can understand that it is quite natural, when you subscribe to a service, when you buy it, to be able to continue to benefit from it. In addition, this portability service for audiovisual services throughout Europe is a continuation of the abolition of roaming charges: from the moment we set up connectivity throughout Europe, it makes sense to also allow the access to these services across the Union. I also welcome this text because it reinforces and maintains the need for fair remuneration for the work of actors, authors, directors, the investment of producers and all those who contribute to audiovisual creation. and who can, in this way, retain their ability to make a living from their work and to receive legitimate remuneration. I therefore find this text very balanced and, I repeat, very beneficial for all European citizens.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, thank you. First of all, I would like to congratulate Mr Cavada on his work. I believe that this report is an important step in defining any corner of the European Union as 'home' for every European citizen. In this context, the free movement of persons must be doubled by access at a reasonable cost, both to the Internet and to digital technologies, while respecting copyright and maintaining a balance between the providers of such services. The adoption of this report meets the needs of citizens and offers solutions that will remove the restrictions that prevented them from benefiting from digital content in their travels. Europe must take advantage of the digital revolution that has transformed the world on all levels and in all areas, providing opportunities for citizens but also for businesses. An important step is the cross-border portability of online content services. With the entry into force of this measure, the share of portable users of subscriptions to online services is expected to increase by 2020 to around 72 million people in the European Union. The elimination of roaming charges, the unblocking of e-commerce, the portability of online content services in the Member States create the premises for a digital single market and a single space. In this way, citizens and businesses can carry out their activities, innovate and interact without barriers and in safe conditions, thus guaranteeing the prosperity of all.

name: Tiemo Wölken (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Ansip! The invisible borders of the digital single market must be abolished. This regulation is a first step in the right direction. The regulation is a great success, especially for the citizens. Legally acquired content will thus be accessible throughout the EU with full functionality, in the same quality and as usual at home. The principle “legally acquired, legally streamed” applies across the EU. I warmly welcome the fact that the regulation applies to all content. It is a great success that the regulation expressly does not contain any upper time limit for the temporary stay, there is no obligation to return to the country of residence and providers are not allowed to limit the duration of use in the general terms and conditions. However, we cannot rest on what we have achieved. There is still a long way to go before the full digital single market is achieved. In particular with the CabSat regulation, for which I am the rapporteur, we must not fall behind what has been achieved in order to guarantee cross-border access to the broadcasters' media libraries.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: - The limits in the field of mobile roaming have been falling for ten years, and in a month they will finally fall. At first, only a few believed, although it seemed impossible at first, despite the strong resistance of mobile operators, we were not intimidated by the path that lay ahead. The old regulation unfairly punished everyone who telephoned or sent messages abroad, so we were obliged to end it. Not only have telecoms, however, taken the side of the mobile service users from whom they finally live, but the governments of the Member States have also had to take the side of their citizens over these long years. With this, we have achieved another important victory in the realization of the idea of ​​the internal market. However, we must not lose our breath. When it comes to the benefits of our citizens, we run long distances. Namely, consumers are still burdened by the high costs of cross-border calls and SMS within the European Union, which we make from home. A situation where calls made abroad are cheaper than calls made from home is unacceptable. Telecoms make profits at the expense of unfair commissions. Commitment to a truly single European telecommunications market, we must not afford this. If the issue of roaming has been a testament to the functioning of the European Union for the benefit of European citizens, we must do the same for so-called calls and texting within the Union. It is now an opportunity to prevent further abuses of the internal market and to offer our citizens new proof of the functioning of the European Union, proof that they will feel in their pockets.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! I, too, will congratulate Mr Cavada and the team that negotiated this excellent agreement during the trialogue under the Maltese Presidency in February this year. These new portability rules for EU users allow citizens traveling abroad to use online content services purchased in their home country. I understand this approach, which is intended to make it easier for consumers to access content legally acquired or subscribed to in their country of residence. However, we must not forget about the creators, because in the European cultural diversity they create and deliver high-quality products and cultural content to the European market. That is why this agreement gives us, as consumers, new opportunities, but at the same time it is supposed to protect creators and entities investing in the production of cultural or sports content. I believe that this is a balanced solution and a positive signal for creators and consumers.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - I am very pleased to welcome the process of negotiating this regulation today.This, ladies and gentlemen, is exactly an example of a specific provision of European law that we can happily communicate to our citizens and show how the EU is helping the lives of normal ordinary Europeans.On Friday, I will be lecturing to high school students in my country about what the EU is doing for citizens, and I will certainly mention the story of this regulation there and show what we are doing specifically for them.So I congratulate the rapporteur and the Commissioner, and I hope that other parts of the digital market will succeed by the end of this legislature.With this regulation, we are tearing down a specific part of digital borders and giving consumers the opportunity to use their services, online content in another EU country.It is a clear advantage, congratulations on that, and we can build a new EU image for our citizens on this.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with the spread of online content services and the increasing use of portable devices, the expectation of European citizens to be able to use online content services wherever they are in the European Union has increased. Currently, when traveling within the European Union, users cannot benefit from this cross-border portability or can do so only to a limited extent. Removing existing barriers to the use of online content and services will allow effective satisfaction of user needs, but also further advancement of innovation, clearly to the benefit of consumers, service providers and rights holders. The agreement reached is particularly timely at this historic moment, also in view of the abolition of roaming charges within the European Union. Consumers' demand for cross-border portability is set to grow and I believe that the removal of obstacles to the use of online content and services could be a significant step towards the creation of a true digital single market, the benefits of which will only fall. on all citizens of the European Union.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr President, single market issues are often secondary to political integration.The emphasis is unfortunately on something that cannot work, further political integration, and neglects what can work even better, and that is the single market.This report is certainly a step in the right direction because we need to ensure that the same rules apply throughout the single market and that services and products are available to all citizens regardless of their place of residence.Telecommunications have long been under the absolute protection of member states, and telecom companies with their large lobbying capacities have been a major barrier to the advancement of the European single market.After the abolition of the roaming fee, we are now going a step further with the transfer of Internet content services.It is a big and welcome step that will make life easier for the citizens, so I can only welcome it.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, I welcome my colleague Cavada's report because it represents an important step towards equal access to the Internet and the content of all citizens of the European Union.I certainly agree that consumers with subscriptions to Internet content services that they have legally purchased in their country of habitual residence must also have access to them when they are temporarily in another Member State.Consumer access to the cross-border portability of Internet content services will certainly contribute to the better functioning of the internal market, which is primarily based on the free flow of services and goods.I believe that a clear distinction needs to be made between portability and cross-border access so as not to jeopardize the sustainability of funding for the European audiovisual and film sector, which is based on the territoriality of law.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the digital revolution has really brought ups and downs. We have a single digital market in the European Union that has really, in the first instance, also abolished high roaming charges. We are now discussing an important issue, such as the cross-border portability of online content, ie an opportunity for citizens in another country to be able to use the digital content they have purchased or subscribed to, ie to be able to use games, music , entertainment programs, e-books, etc. From this we can consider that portability is essentially a monitoring of the principle of free movement and services and individuals. In other words, the citizens of the European Union should be able, at no extra charge, to use this online content, which they have paid for in their own country. Of course, we must take care of the protection of copyright and the protection of all those who have copyright, because this is crucial if we want to have additional intellectual property and creation in the future.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, when talking about a cross-border portability regulation, we are talking also about people visiting today the European Parliament. When talking about the low portability of digital content, we are talking approximately about 100 million European citizens a year. Our people will get access to their legally-bought digital content, but when talking about low portability of digital content, we are talking also about our authors. Authors have to be fairly remunerated. We respect the principle of territoriality, but just one and a half years ago there were quite different understandings of what this principle of territoriality really means and what this absolute exclusivity means. For some people it was about absolute exclusivity when they even knew that 68% of those film viewers are using free downloads. According to my understanding, it was very relative understanding about absolute exclusivity. For me, absolute exclusivity means 0% or 100%. I am happy that we were able to find this common language with creators, and I am sure creators also believe – and they are right to believe – that they will be much better remunerated just because of this cross-border portability regulation. I agree with those people who said that we are just in the beginning of the process. We have to create a digital single market in the European Union, and I hope our cooperation will be also fruitful when we deal in a detailed manner with abolishing of unjustified geo-blocking in the European Union.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada
text: protractor. - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank our colleagues for all their more or less satisfied appreciations. The credit goes to everyone who worked on this case and, first and foremost, to the European Commission. From the outset, the current Commission had been extremely compelling about the need to create a digital market. It was a good thing, but many ulterior motives persisted, both in this chamber and, probably, in other European institutions. What I like about this text as well as the positions you have gradually taken, Commissioner, is the idea that a dangerous prejudice needs to be exposed. Yes or no, should the digital market crush those who create the contents of this market? In other words: is the great European digital single market directed against creators, who should fold and abandon any form of law or control of law? Commissioner Ansip, dear President, you have committed your word and shown by this text that you had taken the opposite option. No, the digital market is not adversely affected by territoriality or geoblocking, contrary to what is said from time to time, including here, nor - naturally - the fair remuneration of copyright. Indeed, this copyright remuneration is the absolute backbone of one of the European values, and not the least. Concretely, around 530 billion euros a year come from creative activity. If this backbone were to be abandoned, by geo-blocking or by the elimination of territoriality, this would mean that we would open our doors wide to the main Anglo-Saxon and American groups which, in some cases, already use in their commercial activity content that they have not purchased, which is in principle prohibited in any form of commerce - and I am glad that your colleague, Mrs Vestager, be vigilant to sanction these facts. On the other hand, these same groups - and I draw your attention for the texts to come - allow themselves, thanks to our weakness, to pay their taxes where they have tax facilities and not where their consumers are. Commissioner, from this point of view, I would like us to have extremely demanding discussions on the texts to come. There is no shortage of people to say that slicing the Digital Single Market issue by topic is a strategy. I believe I can count on your good faith - you have just demonstrated it -, but we will naturally be very vigilant about what follows because it is defending one of the very great European values ​​to defend the single market for authors through their territoriality and their fair remuneration. With regard to this text, I would like to congratulate myself once again and thank you, dear colleagues, dear President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, for the excellent and intelligent cooperation that we have been able to have.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 18 May 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: in writing. - Despite the popularity of mobile devices and the ease of traveling within the EU, many internet services are still geographically blocked. According to the European Broadcasting Union, 11% of European households purchased a video-on-demand service in 2016. It is estimated that by 2020 this percentage will double. More than half of this market belongs to the American distributor Netflix. The regulation adopted during the current plenary session will allow online access to your favorite series, program or music, purchased in one Member State, to be used throughout the Community. Such unlimited access to multimedia services will be granted to people who are staying abroad for recreational, professional or research purposes. This report builds on the orphan works and collective rights management debate and is another step on the way to modernizing copyright in Europe, which I am currently working on. The regulation should remain simple to apply so as to benefit as many European citizens as possible when moving for a shorter or longer period to other EU countries.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing.- Tomorrow we will vote on legislation which will allow European citizens who subscribe to films, music and TV series online to access this content even when they are abroad.Almost one in two Europeans is affected.Concretely today, 49% of Internet users in Europe listen to music, watch videos and play online.But when you go outside your national borders, you can not, or little, access the online content services to which you have subscribed and therefore cannot obtain the movies, tv series, music, games, or even the best.sport events.We have managed to remove these restrictions and ensure that citizens can access all this online content wherever they are in Europe, during their travels or international business trips.Good news for the consumer.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - Mr President, thank you very much for the floor. The European Union's single market must adapt to the digital age and, with it, to technology that is rapidly evolving and upgrading. Services must be available to people throughout the Union, regardless of the Member State in which they were leased. It is also one of the four freedoms. I therefore welcome the lifting of cross-border blocking of access to online content. I believe that easier access to services will bring with it many positive effects, such as a more diverse and better offer. More supply means more consumers, more consumers means expanding the industry and thus creating new jobs. We need to take advantage of all these opportunities that digitalisation offers us. With new technologies, of course, come new challenges, and we must not forget the dangers they bring. Consumer protection must remain a primary concern, regardless of industry. I therefore call for clear and transparent regulation that will protect users' personal data and at the same time offer everything it has to offer.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the implementation of Regulation (EU) 2017/458 as regards stepping up checks at the external borders using the relevant databases.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, not long ago this plenary debated the new rules on reinforced border checks. I am happy for this opportunity to debrief you on the state of play since these new rules came into effect on 7 April and the results achieved so far.  But first, let me recall why these new rules were adopted. The aim is to increase the internal security of the European Union as a whole, and the systemic checks are also to address in particular the threat from foreign terrorist fighters. The extended negotiations ensured the right balance between the security needs and the freedom of movement. During this lengthy period, Member States have had the time to prepare for the entry into force of these new rules. The Commission has provided financial support to Member States to make the necessary investments at the border crossings.  Thanks to this preparation, in many Member States the waiting time due to the new rules has not caused excessive delays, but indeed, in some cases, the waiting time at the external borders has increased. In particular at the land border between Slovenia and Croatia the waiting time exceeded a few hours during the Easter holiday period. However, we should note that even before the new rules started applying, some crossing points at this border section experienced occasional delays of up to two hours. Commissioner Avramopoulos and his services are in close contact with the Croatian and the Slovenian authorities to find the operational solutions to the situation at this specific border section. As a follow-up to the discussion between President Juncker and the Croatian and Slovenian prime ministers in the margins of the European Council on 29 April, an on-the-spot visit took place on 8 and 9 May at the most affected border crossing points. Following this visit, all parties agreed on operational guidance on the implementation of the new rules. This will take into account the specific situation of this border section to limit the impact of the new rules at this specific border to the minimum.  To sum up, we are doing our best to ensure increased security at all external borders while minimising the impact on EU citizens, as foreseen in the new Schengen Border Code.

name: Kinga Gál
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner! Maintaining the security of its citizens must be a primary goal of all decision-makers. It is essential that we know who is entering the territory of our countries and that is the only way to prevent further tragedies from happening. At the same time, the introduction of controls on the entry and entry of EU citizens at the Schengen borders must not jeopardize the Union's greatest acquis: the free movement of EU citizens. It cannot happen that there are several hours of waiting between two Member States on certain border sections, such as the Hungarian-Croatian or the Croatian-Slovenian border sections just mentioned. Yet even summer tourism dumping has not started. It is becoming increasingly difficult to explain to our citizens in these countries that it is impossible to travel from one Member State to another while the uncontrolled arrival of uncontrolled masses in Europe continues. This situation needs to be remedied. I therefore call on the Commission to take steps not to make the free movement and daily life of our citizens impossible while maintaining the security of EU citizens.

name: Tanja Fajon
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - On April 7, I was also among the thousands of affected passengers, who waited for 5 hours or more to leave Slovenia for Croatia. The chaos we were constantly reminded of has happened.
