In the negotiations, we pointed out the impossibility of systematic screening of passengers with colleagues in parliament, my country warned, the profession warned. We have adopted a measure which, Commissioner, is unrealistic and reckless, without a proper study to examine the effects on transport, tourism and the economy. I understand and agree that the safety of our citizens comes first. I support all sensible and thoughtful measures that also ensure this. But this is not the last resort. What we have done with the disproportionate overhaul of the Code is, unfortunately, proof of a mere headless and ineffective European policy. Every weekend, thousands of tourists, weekenders who go to the Croatian coast, cross the Slovenian-Croatian land border. In recent weeks, we have witnessed sharpened rhetoric on both sides of the border, mutual accusations and also the powerlessness of border authorities left to their own devices. This is not a European policy that instills confidence in the people. In a situation where Slovenia, with a population of two million, also has unjustified control on the border with Austria and Italy, we rightly wonder whether Schengen is still working at all, or whether the European policy for ensuring security and managing migration is on the right track? Does the Commission still have reason and decision-making power, or has it succumbed to the interests of individual countries? As border controls are not a bilateral issue, I would like to know, Commissioner, whether you intend to formally include the agreement between the Prime Ministers of Slovenia and Croatia with Commission President Juncker that countries can carry out targeted passenger checks when the waiting period is longer than 15 minutes. I expect you to take action, otherwise, as a negotiator in other key dossiers in the field of migration and security, I will take new action with a much greater degree of restraint.

name: Monica Macovei
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Thanks. In the context of the entry into force of the Schengen Regulation amended on 7 April this year, it is important to know that the European Commission has funds for the internal security of the Union from which each country has received money through national programs and the money must be used. For the period 2014-2020, about EUR 3 billion is available for the borders and visas component alone. Slovenia also received money to ensure smooth traffic for those crossing the Slovenia-Croatia border. So is Hungary and all the other countries. It is very important how this money was spent and how much it was accessed by the Member States. First of all, mobile and fixed scanners need to be bought so that the identity data of people crossing the border can be quickly verified in databases. Such a check takes ten seconds. If a problem with that person appears on the single screen of the scanner, then check separately. The rest of the people pass quickly. That is why I hope that Slovenia, Hungary, Romania and other countries that have not yet done so will do so as soon as possible, precisely to help those who cross the border to cross it quickly and to ensure their security and life. the health.

name: Ivan Jakovčić
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. - Madam President, Commissioner, please listen to me carefully because I may be the main culprit for this item being back on the agenda today. Friday 7.4. when the Decree came into force, I was returning home from the last Strasbourg session and at the Kaštel-Dragonja border crossing I was greeted by a 2-kilometer column in which I waited for 2 hours. On Saturday morning, I immediately wrote a letter to President Juncker and Prime Minister Plenković, who really called me after an hour or two and promised to arrange a meeting with Prime Minister Cerar and President Juncker. That meeting really happened on April 29, and the result of their conversation is that in case the waits in the columns are longer than 15 minutes, they will switch from total to targeted controls. The intention of the three friends is good, but it aims more at calming outraged citizens, rather than at the right solution to the problem of unnecessary delays. After all, in practice this is subject to the arbitrariness of individuals and is not formalized at all by any regulation. The correct solution is to introduce targeted controls as a rule, as a written rule, especially at border crossings where security risk is minimal, and to introduce total controls as an exception only in the case of risky intelligence. Namely, this Regulation 458 does not objectively solve the problem of security of citizens, but significantly complicates the lives of especially those people who live along the border. I therefore ask the Commission to immediately propose a revision of the regulation and take into account the fact that targeted controls, which were in practice until recently, have proved to be an appropriate solution. And three more absurdities. The Commission is 15.5. reduced the GDP growth forecast for Croatia due to “unusually long columns at border crossings” because it directly harms tourism, which accounts for 20% of GDP. Thus, on the one hand, the Commission proposes regulations and then, on the basis of their non-implementation or enforcement, gives a negative forecast of economic growth. A concrete absurdity is what happens when a tourist who has already passed the entrance control to Istria wants to go on a day trip, for example, to Venice.There he is again greeted by several hours of control, which makes such excursions a torment, not a pleasure.I am sure that you share my opinion that the main absurdity is that we went from Yugoslavia to Italy and Austria easier than from Croatia to Slovenia and vice versa today, and we are both members of the European Union.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, a month after the implementation of the regulation on systematic border control, we are back in plenary to discuss the difficulties encountered, unsurprisingly: it was predictable, but perhaps a little quick. It was inevitable that these systematic checks, far from making borders more fluid, would have an impact on traffic. We did say so. In the front line are the airports, where customs staff have not been increased and where the queues have lengthened as a result, prompting the reaction of airlines. The same goes for land borders, especially the most exposed, with particular difficulties between states, whether or not they are members of the Schengen area. It must be said that implementing the new regulations at the time of the Easter holidays requires a certain sense of humor which tourists, especially Swiss, German and Austrian, have paid the price by going to the shores of the Adriatic, passing through Slovenia and Croatia. And the same dysfunctions must have been observed in Romania and Bulgaria. What solutions do we offer? Go back to targeted checks, in defiance of the stated security objective. Under pressure from the Council, once again, systems were hastily adopted and put in place without testing their reliability, even through an impact study. And we reproduce the same mistakes as for the PNR and for the SIS on the backs of the European taxpayer and the credibility of the European Union. European citizens and their security have a good back. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tomáš Zdechovský
text: in the name of the group, the question “cardboard box”.- Don't you think you are criticizing the front lines today and that people have to wait a little, a little populist?Once we introduce a measure, we must immediately criticize it and not wait for its effects and for it to be implemented.Was it not you who criticized here after the attacks in France precisely that we are not guarding the EU's external border?Please reply.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: answer "blue card". - I think there must have been a little problem with the interpretation and that you don't know me well, my dear colleague. What I said, I said when the text was adopted. Therefore, I have not changed my mind. I think security is important, but I also see the failures of the systems that we implement one after another. I happen to follow all of these devices for the GUE / NGL group. We are seeing that the PNR is not in place and that SIS is not working, and that the system will have to be reviewed once again. Therefore, I am not at odds with myself. I am always in the same position: I alert and I say that the systems put in place are not functional and do not meet the security needs of citizens. (The speaker accepts to answer a 'blue card' question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules))

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: blue-card question. – Just a very short question: isn’t it better to ask our governments why they did not use the money they had at their disposal for at least two years to buy the equipment? This is what they should have done, and this what they should do – not that the regulation should have been adopted. The money was there. Some Member States did not fulfil their duties. Let us make them fulfil their duties and buy this equipment on the money from the Commission.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: answer "blue card".- Mrs Macovei, you may be surprised but I agree with you.If I said "on the back of the European taxpayer", it is because I am afraid that what is being proposed to us today is to increase funds that already exist and that our governments will notnot use.We need more transparency about exactly how national governments are using homeland security funds.It is not by increasing the envelopes that we will solve the problems, on the contrary.

name: Ulrike Lunacek
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, I would like to thank my colleague, Igor Šoltes, who will speak after me, who put the issue on the agenda for my group, and I am glad that we are now having this debate. I was the negotiator for my group on this issue and I drew attention to several things back then. There was no impact assessment by the Commission on the impact - not from the start. It was clear to many of us that targeted controls would be much better. What we have now experienced, and Ms. Fajon has described it from her own experience, is that there have been massive disabilities here, especially in holiday traffic at the borders. The current system is simply not proportionate. It doesn't create more security. Anyone who believes that these massive border controls - and everyone is being checked - the terrorists will be caught: That is simply not true. The problem is that the European Member States do not even fill the database that is there with data. That means: It is often of no use because the relevant people are not included. In other words, it would make a lot more sense to simply do these targeted checks here and not suspect everyone - that would be necessary. I can only say that I very much support the proposal to the Commission, which has now also come from Tanja Fajon and others. I request that you actually include in the Schengen Code the proposal that, after a waiting period of 15 minutes, targeted controls can and should be introduced here. That is the proposal made by Prime Ministers Cerar and Plenković. But that cannot remain at the bilateral level, because the problems also exist between Hungary and Serbia, as Mrs Gál has just said. There are problems, for example also between Gibraltar and Spain, and we cannot conclude nothing but bilateral agreements there.So, proportionate solutions are needed here, and please accept this proposal and let us change the Schengen Code in this regard.

name: Gerard Batten
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the European Union itself has created serious security problems because of its open borders policy. These problems became all the more obvious after the accession of the Eastern European countries in 2004. Even the Head of Europol, Rob Wainwright, has said that Schengen not only facilitates the freedom of movement of people, but the freedom of movement of organised crime and criminals. To try and fix the problems and restore some kind of stability the first step should be to abolish the Schengen area. The only real solution is to restore the control of borders to nation states. They all have different challenges and they have to approach their particular problems in their own way. Unfortunately, the waiting times at borders are going to be longer in some countries than others. Regarding what databases are required to help with border controls, of course the authorities need the fullest possible information on police records, identity documents, fingerprints, criminal intelligence, etc. What we do not need is the EU’s own databases, such as the Schengen Information System working under SIRENE. SIRENE is a police organisation and is part of the EU’s own developing police force. These organisations duplicate the work of Interpol and are unnecessary. Interpol already has at least 12 databases which are at the disposal of nation states. These databases cover a range of information regarding DNA and fingerprints for criminals and missing persons, stolen and missing documents, and counterfeiting, to name just a few of many. The framework for increasing international cooperation in this sphere is Interpol and not EU organisations. When Britain leaves the European Union, which I hope will come sooner rather than later, it should withdraw from Europol and SIRENE and be at the forefront of increasing international cooperation via Interpol.

name: Mario Borghezio
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, certainly the debate has revealed problems and difficulties in adopting these measures which, however, remain necessary, just think of the risk of perhaps even thousands of foreign fighters leaving Syria to understand this. However, I would like to point out to the Commissioner and Vice-President the situation of another external border, that between Italy and France, yes, the external border, because since from the southern coasts of Italy tens, perhaps hundreds of thousands of subjects flow adequately identified and in some cases they are not even absolutely identified, these subjects arrive en masse at the Italian-French border of Ventimiglia, which becomes an external border, in fact. And there these new measures so necessary, which would be really necessary, are absolutely not applied. If the Commissioner wants to realize for himself, of course the period in which measures to interrupt free movement for the G7 were sacrosanctly ended, but immediately afterwards the situation that lasted until May 14 will resume. It was enough to go to the Ventimiglia railway station to realize the daily influx of dozens and dozens of totally irregular and clandestine subjects, who flowed in peace, without any control towards France, creating enormous problems, not only in terms of image but also for the police authorities. So are the European rules a serious matter or are they totally ignored on the Italian-French border in Ventimiglia and there is instead an unwritten, invisible rule that makes this filthy, this shameful situation possible?

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: - Mr President, the proper and thorough control of the external borders is an effective way of instilling a sense of security among the people of the Member States. In addition, proper external border controls minimize to zero the need for detailed internal border controls. Following the expected catastrophic failure of the European Border and Coast Guard in Greece, the regulation rightly provides for the assignment of the external border control mission by the border guards of the other Member States. Because they have both the ability and the will and the means to successfully accomplish this mission. They have, among other things, familiar databases which include data for travel documents that contain biometric data so that their owner can be more easily identified. In this way, and because they exchange information between databases in which lost or stolen travel documents have been registered, they help to protect the European Union from terrorists and foreign fighters of European origin.

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE).
text: - Madam President! First of all, I think that the factual decisions, contrary to what my colleagues from the Social Democrats and the Greens have just said, are generally sensible. The implementation problems - where they exist - have to be tackled in detail. These are not major legal problems, they are implementation problems with a new regulation. There are problems with the border authorities, there are problems with the transition: When do you switch to targeted controls, which technical options can also be used to meet the relevant requirements? There is a whole range. And we will talk more often about how this can be optimized. I believe we are in agreement on this, but please, dear colleague Fajon, do not immediately break out into threats, we will now block something again. I don't want to block anything, I just want to make sure that we then find solutions together so that the waiting times don't get immeasurable. The Spanish government has reacted very sensibly and switched to targeted controls when it was necessary. You first have to get used to a new situation that you have not known before and find solutions for it. We should approach it constructively and try to solve it constructively. I would just like to say to Mr Batten: I find your remarks on Interpol and Europol almost amusing, because Great Britain feeds in very little news. And I would also like to note at Interpol that we now employ tens of people to determine whether Turkey may try to issue international arrest warrants following false Interpol arrest warrants. I have great confidence in Europol and I believe that we are best based on our standards and methods can react to the situation.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: - Madam President, "If the long columns continue, they can affect the arrival of tourists in the summer months, which will affect the income from tourism, which is very important for your country," said Commissioner Moscovici. The application of the Regulation on Systemic Controls has been highlighted as an important reason why the Commission's projections on Croatia's growth have been reduced. It is paradoxical and inadmissible for the Commission to forecast reduced growth due to the implementation of the Regulation it proposed itself. Existing European security mechanisms have shown too many weaknesses following the terrorist attacks, primarily due to the lack of exchange of security information between member states. Better cooperation of security systems is a prerequisite for greater security of citizens. The political reality calls for strengthening the security of the Union, but this Regulation cannot compensate for fundamental weaknesses. The Croatian-Slovenian land border is not the only crisis point for the implementation of this Regulation. Longer waits have also been reported at the border with Gibraltar and at airports across the European Union. The existing technology is undercapacitated and does not allow fast enough extraction of biometric data, their verification in existing and storage in new systems. Also, some members retained border controls within Schengen. All this calls into question freedom of movement as a fundamental value of the European Union. The agreement between the Croatian and Slovenian prime ministers is welcome. It remedied the problem, not solved it. Joining Schengen Croatia should also become an operational priority. The smooth crossing of borders by those entitled to it must not be called into question.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, the insane policy of open borders has led to drastic controls being carried out today. Western Europe, which after World War II turned into an oasis of freedom, must now restrict the hard-won freedoms of its citizens because of the terrorist threat it has imported into itself. I support stronger controls because unfortunately we are at a point of no return, at least until security issues are resolved, but I would really like to address the causes, not just the consequences. There is a reason why we have introduced stronger controls - not only on external but also on internal borders. Today, Croatia is a victim of these controls, and in no way contributed to the security chaos in Europe. The crowds at our borders are unbearable, which is likely to negatively affect the tourist season in a country where tourism accounts for almost 20% of GDP. Someone is to blame for this, some policies have proved to be a failure, and I think it is high time we set out to correct those mistakes.

name: Jozo Radoš (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, colleagues, due to the inability to influence the sources of crises outside its borders due to weak foreign and security policy and due to insufficient cooperation to create a security space within its borders, the European Union opted for this bureaucratic measure.However, this measure is not effective for at least two reasons.Terrorists are most often citizens of the European Union who are subject to more lenient controls, and secondly, terrorists have ways to circumvent this measure.I therefore welcome the proposal of the proponents, colleagues who have spoken before me about easing these controls at the EU's external borders, but especially strengthening foreign and security policy and better security cooperation that will make Europe secure not only at its borders but within itself.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, I would like not only to analyze the specific proposal but also the philosophy in general that we are seeing. I believe that no one can be against more security for European citizens, but security is not only - or much more than - border controls. We are increasingly faced with proposed regulations that systematically link security, border control, immigration and terrorism. This is not only a fallacy, but, above all, it is irresponsible. It is political fuel for the electoral boom of the extreme right. But let's face it. Many times, when we talk about security, we really mean business. I don't know if they know who the European Security Organization is. It is the main lobby group in the military and security industry. Its objective is the development of a harmonized European security market. For this they condition policies, as revealed in the report of the Transnational Institute Border wars, in order not to protect European citizens but to protect their own interests and their immense business. Unfortunately, the European Union has often stopped fighting poverty to fight the poor. That is the security philosophy that should be fought.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: - There is no doubt that the protection of the external borders is a necessary and necessary measure to ensure the security of citizens within the European Union, but it is, of course, necessary to take such measures that are proportionate to the goal we want to achieve. And this regulation is not. Recent events, however, the long boundaries between the Easter holidays and the long columns on the Slovenian-Croatian border show a completely different picture that we saw thirty years ago. In particular, inhumane congestion at borders has shown that measures are clearly not appropriate. However, the regulation is too rigid, to a certain extent, and also unrealistic in certain requirements. Slovenia has proposed several exceptions for low-risk groups, including children, organized groups of pensioners and so on, and these proposals have been completely ignored. The warnings of the local population along the borders, for whom the flow of the border is vital for everyday life, were also ignored. Of course, we all want more security, and we need to take action on the basis of an impact assessment, which this regulation did not have. And we must also take into account the real situation on the ground. At the same time, of course, I cannot ignore the absurdity that is also happening within European borders and shows the duality of European policy. On the one hand, we are tightening controls at the external borders, and on the other hand, we are giving the green light to enhanced controls at the internal borders, ie, for example, at the Austrian-Slovenian border. And finally that. Let me also express my extraordinary congratulations to the Slovenian police officers and all border authorities for carrying out their work with dedication and, of course, professionally, despite the heavy workload. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question asked under the 'blue card' procedure.- Thank you very much, dear colleague, I agree with much of what you said.Of course, the way in which cross-border traffic is carried out can lead to the development of trade, the development of tourism, at the same time security.However, I did not understand why you said that there should be restrictions between Slovenia and Austria.Do you think we need more restrictions within the European Union?I believe that there must be a single European Union, a single market.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: The answer to the question posed by raising a blue card.- I am talking about a fact that has been dragging on for more than half a year, namely - The European Commission has given the green light to Austria to strengthen controls at the Slovenian-Austrian border, despite [...] and above all that checks have not shownhigher risk.This, of course, also causes economic damage, which could have been avoided if, of course, these controls had been simplified.And, as I said, I think that the measures that need to be taken to increase security must be in proportion to the impact assessment, which must be done before any regulation is adopted.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - I have long been in favor of stricter controls at the EU's external borders. Especially on those borders through which foreign fighters returning, for example, from the wars in Syria, may come. These are undoubtedly a major threat to EU security and need to be stopped. Where else but at the EU's borders? This border control must be carried out intelligently. That is why, in this regard, I give great hope to the regulation that was adopted a month ago. I think, like my colleague Hohlmeier, that we need to give this regulation some time to run. I think that there is a need to work much more with the SIS and Interpol databases, not only at the entrance but also at the exit from the Schengen area. Each state must conscientiously and at the same time effectively control that persons coming to the EU do not pose a threat to public administration, internal security and public health. Although these controls, ladies and gentlemen, may pose some problems with the flow of traffic at the borders and the associated inconvenience for commuters, such as between Croatia and Slovenia, I consider these stricter controls to be a very important tool for ensuring EU security. This, ladies and gentlemen, should always come first.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, in February 2016, and after terrorist attacks that certainly shook Europe but were not perpetrated by foreign fighters or immigrants, far from being refugees, but by Europeans who lived among us, the Council took the initiative for a new regulation revising the Schengen border code. Many of us objected at that time, not because we don't care about security, which of course worries us, but because we want proportionality and necessity in the measures, and because we wanted to avoid chaos at the border, which has become evident not only between Slovenia and Croatia. Because the measures adopted - the new border identification system, the exhaustive identity controls - and not the controls previously in force, are not working. Fortunately, it is the forces and police themselves that are adopting some reasonableness in the management of the new system, but they have revealed flaws in the way it is legislated. Because when legislating in hot water, in a way that is not sufficiently thoughtful or proportionate, without observing the principle of necessity in restrictive measures for the free movement of people, we run the risk that the legislation fails to function. The European Union speaks of better legislating. I completely agree. Of course, we must legislate better, but in agreement with the European Parliament. Many of us raised objections that should have been considered. Legislate with the European Parliament when it comes to the Union's external borders, the management of the Union's external borders and the free movement of people and the Schengen code. With the European Parliament, not just the Council.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, of course there have been some difficulties in the implementation of systematic checks at the external borders. This is all the more regrettable as it is, in this case, a false external border, since it is destined to disappear soon. But these few difficulties should not hide the essential: systematic controls at the external borders are necessary and justified. In Belgium, just on the first day of the implementation of these controls, fifteen people reported in police databases were arrested. I realize that queuing is always awkward. However, to feel sorry for ourselves on the pretext that a wait of more than fifteen minutes is unbearable on the road is not reasonable when we know that those who take the plane must sometimes wait more than two hours and that all their luggage are controlled. However, the current system provides that the states concerned can use targeted controls - let us use them! - that the Member States use European funds to acquire high-performance and necessary equipment and, finally, that the Commission indicate what fluidity really is to help States make use of the possibility of targeted controls.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, the strengthening of controls at the European Union's external borders by Regulation 2017/458 is already proving problematic. As the dangers threatening Europe are numerous, we must pursue rational policies and not exaggerate. External border control helps maintain security at home, but the imposition of massive and excessive controls forces many Member States to upgrade their security systems and increase security personnel, without being able to do so due to the economic crisis and restrictions imposed on them. At the same time, there is a risk of increasing delays at peak points and times, especially for countries in the European South such as Greece, which rely financially on tourism. This practically increases the risks of terrorist attacks. The regulation should therefore be amended. (The speaker agreed to answer a question with a "blue card" (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Madam President, I would say to my dear colleague that in fact we all support attempts to increase security at external borders, and as a consequence within the Schengen Area. But considering this support could create havoc at the external borders, with the introduction of additional checks, do you think that this would bring additional security benefits? I do not.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: answer to a question with a "blue card".- As I said, change must be based on logic.And they are not based on logic when obligations are imposed on the Member States, which they are unable to meet, inter alia due to financial weakness.So there should be a different distribution of the financial burden, the Union should help the Member States financially and, of course, the controls should be kept within a reasonable framework.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I am glad that this item was on the agenda today, among other things, because 20 MPs signed a letter to Juncker, Tusk and Avramopoulos on April 11, and that this item was on the agenda today because it was obvious that this The regulation does not have the effect it wanted to achieve. It is ridiculous and paradoxical that the European Commission's growth estimates related to gross domestic product in Croatia have been reduced precisely because of the situation around the congestion on Croatian borders, which arose as a result of the Regulation proposed by the European Commission and passed by this Parliament. Therefore, it is good that there was a trilateral meeting between Mr. Juncker, Mr. Cerar and our Prime Minister Plenković, which resulted in greater propulsiveness at the borders, which means that after fifteen minutes of waiting, it moves from systematic checks to targeted checks. However, I believe and agree with all previous colleagues that this is not enough, that this decision should be formalized or a change to the Schengen Code should be initiated, because in this way the situation will not change significantly because it depends on the personal assessment of an individual border guard. Therefore, I am in favor of initiating this procedure, and I believe that it will be done. It is also an opportunity to say that one of the main priorities of Croatian politics is to enter the Schengen zone, I hope that we will achieve this very soon. And don't be surprised that almost all Croatian MPs spoke here today because you have to know that 20% of Croatia's GDP comes from tourism. For us, this Regulation is unsustainable, but we are also aware of the need to ensure security at both the external and internal borders of the European Union.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, one of the main achievements of the Union is certainly the free movement of persons, which must always be guaranteed and protected. Today, however, as confirmed by a recent report by Europol, the threat of terrorist attacks by European citizens returning from conflict zones, the so-called foreign fighters, remains high. To deal with the situation, the regulation we are discussing binds Member States to intensify border controls, controls which certainly must not lead to the loss of an acquired right but which, given the circumstances, represent a necessary tool to guarantee the security that allows freedom of movement to citizens and, in this context, consultation and rapid exchange of data through the SIS system and border controls become essential. However, I believe it is necessary to provide adequate support, possibly including financial support, to those Member States, such as Slovenia or Croatia, which, following the entry into force of the regulation, are suffering disproportionate impacts on traffic at their external borders, so that can carry out systematic checks more quickly and effectively. In essence, the Commission will have to ensure that the necessary strengthening of controls does not have disproportionate and unjustified impacts on the freedom of movement of European citizens and of those who reside and move legally, perhaps for work, in the Union. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Question "blue card".- Mr Chinnici, I wanted to ask you, does it not seem absurd that tourists who arrive from Istria by hydrofoil to visit Venice for a few hours have to wait two hours to enter the city of Venice?I'm talking about those who arrive as tourists, not those who arrive by land, but who arrive by sea.Don't you think this is really absurd and that Italy has to do something?

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: Answer to a "blue card" question.- Thank you for this question which perhaps allows me to clarify what I have already said.Controls are necessary, it is a reality, unfortunately, which must protect the freedom of movement of citizens from the risks that the terrorist threat entails for all our countries.But I have just said it, I say it again, there must not be disproportionate and unjustified impacts on the freedom of movement which, moreover, as in the case you mention, can also have economic consequences.It is therefore necessary, and I repeat, and this is essentially the request that I propose to the Commission, to find the right balance, to find the right measures between the need for security and the need for freedom that we must always respect.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE).
text: - Madam President! Ladies and gentlemen! I fully support the changes to the regulation that we are talking about today. An open Europe will only be able to retain its character, only then will we be able to enjoy the benefits of the Schengen area, when European openness cannot be confused with naivety, nor used by people of ill will. Therefore, enhanced control at the external borders, but also within the European Union, is a very good decision that serves the security of the citizens of the European Union. I also believe that the decision about mass, inevitability of this control is a good decision. Criminals are usually very clever and they can take advantage of all such system twists and turns, so it is better for this control to be massive. And if there are queues, well - we should shorten the queues, but not by avoiding control or giving up control, but by improving control, i.e. automation, digitization. We should do whatever we can to speed up this control. I now have a question for the representatives of the Commission about smart borders. How advanced is this project? To what extent are countries prepared to respond to these security challenges in a digital and not analogue way? What about training people who will use these modern devices or already partially use them? What is the compatibility of national databases of lost or stolen documents with European databases such as Europol or Schengen databases?

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Ms. President! I have already pointed out in connection with the debate on the austerity regulation: a measure which is unnecessarily inconvenient for our citizens and which restricts their freedom of movement in practice is not really suitable for screening out potential terrorists. While it creates fear and insecurity, it strengthens the atmosphere of terror. I am not pleased, but with some reassurance, to see from the report that the Commission is able to make corrections if necessary along similar findings. The security of citizens is, of course, still a priority in my view. That is why it is time for prevention, risk analysis and the full exchange of European information to come to the fore again in the external border control of the EU and in the fight against terrorism, instead of spectacular actions. I am convinced that, if necessary, the European Parliament will also be ready to provide the necessary political and financial support for this correction.

name: Емил Радев (PPE).
text: - Madam President, systematic checks at the external borders are important because, for the first time, European and national security services will know exactly who is crossing the borders. This will significantly reduce the chances of two thousand five hundred European citizens involved in terrorist organizations in Syria, Iraq and Libya returning to Europe unnoticed and posing a security threat. At the same time, I believe that the possibility of terminating systematic checks in the presence of obstacles to free travel in the European Union and after a risk assessment represents a balance between the need to ensure European security and the economic and business interests of the countries concerned. The topic of border security is extremely important for my country, Bulgaria, which guards perhaps the most sensitive external border - the one with Turkey. Unfortunately, although the country fully implements the Schengen legislation, including systematic checks, and fully meets the criteria for Schengen membership, Bulgaria still does not have full access to the Schengen Information System - the same system in which European citizens must be checked under the new rules. when entering and leaving the European Union. Let me be clear - as long as Bulgaria does not have full access to the SIS, despite our good intentions and the enormous efforts we are making, we will not be able to guarantee maximum security at Europe's external borders. That is why I want to call on the leaders of these countries, which hinder Bulgaria's membership in Schengen, to think about the security of European citizens. Because if they continue to block Bulgaria's access to the SIS, that means they are not taking seriously their own calls for increased security at the external borders.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Madam President, this Decree was passed in good faith with the intention of combating terrorism, but without considering the consequences of its application. The result is congestion at the border and a blockade of the movement of people and goods, which can have a particular impact on Croatian tourism, fisheries and agriculture. It is a political decision, and every political decision in the European Union is usually accompanied by a cost-benefit assessment. If the benefit is justified, the costs in the form of negative consequences for one of the Member States, in this case Croatia, are certainly not justified. I therefore propose that funds be provided at EU level to cover the additional, unforeseen cost of the obviously necessary strengthening of administrative and technical capacity at the border between Croatia and Slovenia to the extent that the negative impact of the application of this Regulation on Croatia is minimized. Over 2 million Germans, over a million Slovenes, one million Italians, 800,000 Czechs, 750,000 Poles, 500,000 French and 500,000 Britons, as well as tourists from other member states and the rest of the world, know why they chose Croatia for their holidays. We are expecting them this year as well, but in order for them to decide to spend their holidays in Croatia, it is necessary to improve the implementation of this Regulation, ensure targeted controls and ensure that waiting at the border does not exceed 15 minutes.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE).
text: - Madam President, we have received a large number of migrants without a proper check on who we are receiving. The stricter border control regulation is only an alibi for the administration in the event of further attacks on European soil. If it would ensure quality control of external borders and greater security for the citizens of the European Union, it would be commendable to support. However, this document is so complicated and dubious that it is difficult for those who apply it to understand it, because the document provides countless possibilities for interpretation and application, and it cannot be understood and accepted by the citizens of the European Union. In terms of security, it does not bring any progress. Our actual external borders are still extremely permeable. The effects of this Regulation are chaos in traffic within the European Union, damage to the economy and harassment of its own citizens. Finally, the border between Slovenia and Croatia cannot and must not be the external border of the European Union. If treated this way, then Croatia is not a full member. Croatia meets all the criteria for joining the Schengen regime and accession must not be a political issue nor must it be conditioned by a package with other countries. In any case, systematic border control should be suspended immediately.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, at a time when Europe is full of thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants, at a time when the European Union has lifted the visa requirement for Kosovo, that is, the jihadist wasp nest, we have the implementation of this regulation, which has literally create chaos. It has dismantled every tourist prospect within the European Union. And the problems exist in the countries of the European South that must be able to receive millions of tourists. We have heard that there are problems in both Croatia and Slovenia. The regulation needs to be amended. But here unbelievable restrictions are imposed even in Strasbourg because, for six months, when the plane arrives from Athens, to disembark, to get off the plane here in Strasbourg, they ask us to show the 'boarding pass', to that is, show the boarding pass. Amazing things that happen here in Strasbourg as well. I imagine you colleagues have seen that too.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, it is unquestionable that in the context of the upcoming tourist season Croatia will suffer heavy losses in the tourism sector if we do not move to targeted checks of passengers in traffic jams and unquestionable harmfulness of vehicle emissions waiting for hours in columns for the environment and health. Therefore, I call on the Commission, but also the governments of Croatia and Slovenia, to adopt a lasting and effective solution to this problem as soon as possible. Today, however, the Commission called on Croatia to better implement information sharing with a view to fighting terrorism and serious crimes. Croatia is late in automatically exchanging data on DNA, fingerprints and data on national vehicle registrations. But it is not the only member state to be named by the Commission. It is also important to mention the fact that Croatia will only have full access to the Schengen Information System from 27 June 2017. If Croatia does not start implementing binding measures, if this access to the Schengen Information System is not achieved, we must ask ourselves why the Commission insists on systematic border controls?

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Madam President, the border control system is not viable and effective and, following the terrorist attacks on European soil, it has proved inadequate. The examples of Islamist terrorists, who managed to cross European borders with fake documents, are fresh. Systematic control of third-country nationals should be strengthened through the intensive use of all relevant interoperable databases that need to be updated, but also through the use of high quality biometric data from additional travel documents. Innovative tools, such as automated face recognition technology, will reduce existing risks and threats to public order, internal security and public health. The Commission must legislate them immediately. Unjustified inaction will make the notion of the protection of fundamental rights irrelevant if we lead to the complete abolition of border crossing points and, consequently, to the conquest of European territory. We must protect our fellow citizens, our property, our children and our nations.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank Members for this interesting debate. I listened to them very carefully.  Security is one of the major concerns of Europe’s citizens. With a reinforcement of checks against relevant databases the EU has yet another tool to better secure the external borders and strengthen control over who enters and leaves the European Union. It is already clear that the new rules have led to an increased number of hits in the Schengen Information System. Even if they mostly concerned documents or objects, thanks to the new rules, the EU is better equipped to deal with terrorist threats.  There is also the possibility of a derogation from the principle of systematic checks, in justified cases, to strike the right balance between security needs and freedom of movement. The Commission is well aware of the challenges related to the initial phase of implementing the new rules and we are working with the national authorities of the Member States concerned to offer the best solutions in line with EU law.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on road transport in the European Union (2017/2545 (RSP)).

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, first of all, I wish to apologise for the fact that Commissioner Bulc cannot be here this evening with you. As you know, she has had to return to Brussels for a very important meeting relating to the issue of international aviation safety, with which I am sure all of you are very familiar. I can assure you that she fully appreciates the importance of the issue of road transport and would like to have been able to be here. On her behalf, I want to thank you for the invitation to participate in this preliminary debate on the Commission’s forthcoming proposals on road transport. We plan to adopt a series of road initiatives on 31 May as part of a larger mobility package. I am very pleased to say that the motion for a resolution on road transport in the European Union, which was tabled by the Committee on Transport and Tourism and which will be voted in plenary tomorrow, is an important contribution to the conclusion of these proposals. Road initiatives will contribute to the three main priorities highlighted in your draft resolution. Firstly, in relation to environmental sustainability. Road charging is one of the most prominent measures to implement the ‘user and polluter pays’ principles, which are guiding principles of the Commission to make road transport clean and sustainable. Clear price signals are essential to encourage the use of infrastructure in an efficient manner, as well as the use of clean vehicles. Among the main measures we are contemplating is an extension of the scope of the current legislation by including passenger cars, vans and buses. These vehicles are responsible for the lion’s share of pollutants and CO2 emissions as well as congestion on our roads. Adequate road charging can provide a decisive contribution to addressing them. Of course, Member States will remain free to decide whether access to any specific infrastructure must be charged for or not, but it should not be ignored that distance-based charging has clear advantages. These relate to fairness and efficiency. Distance-based charging ensures that users pay for their actual use of infrastructure, with account being taken of the relative share in pollution emitted. Distance-based charging is also a precondition for external cost charging, and this is what is requested by the motion for a resolution on road transport in the European Union. To this end, external cost charging needs to be facilitated, made simpler and made more attractive for our Member States. Secondly, in relation to technological innovation and digitalisation: for efficient road charging, Europe needs interoperability of national systems. Currently, there are many different, independent charging systems in the Union, which are complicating cross-border transport. The Commission wants to ensure that new service providers who wish to provide pan-EU services will be able to enter established markets and provide one OBE, one contract and one invoice to users. Similarly, effective enforcement of EU transport is crucial. At times when enforcement capacities in Member States are being reduced, it is especially important to have modern and efficient tools available for the controls in respect of our rules. It is also essential to improve further the cooperation between the public authorities of Member States. One good example is the optimisation of the European register for road undertakings and an IT tool which allows exchanging information between Member States. We also need to make better use of tachographs as well as e-Documents to improve enforcement. Thirdly, in relation with a fairer and deeper internal market: the road initiatives should contribute very significantly to the proper functioning of the road transport market. Status quo is clearly not an option. We are encouraged by the consensus emerging around this idea. The Commission will aim at finding truly European solutions which would combine the necessary protection of workers and at the very same time avoid the fragmentation of the internal market. One of the starting points is to fight letter-box companies. Transport undertakings could fulfil the conditions of a genuine establishment in a given Member State and carry out a genuine economic activity in that Member State. Solving this issue will contribute significantly to diminish illegal cabotage and periods when drivers are away from home. In relation to posting: Commissioner Bulc wants to be very clear. One thing is that drivers operating abroad are often in a posted situation. One cannot simply ignore the fact that road transport is by definition a highly mobile activity which requires sector-specific rules. In this context, three objectives should be borne in mind. Firstly, reducing administrative burdens for road hauliers, which in certain Member States are disproportionate. Secondly, making sure that the more efficient tools available in the sectors, such as the tachograph, are used to ensure the enforcement of the rules. And thirdly, to clarify the circumstances in which national minimum wages should apply. Another serious issue is the international nomadism of drivers. A right balance is necessary between flexibility for drivers and operators to plan international journeys on the one hand, and sufficient guarantees that enable drivers to return home on a regular basis and to have access to adequate accommodation when taking weekly rests away from home. In this context, the solution cannot be shorter rests and longer driving times. On the contrary, drivers’ working conditions and road safety should be improved rather than compromised. Finally Madam President, I would like to highlight one additional issue which I already referred to, which is the simplification of the rule on cabotage. Almost all stakeholders have told us that the current rules are too difficult to enforce and that there is a lot of illegal cabotage. These concerns are well understood, and we agree that enforcement is key in this area as well. Adapting the cabotage rules to this end does not, however, mean opening or closing national freight transport markets. Honourable Members, I have briefly outlined some of the essential considerations underpinning the preparation of the Commission’s road initiatives. I look forward to discussing the details of our forthcoming proposals when they are adopted. However, I would like to urge everyone to keep in mind the actual problems on the ground faced by our transport operators. These problems are substantial and they are real. Let us focus on the facts and try to avoid heated discussions and be prepared to enter a constructive debate. This is what Commissioner Bulc is certainly seeking.

name: Wim van de Camp
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - (NL) Mr President, I would first of all like to thank Commissioner Hogan for replacing Mrs Bulc. I am convinced that she had to return to Brussels today to discuss the so-called 'laptop ban' with our American friends, and for good reason. Mr President, this is the last chance for the European Parliament to send out a few signals about the so-called Mobility Package before the famous date of 31 May. We first talked about a road package, but nowadays it is called mobility package. We hope that this also improves the quality. I must tell you that the EPP Group is disappointed that it is all taking so long. We are already in the second half of this period and it will take a lot of effort to finalize this file before the 2019 elections. Madam President, the proposals contain many elements. It is about the economic significance of the transport sector, but also about employment and a decent social policy. It is unfortunate that some colleagues have already spread rumors about how bad things are going to be without us knowing exactly what is going to happen. But it is also about sustainability. It's about usage. It's about 'the polluter pays'. And let's not forget the training. We will have a huge staff shortage in this sector in the coming years. How are we going to deal with this in a socially responsible way? Finally, the appeal to the Member States and the Council, and in particular Estonia, Bulgaria and Austria, to bring it to a successful conclusion.

name: Ismail Ertug
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Madam President, Commissioner! The time has finally come - on May 31, it has been repeatedly announced that this road traffic package should come. Dear Commissioner, this package is extremely important. This package will now show us to what extent the European Union has grown together with east and west and north and south. I can tell you that these debates will not be easy because there are fears from different quarters. Therefore, in order to be able to bring this very idea of ​​the open access single market together with the idea of ​​preventing social dumping in Europe, in addition to all the proposals that you will be making on May 31, it definitely needs - and I say that in particular Direction of my colleagues in the European People's Party - a European road transport agency that will address all of these issues. Otherwise it will be very, very difficult to bring the various interests together. That's why I'm looking forward to the discussion in the coming weeks and months.

name: Roberts Zīle
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President. Commissioner! European conservatives and reformists have always been a true single market in the European Union without protectionism, often dressed in magic words such as social dumping or referring to unproven and unconfirmed violations by market participants that cause problems. As we know, very strict laws have also been adopted in several Member States, which are already fragmenting this road haulage market. Also, as the Commissioner has just mentioned, the Commissioner's view is that these penalties are disproportionate to how it might work in a logical way. We must remember that the European Union has about 4,000 km in an east-west direction and almost as much, a little less, in a north-south direction. It is a huge area in which road transport plays a leading role in freight transport. We must be very responsible in working with this mobility package, because we can incur very significant economic and social costs in this sector and in freight transport in the European Union as a whole. As for the resolution that Parliament will adopt tomorrow, which we are debating today, I would like to say that I am relatively skeptical, because it is more about social issues, less about the economy, it is about liberalization, cabotage is not really affected, about tachographs. there is no real confirmation of the irregularities, as I said, and, in the end, the principle of setting up a new agency without knowing whether it will coincide with the principle of 'Oops, we have a problem. Let’s make a new agency. ” And the majority of European Conservatives and Reformists do not support this resolution because it is a path to protectionism and therefore, in our view, sending a message to the European Commission shortly before the document is not the right course of action for the adoption of this package in college.

name: Pavel Telička
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, first of all I am glad that finally we are able to debate, and tomorrow vote on, a resolution which was an ALDE initiative and which we passed in the Committee on Transport back in February. It is difficult to comprehend why we didn’t manage to tackle it early on here in the plenary and send out the clear message we wanted to send. Secondly, I must say that what the Commissioner presented, seems to be a balanced approach, but of course the nitty-gritty is in the details. We’ll have to see when we see it on 31 May, and then later on also in autumn.  But my first point would be that this is maybe the most important legislation, certainly in the transport sector, that we will be dealing with until the end of this mandate. This is about whether we will be enhancing and fostering the single market or not. And I think that this is an absolute need: to be able to combine on the one hand an effort in terms of building that market, while also, of course, confronting all the practices which are – either from a social, environmental or any other point of view – to the detriment of the internal market.  So that is one point I would like to highlight. The second is that I very much hope we will manage to approve the package well in time, under this mandate, at least to the largest possible extent, so that we will make it impossible for individual Member States to be coming in all the time with national legislation, with different measures, which in fact do lead to fragmentation of the internal market. That is what I understand this package to be, and this is how we should see it and we should maintain it as a package.  My final remark to the Commissioner is that I understand that the Commission has already finalised its review of the German legislation on the road toll (Maut) and I understand that it will not be taking steps. If that is the case, I would like to remind you that there is a European Parliament resolution on the issue to which Parliament expects a response.

name: Dennis de Jong
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - (NL) Mr President, I still very well remember one of the first conversations I had with Commissioner Bulc. We had taken a driver with us and he showed a large number of photos about the abuses on the road. Dangerous situations, exploitation, abuses. And the commissioner was moved. From that moment on I have the feeling that we have laid the foundation for measures. But we now hope that the Commissioner will continue. A few more examples. It is nice to have extra money for parking spaces, but if Eastern European drivers have to pay the rates for such parking spaces from their wages, they will not use them. That is the experience. We must then look for other measures. For example, we need to strengthen controls - I understand that the Commissioner is thinking about this - of enforcement of the rules, make minimum agreements and, in particular, make use of new techniques. The smart tachograph, it should become mandatory. And I haven't heard that yet. The last thing we need to do at this point, I think, as long as enforcement is not in order, is further relaxation of cabotage rules. That won't solve it, but better controls will.

name: Karima Delli
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the legislative package on road transport, which will be announced in two weeks, comes at a crucial time. In fact, we are talking about a sector that today faces three major challenges. First of all, the road contributes 20% of the greenhouse gas emissions of the European Union. This has to come down, and quickly, if we are to meet the commitments made in the context of COP21 to save the planet, the climate and humanity. For this, it is urgent that the Commission proposes, among other things, more ambitious standards in terms of CO2 emissions for all vehicles in motion. The second challenge is digitization. It should make it possible to facilitate the work of employees and cross-border mobility, but also to improve control to ensure compliance with the law. But all this cannot wait until 2034, the date proposed by the Commission to complete the equipping of the European fleet with the smart tachograph. Because the third challenge must be resolved before it is too late. The truck has become a social jungle because of the cheating organized by transport companies who use and abuse social dumping thanks to the low wages of workers from Eastern countries. It is time to affirm the principle of "equal work, equal pay" and to create a European road agency, a veritable gendarme whose mission will be to ensure compliance with European legislation. This unfair competition is wreaking havoc on employment, harming working conditions for employees, destroying lives, pitting European workers against each other and fueling the anger of both sides. It is the poison that is killing the European project. The stake of this mobility package is the survival of the European project. This is the last stop before the triumph of the Eurosceptic parties. We have an obligation of result, here and now.

name: Peter Lundgren
text: for the EFDD Group. - Madam President! The transport industry is severely exposed and the EU must act here. It's not possible to continue like this anymore. You have really lost all confidence in the transport industry in the countries that are trying to maintain sensible rules and conditions. We must give national police authorities the tools to act. We need to give them an IT information base where national police can check whether it is legal transport or not. There must be smart tachographs to be able to comply with driving time rules and cabotage rules. But the problem with the cabotage rules is that neither the current rules nor any new rules - such as having four days instead of seven days and three transports - solve the problem. It is still possible to cross the border and change trailers. It cannot be the intention that some countries that ignore regulations and have used drivers for pure slave wages should be allowed to compete with countries that pay decent wages and have modern, environmentally friendly vehicles. That cannot be the spirit of the EU. Thanks!

name: Georg Mayer
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President! Yes, the transport sector affects a very broad field in Europe, and the industry also makes a very important contribution to the economies in the individual Member States. 5 million people are employed in this sector, which is 2% of the domestic product in the whole of Europe. And that is precisely why it is so important not to leave this sector to green Disneyland fantasies. It's just too important and necessary for people for that. It is also necessary to expand global competitiveness. That creates jobs, that creates growth. However, this must not happen on the back of the employee. In any case, what we consider to be unnecessary is the creation of a new agency, which will only bring new costs, and also the expansion of the Union's competence, for example in the area of ​​toll regulations throughout Europe. So let's get back to what is essential in this sector and let's tackle it.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: - Madam President!Reading and listening to all of this, you can come to the conclusion that in your opinion transport is there to give wages to entrepreneurs, drivers and to keep officials busy, and nobody talks about the recipients of the goods.And the cheaper the costs of transport, the cheaper the goods that customers buy.When I hear about the indignation of Europeans that goods are too cheap, gentlemen and ladies are probably crazy.People want cheap goods.I already lived in Soviet times, and we had even stupider rules.Imagine that there were even stupider regulations in the Soviets than in the European Union - which is hard to imagine, but there were.And I can give you five ways to get around these rules, how to cheat in this case.And we'll take it out of our pockets, we'll do it, but why force people to do things with the right hand through the left ear.Besides, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht Koch (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! I am very pleased that you finally want to publish the long-awaited road traffic initiative. It is definitely necessary to solve existing problems and challenges in this industry. At the same time, I firmly believe that we don't need that many new regulations. The cabotage regulations are actually clear, the problem is their inadequate enforcement in the Member States. Above all, however, illegal cabotage must be stopped. Unfortunately, some Member States are generally wiping out cabotage by increasing administrative hurdles - that, too, cannot be the right approach. I advocate the unbureaucratic use of paperless, standardized documentation. Above all, there must also be deterrent sanctions against letterbox companies, and I am calling for a sector-specific posting of workers directive. In terms of driving and rest times, the industry needs more flexibility, which means expressly not longer driving times. And we have to improve the working conditions of drivers and increase road safety. This is the only way to solve the existing shortage of skilled workers and create a sustainable, competitive European road transport sector. Let us ensure that national solo efforts are avoided, since these stand in the way of a single European transport area, because we need it so much. This also applies to aspects relating to tolls and the Eurovignette. These should be Europe-wide, distance-dependent and earmarked, and ideally electronic and interoperable.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I believe you all share the satisfaction of finally seeing the so-called mobility package presented. There are rumors, but the only certainty and the only fixed point is what will be voted on tomorrow with this resolution, which is the position of the European Parliament. The fact that we have waited so long to have legislative proposals indicates that this is a complex and articulated matter, which requires analysis and prudence. However, what I would like to say right now is that, if we want a truly competitive Europe, we must bear in mind that competitiveness passes through efficiency, passes through the ability to provide a good service and therefore logistics is the pivotal point. I hope that the problem of illegal cabotage will finally be solved or, at least, that this phenomenon will be curbed. This tool, we know well, was created to prevent empty trucks from traveling and therefore other transports at the same time, but this cannot become an unfair competition tool.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: - (NL) Mr President, the transport sector is doing reasonably well again, but unfortunately there are still considerable problems in terms of safety and social matters. Cargo theft is increasing enormously in the Netherlands and Europe. It mainly concerns foreign gangs that strike. And then be gone right away. Safety in road transport must be higher on the agenda and safe parking spaces are therefore really necessary, I say to the Member States. This can be done with the help of European funding. Social problems in road transport are also still extensive. There are many reports of drivers who are away from home for a long time and have to stay overnight and are actually exploited by their boss. That is not good for those people, but also not good for the competition with other drivers. So an approach for improved working conditions is really necessary. And also equal pay for equal work, because then you have fair competition. So things are going well economically, but the EU is more than the economy. There is work to be done. Incidentally, the standard pavlov reaction of the European Union - just do an agency - is really not necessary for that.

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE).
text: - Madam President! We will also need the road in the future, even if we try to use rails and waterways more as an environmentally friendly option. But with increasing traffic - and this is forecast - we will definitely have to see how we can improve the road. That is why these laws are so important. I want to focus on seven points. You can talk a lot about it. One is: we need innovations. A lot will happen there. We must enable these innovations through digitization, through the sharing economy. In the future there will be trucks that drive in platooning. In any case, everything that can come of innovation, intelligent traffic systems, can make traffic safer and also, for example, more environmentally friendly, more efficient of course anyway. Keyword environment: We have a regulation for an infrastructure in Europe for alternative energies, which only really needs to be implemented now. We need electricity, gas and hydrogen everywhere. Third point: freighter. We need electronic shipping documents. If we have that, we can achieve a tremendous amount of efficiency. Another key word is the practicality of driving and rest times. There are a few things that could also be improved from the point of view of drivers. The toll, a Eurovignette. We really have to consistently enforce the polluter pays principle and then use what we redeem in the infrastructure for a specific purpose. Point six: The attractiveness of the driving profession for men and women urgently needs to be increased. We need offspring there. And point seven: What we don't need is a road agency. We have to oversee it, but we don't need a new agency for that. (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question.- Thank you very much for the opportunity, Madam President.I would also like to thank Mrs MEP for the opportunity to respond.I was happy with his words, so I do not want to argue by any means, I would rather ask the question of whether the concept of 'smart villages' is emerging now, and in this context, for example, I would consider it important to have electric charging in every European village.Okay, but for example, how would you see this workable?

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr Szanyi!You are absoluteley right.I said yes: we need an infrastructure for alternative energies.And of course that includes charging stations.They can significantly improve traffic, because we can have more e-mobility on the road.But we don't just need that, we also need stations for hydrogen and liquefied gas - i.e. everything you can think of to have environmentally friendly modes of transport, so to speak, to fill up alternatively, we need that, and of course as many charging stations as possible.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, the defense of harmonization in the sector for the benefit of a single market is nothing more than a highway for concentration phenomena and the creation of trans-European road transport monopolies, subduing the extortion of national heritage and the public purse to its interests. , imposing public-private partnerships, promoting the creation of debt. It will be the workers and peoples who will be the first to pay for the consequences of the proposed intentions. In a sector in which the use of low wages and degrading working conditions is increasing, the proposals that are advancing will contribute to the harmonization and deregulation of labor, to the increase of precariousness and social unprotection, of exploitation. What is required is the defense of the sector as a strategic axis at the service of the sovereign development of any Member State, based on public development and investment policies, of a road transport network and that guarantee, simultaneously, work with rights and collective bargaining, salary increases, the right to training.

name: Michael Cramer (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! A few days ago the head of the logistics group Jost, a Belgian company based in Luxembourg, was taken into custody. He is said to have built an international network of companies to evade social security contributions amounting to 55 million euros. All of this shows that we finally need stricter rules and stricter controls. The solution already exists: this is the digital tachograph. But so far only new vehicles have to be equipped with it; we are taking 15 years to retrofit old vehicles. Therefore: the retrofitting must happen immediately. All of this is possible, but please immediately. Many truck drivers now live in their truck. They almost never see their family. Some Member States have already taken action against this. Now the Commission has to make a European proposal. We don't want to create any new loopholes, such as the idea that drivers could stay with private individuals of their choice. We Greens want a 20% reduction in working hours, for the benefit of drivers, their families and safety on Europe's roads.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, this report sparked my interest, unfortunately for all the wrong reasons. I believe it has a detrimental impact financially on our British small and medium—sized businesses and individual car owners. Following the Commission’s White Paper entitled ‘Roadmap to a Single European Transport Area’, with its view of a sustainable mobility, here we are again seeing a one—size—fits—all policy, a vision of harmonisation of transport for all Member States. Do not misunderstand me. The safety of road users and the environmental impact of fossil fuels needs to be addressed, but the present situation is a knee-jerk reaction that many cannot afford or have the facility to accommodate. However, once again, I feel this motion put before us pushes the anti-vehicle agenda. It stresses that road charging should be introduced across the EU. Yet in the UK the public have completely rejected any attempt to bring back pay—as—you—go road pricing.  I am so glad that the people of the UK have voted to leave the European Union and I believe this motion is all about control, rather than the individual’s choice.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Madam President, at the heart of the resolution for yet more regulations for the road transport sector are the two elements that are always central and dear to the European Union: control and tax. The European Union wants to intervene in the road transport sector, in the name of climate action, to control the sector and thereby further erode Member States’ sovereignty, and then to tax it dry.  These proposals are even more ridiculous when one considers the Dieselgate scandal, when the EU rules were not enforced and went unnoticed for years, resulting in an environmental scandal. By taking further and tighter control over the road transport sector, the EU is expanding its reach. As each new rule is implemented the Member States’ ability to manage this area is reduced, and as the rules become stricter so the economic costs increase, costs that consumers, drivers and passengers will ultimately pay.  All talk of the improving emission standards rotates around the ‘polluter pays’ principle. The tighter the rules, the higher the cost. Remember the scandal of the failed emission trading scheme so beloved by Brussels? We saw that emission controls are a mask for the EU to raise and collect taxes. I had a minute and half, Madam President…  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Markus Pieper (PPE).
text: - Madam President! Road traffic is Europe's lifeline, a prerequisite for the internal market and freedom of travel. Four comments on this: First: National toll systems are a drag, especially for the transport industry.
