That is why we have to implement digital solutions for a cross-border toll system as quickly as possible. Second, we need a competitive transport industry. Taxes, levies, tolls, pollution control - all of this has its justification, especially from an environmental point of view. But we mustn't overstay. Coupling tolls and CO2 emissions is complicated. We must avoid bureaucracy and we must not punish companies twice or three times. Third, those who drive vehicles, the drivers, must not be exploited. I am very much in favor of applying the wages and social conditions of the Member State in which most of the drivers work. If that's difficult to do, sure, but the current practice is definitely exploitation. If drivers work for months in Germany or Benelux, but are paid for their work at the lowest European wages, I see it as an abuse of the European internal market. The Commission must therefore fight and control dubious subcontractors and illegal practices on the streets more intensely and, above all, make the Member States much more accountable. Otherwise we will continue to lose credibility with the employees and also with the medium-sized transport industry. Many points are taken up in our resolution. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Michael Cramer (Verts/ALE)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- You said: The toll should be unbureaucratic, I think so too.But do you believe the car toll for foreigners - which is now being introduced in Germany and which the Commission has still confirmed today, although it is anti-social, unecological and anti-European - this toll is wonderfully designed, it is unbureaucratically easy to handleor would you have preferred it to be different?

name: Markus Pieper (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Dear colleague!There are always things that can be improved.But it is at least once a start for a distance-based fee collection.The Greens want that too.And if you can now find a system that perhaps builds on the German system to a certain extent and then enables digital solutions with which we can be active across borders - yes, why not?So the German toll can definitely be a start.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D).
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, before tomorrow's vote and before the presentation of the mobility package by the Commission, I see that differences of opinion have deepened. I hope that we all want to promote workers' social rights, decent wage rights, the right to rest, but we have not been able to agree on definitions. We use the same words and we seem to want the same things, but we fail to find a common direction. We do not yet have a technical definition of what social dumping means and we insist on blaming Eastern companies for what is simply a competitive advantage due to the local economic situation. This resolution and the future road package must focus on the real problem, namely the existence of letter box companies that exploit drivers in Eastern Europe, and we know very well that these companies come from Western Europe. We should also insist on the establishment of a European Road Agency, an initiative which this institution, the European Parliament, has already voted twice in the White Paper on Transport and in the report on social dumping. I think we need to move from words to deeds if we really want an integrated European road transport market and an efficient and fair transport system.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR).
text: – Madam President, we should not limit the debate on the future of the European road transport sector to social issues only. For the last two years we have seen many cases of violation of free competition in the EU in this sector. So firstly, we need to ensure freedom of providing haulage services across Europe without any administrative barriers. Then we can go further. I agree that many things have to be done to improve security and standards of daily life of truck drivers, but the idea of the creation of a new agency responsible for road transport is not the right solution. Stigmatisation of transport companies from Central and Eastern Europe is not a very good way to build a common market. We are interested in cooperation with our partners in the EU to fight against fraud, but such cooperation should be based on honest and not discriminatory rules. I hope that the Commission’s mobility initiatives will not create the next problem but will be an answer for existing challenges of the road transport sector.

name: Matthijs van Miltenburg (ALDE).
text: - (NL) Mr President, I too look forward with interest to the plans of the European Commission for European road transport. The current rules certainly require adjustment. They can lead to different interpretations in different European countries, for example when it comes to cabotage or driving and rest times. As a result, they are not always easy to enforce and from time to time stand in the way of a 'level European playing field'. For example, the driver's overnight stay in the cab - good example - is prohibited in France and Belgium, but is allowed in other countries such as my own country, the Netherlands. Fragmentation - whether it concerns the rules we set or the implementation thereof for road transport - is very bad for Europe. A very good example is also the German toll plan, which discriminates against foreign road users. Today it became known that the European Commission has stopped the infraction procedure against Germany, and that while the European Parliament has spoken out strongly, in a European resolution, against Germany's toll plan. Can the Commission - and I would very much like to have an answer to this - can the Commission explain why the resolution of this European Parliament has not been implemented? Because I find that really disrespectful when it comes to the intercourse between the two institutions. I would also very much like to know from the Commission, in two weeks, how it assesses the German toll plan in the light of its own proposal when it comes to road charging.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, rarely have we seen such a frontal attack on workers' rights as the one the Commission is making in road transport. Going from forty-five hours of weekly rest to twenty-four hours is slavery. Going from ninety biweekly to one hundred and sixty-eight hours every three weeks is slavery. Allowing him to sleep three and four weeks in the cabin is slavery. And we tell you as the European trade unions have told you. We do not want you to legalize this exploitation. What we want is for them to control the current legislation: with modern tachographs, with inspections, with controls and with a decent rest for drivers. Nor can it be tolerated that they seek to prevent transport workers from receiving at least the minimum wage in the country where they operate and that false movements and cabotage operations remain uncontrolled. Workers, Mr. Hogan, come before profits. From here all our support to a sector that fights for its life and for its dignity.

name: Daniela Aiuto (EFDD).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, over 26 000 deaths per year across Europe and a social cost of around EUR 100 billion, so road safety is the main urgency we are called to respond to in terms of mobility . In our opinion, urban centers need to be decongested by implementing the use of public transport to the detriment of the private one which is, among other things, responsible for about 80 percent of the CO2 emissions produced by the entire transport sector. Furthermore, the rules regarding rest times and the quality of heavy vehicle drivers must be enforced by all, with checks on driving licenses and alcohol levels. We have the technologies to make roadside checks very timely and effective, we help small businesses, perhaps even giving them an economic incentive, to adopt the technological devices necessary for such checks. We support the resolution, especially for the part referring to emission reduction policies. For the new electricity sector, we hope for investments both in the diffusion of the network and in research for the sustainability of the batteries used, in order to have less impacting products both during construction and disposal.

name: Andor Deli (PPE).
text: - Ms. President! I welcome today's debate, but I regret that it has not been possible to put it on the agenda before, as it will no longer be able to have a significant impact on the mobility package that will be presented at the end of the month. These days, we are talking more and more about multi-speed Europe. Unfortunately, this multi-speed Europe already seems to be a reality in terms of transport. This is because a circle of Member States is slowly emerging to introduce similarly designed unilateral measures, thus jeopardizing the functioning of the single internal market. With reference to elusive and hitherto undefined social dumping, a multi-speed Europe is being created before our eyes, in an area where it is not needed at all. The Commission can see this in the same way, as it has launched an investigation into several cases. That is why the Commission's mobility package has high expectations - both here in Parliament and on behalf of the Member States. After all, there is a need for proposals that eliminate or prevent further fragmentation of the transport market and fully guarantee the freedom to provide freight services. This is not an easy task, and it is important that we find solutions in the interinstitutional debate on the mobility package that are viable and acceptable to all, as this is only a guarantee that the implementation of the legislation will also be complete. I believe that profit-orientation should not play a disproportionate role in cohesion policy, because the return on investment and the success of investment in, for example, education or health cannot be measured solely by the measure of profit. Therefore, the mobilization of financial instruments is important, but in these areas they cannot trigger, but can only complement, grants. Experience to date has already shown that regions with persistently high unemployment and low population density have a very low investment attractiveness. The is non-refundable and subsidies contribute precisely to helping regions in this situation to catch up.Therefore, when designing cohesion policy after 2020, it is important that increasing the share of financial instruments does not lead to a reduction in the amount of grants, as this would hamper the achievement of the main objective of cohesion policy, the elimination of regional disparities.

name: Christine Revault D’Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D).
text: - Mr President, today we are finally interested in the situation of 2 million workers and more than 500,000 road transport companies in Europe, which crystallizes the issues linked to social dumping and the fight against competition. unfair. Indeed, the liberalization of the internal market in this sector has contributed to the deterioration of working conditions, to the massive circumvention of European legislation and to the proliferation of abusive practices, such as letterbox companies. As we all know, due to the itinerant nature and the fundamentally cross-border character of the road sector, solutions can only be European. In this context, the mobility package must be the direct application of the social pillar. Indeed, we cannot, on the one hand, work to improve the living conditions of citizens and, on the other hand, make an exception to road transport by increasing the flexibility of rest times. I do not understand how the President of the Commission shows his full support for the principle of “equal pay for equal work” in the same workplace when, at sectoral level, it is proposed to exclude more than 2 million people from the workforce. Posted Workers Directive, which must ensure the application of this principle. You have to be consistent in speech and action. Beyond the road sector, it is important that all MEPs understand that what is at stake here is not only that question, but the question of the survival of Europe.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: - The European transport sector is getting stuck more and more. Deadly emissions, countless traffic casualties and increasing traffic congestion give the sector a bad name and serious headaches. Unfair competition due to the abuse of European and social regulations also makes it very difficult for many transporters. Setting up shadowy PO box companies and hiring underpaid and untrained drivers is a widespread practice. It's nothing short of modern day slavery! This worries me and many Flemish people with me. Because of these abuses, unfair competition, social exploitation and road safety are a curse over the sector. That is a shame, especially when you know the important role the sector plays for our European economy. It is therefore urgent time to upgrade the European transport sector. This is only possible through more efficient European cooperation and better implementation and enforcement of existing European rules. I look forward to the proposals from the European Commission with great expectation. The EU is there to create prosperity, not facilitate a downward spiral.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, the road transport sector is critical for road safety and the competitiveness of the economy, and it is also a source of employment. Overcoming the challenges it faces forces professionals and companies to integrate technological innovations associated with autonomous, hyperconnected and low-carbon vehicles, aided by public and private investments and by new training that will enrich professional performance and improve services. The evaluation studies on the current framework indicate the dysfunctions that we must correct. These include social dumping, the fraudulent use of letterbox companies in states with the lowest social protection standards, the disguised protectionism behind the very varied interpretations of the scope of the cabotage regulations, or issues related to the Eurovignette or electronic toll collection. Likewise, it is necessary to harmonize working conditions in a sector characterized by mobility, improving the directives that regulate driving time, the movement of workers or the regulations on access to the profession. For this reason, Commissioner Hogan, I wish Commissioner Bulc luck in presenting her proposals, and I thank her for the effort that - I am aware - she has put into the subject for some time, and I announce my full support, after listening to the industry, for European solutions. Because state-to-state unilateral actions only contribute distortion, confusion and more administrative burdens to a sector that has enough with the problems described.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: - We are talking about road transport and I will tell you one simple thing that the EU should do and benefit everyone - hauliers, drivers and consumers. The Road Transport Regulation restricts so-called cabotage. Specifically, it prohibits the loading of other goods during transport, so for example, when a truck travels from the Czech Republic to, say, Hamburg, Germany and still has space in the area, he may not load other goods, for example in Dresden, because the EU prohibits it. As a result, unnecessarily many lorries drive on European roads. This is called dead weight loss and a quarter of the trucks that drive around Europe are empty. Lifting this ban would be good for everyone. If you want less traffic jams, loosen cabotage. Want lower prices for transportation services, free cabotage. If you want more environmentally friendly farming and less diesel, loosen cabotage. You want lower CO2 emissions, if you are bothered by global warming, unleash cabotage.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the transport sector is responsible for around a quarter of Europe’s greenhouse emissions, and is a particularly problematic sector for Ireland. Achieving 80% decarbonisation across the EU by 2050, which is the goal, would likely require the decarbonisation of the road transport sector by around 95% by 2050. As EPP rapporteur on the Renewable Energy Directive, this is an area in which I have a keen interest and an area where I believe there are huge opportunities to make great emission savings with innovative solutions.  Electromobility is an important way forward if we are to have any hope of achieving this target. The electrification of transport would displace imported carbon-intensive fossil fuels and eliminate harmful air pollutant emissions in our cities and towns. There is great potential in this. The EV market share in Norway, for example, increased from 1.4% in 2011 to 17.1% in 2015, due to favourable policies. This is a blueprint for us. However, the foundations need to be laid for this and I welcome the Commission’s ideas, in the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive, to increase the amount of charging points in our buildings. We need to ensure the right infrastructure is in place if this is to be successful.  In addition to this, sustainably produced biofuels will continue to play an important role, not only as a means to decarbonise our transport sector, but also for economic growth in rural areas. Yes, there is a sustainability question about some feed stocks, palm oil for example, but I think our challenge in the work on the Renewable Energy Directive will bring certainty for producers of sustainable biofuels.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. –  Mr Kelly, you know I appreciate very much your activity within the European Parliament. I want to ask you if you support the trade unions’ request aimed at making the forthcoming road mobility package a better enforcement of social rights and to avoid current cases of social dumping?

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. –  Well, I didn’t refer to that in my speech, but obviously we do not support social dumping. The proposals here, by the Commission and by Parliament, will address these issues in an equitable manner. I support equality, I support fairness, and definitely there are huge opportunities here for us to get a good and better transport system in Europe.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: - Mr Chairman!Commissioner!We are talking about the most important mode of transport in Europe in every respect, of particular importance for small and medium-sized enterprises.Commissioner, there are serious complaints at the Commission.First, inactivity when introducing MiLoG and "Loi Macron".Secondly, that the Commission is indifferent to the so-called new Europe companies that are successful in the European market.There is an undisguised feeling that the carriers of this new Europe had no right to be successful and now have to be punished, and the Commission accepts it.Therefore, I would very much like to ask that the Commission become a Commission, that we start using Community methods.This one minute is almost over, but I have this general request: simply start being responsible for road transport in Europe.Otherwise, serious conflict situations will arise.

name: Georges Bach (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! Two years ago, during a large conference in Brussels, the Commission advocated a social approach to road transport. The motto at the time was to focus on the employees and the drivers. They made us wait a long time, made us wait a long time. And, of course, the rumors do indeed boil over the course of time. I am concerned about what I am hearing, I am concerned about what I am reading. As a representative of the citizens, I think that we as a Parliament cannot put our hands on our laps. It is for this reason that we have also drawn up the resolution, even if it is no longer being noticed. Hope dies last. I would like to raise a few points that are nevertheless important for me personally and also for us as an EPP. We do not want any additional liberalization of cabotage. There is talk of an extension, of three or five days. That is unacceptable to me. On the social aspect, I would like to ask the Commission: will we continue with the weekly rest periods as we know them today? Or does the Commission intend to add further flexibility? And if so, has the Commission examined a method of how longer working hours could affect safety and how this also affects social conditions? In the end, I hope that the Commission will present a balanced package that protects drivers, guarantees fair competition, does not entail any additional administrative effort and that will increase road safety through digitization.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, as you know, Belgium is shaken by a legal case which targets a major road transport operator. 1,100 drivers from eastern countries were allegedly exploited in unworthy working conditions and for a pittance. If the facts are true, we are talking about extremely serious things here: criminal organizations, human trafficking, social fraud and money laundering. I no longer want that Europe. I believe in Europe and I really want a Europe which puts the social and the economic on the same footing. I want a Europe for which the principle "for equal work, equal pay" at the same workplace is a fundamental right applied and monitored. Your responsibility here is immense, because the Belgian case demonstrates the ineffectiveness of the system. You must put an end to this social carnage which has enriched some companies by sacrificing jobs on the one hand and the fundamental rights of tens of thousands of European workers on the other. Therefore, we expect a lot from your proposals and I hope that the first negative echoes that are coming back to us are only fiction given the immense stakes in the road sector. We look forward to your proposals.

name: Luis de Grandes Pascual (PPE).
text: - Mr President, for a long time now, the road transport sector has been neglected. It is true that we have dealt with railways, aviation, maritime transport. But it is no less true that road transport demands and draws attention to its important role in the symbiosis that co-modality implies. We have to treat this package very seriously, either from the modernity that represents the digitization of the sector or from the old acquaintances, such as social or environmental issues. We must not forget that the road is one of the backbone of the Union. Vital to our economy. With more cargo and more passengers than all other modes combined; and, furthermore, an essential engine for job creation and growth, with more than ten million citizens who are involved. We need a strong and competitive road transport sector to respond to the needs of the European market, as well as to the social and environmental requirements of the European Union, which are an inexcusable requirement at this time. In any case, you need an update of your own role in addition to other modes of transport. The Commission urges us to approach the issue from four pillars: the internal market; fair competition and workers' rights; decarbonization; digitization. The European Parliament, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, accept the challenge and we get to work.

name: Jens Nilsson (S&D).
text: - Mr President! When I was rapporteur in the Committee on Transport for our report on social dumping last year, we came to some things that were important for the Commission to include now. One is the cabotage rules. They said they should be easy to follow, and they should be easy to control. We cannot continue as today, where unscrupulous, unscrupulous companies break the regulations without any consequences. These rogue companies exploit people to work for low wages and dump prices. In a functioning market, fair competition must prevail. If not everyone who e.g. driving in Sweden follows the rules of the labor market and current collective agreements when it comes to wages, well then prices are dumped and serious companies are eliminated. This must end. We also called for a revision of the Combi Directive as this directive is used to circumvent cabotage rules. My view is that the Combi Directive can be completely abolished, as it has no other function than to make it easier for those who want to break the rules. But if the directive is changed, then the loopholes must be closed. I demand fair competition and rights for workers. It is the most important!

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! We have been waiting for over two years for the final position of the European Commission on the introduction of a minimum wage by Germany or France. For months we have been hearing about social dumping, a definition that has entered the EU vocabulary and which many believe is part of the fight against competition. Many would like to make certain transport operations subject to the provisions of the Posting of Workers Directive. Where in all this, ladies and gentlemen, is the most important European principle - the free movement of goods and services? Where is the idea of ​​competitiveness, thanks to which new companies and new jobs are created? Let us remember that it is natural that the existing economic differences between the states of our community make different states the leaders in different sectors. It's natural. Of course, this does not mean that there are no irregularities in this sector. And I would like to stress with all responsibility that everything should be done to eliminate all abuses. That is why we have been waiting for months for a mobility package that would solve many problems and answer many questions. However, let us remember - or be aware - that representatives of the transport industry from all European Union countries - although not everyone talks about it - is afraid that, using the arguments of protecting social rights, the European Union will not force protectionist regulations that will limit competition and introduce excessive bureaucracy.

name: Петър Курумбашев (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I would like to ask a few questionable questions. In the first place, is there no speculation on the subject of social rights in order to require a redistribution of market share? Is the ban on liberalization of cabotage only a measure to protect social rights or is it pure protectionism by Member States that do not want the new Member States to increase their market share? Why is the Commission not instituting criminal proceedings against countries that are at the geographical center of the European Union, which are making changes to their national legislation and opposing the liberalization of the European single transport market? In order to arrive at proposals such as trucks registered in certain countries, to provide services mainly in those countries. So, German trucks to provide services in Germany, French - in France. I would even ask you to expand your proposal: can Berlin trucks only run within a 50-kilometer radius around Berlin, or can Budapest trucks move within a 50-kilometer radius of Budapest? So we will return from the 21st not to the 20th, but to the 17th century. Is this the future of the European Union?

name: Claudia Schmidt (PPE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! The Member States save 280 billion euros from motorists and hauliers every year. 280 billion euros simply because it was decided that citizens should pay extra because they have to, should or want to get from A to B for work or in their free time. 280 billion euros - and that should still not be enough? I really don't believe what has been said here under the guise of the user pays principle or polluter pays principle. It can almost be described as shameless. I would like to say: First: We are representatives of our voters, and not their legal guardians. Second: what right is actually required to make driving a car more expensive? Because we think that by doing this we can save our planet on our own, or because cycling and railroaders can't think of anything other than trading in organic indulgences? Third: what have all the taxes and duties brought in over the past 40 years? Did that mean you drove a kilometer less or sold one less car? No! It doesn't help if you just keep increasing the dose. No toll in the world, no matter how high taxes, mean that citizens do without their cars. And why should they? The car is indispensable for young families, for commuters, for rural areas and for leisure activities. Ecological penalty taxes do nothing for the environment, but better technology does. Let's invest in it, let's channel money into research! That really helps, the rest is just expensive ideology and green folklore in the fight against the car.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I think we need to look at the situation very realistically. We need a single transport market. If we talk about the single market, we must also think about this activity. At the same time, we must be very fair to ourselves: there is not yet enough ethics and fair activity. There is still discrimination between workers in one country and another, between large and small companies. And I am glad that the Commissioner has presented here that the mobility package aims to clarify the circumstances in which the minimum wage is paid in a certain country, because many colleagues here have noticed this. Drivers are taken from one side and, although they work in a country, the driver is paid the salary in the country where the salary is lower. Then improve working conditions. But let's be fair. There is a difference in the economic development of the Member States and we need to link this mobility package with the cohesion funds. There is no equal infrastructure. Who can balance a four-legged table that has each leg of a different length. Commissioner, I have high hopes for this package, but there must be a link with the other projects.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, criminal organization, trafficking in human beings, money laundering, forgery and forgery: this is what the Belgian company Jost, active in road transport, is suspected of. She is now suspected of major social fraud, an indictment that reminds us that social dumping is undermining our society, with the main victims of workers who exercise their profession in sometimes inhuman conditions. "We must fight against social dumping"! This is what the President of the Commission often tells us with conviction and reason. This action is essential to give a future to the European project. We cannot be satisfied with vague statements. We need to act at all levels, especially at European level. The Commission will present its road transport package. Without anticipating the content, I would like to stress a few priorities. Rules on cabotage and posting of workers must be strictly enforced. It is urgent to regulate professional transport carried out by means of small trucks. This is an issue in terms of working conditions but also unfair competition and road safety. Finally, it is essential to guarantee the drivers' rest time. The transport package must meet these challenges. We must stop social dumping and ensure decent working conditions for workers. To achieve this, I am convinced that you will be able to count on the social partners, but also on the work of this Parliament.

name: Karoline Graswander-Hainz (S&D).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! The challenges in European road traffic are diverse: reduction of emissions, new drives, automation, digitization - all these are areas that play a major role. But in my opinion one of the biggest problems is the social area. The unions keep telling us about precarious working conditions and catastrophic conditions: hourly wages of EUR 3.50, drivers who don't come home for months and have to sleep in the truck. What is not needed, dear Commission, is increasing liberalization in the area of ​​cabotage, driving and rest times as long as the principle of "equal work for the same wages in the same place" is not implemented. What is needed, however, is the enforcement of rights and rules through stricter controls and better coordination between the EU member states with the help of a European road transport agency. Fundamental social rights of the people must have priority in Europe.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the transport game, in particular road transport, will be one of the most interesting to test the innovation capacity of the European Union. We talked in great detail about all the challenges related to new fuels, the need to limit emissions into the atmosphere, as much as 70 percent of the emissions generated in the transport sector occur within road transport. A lot of investments are needed. The European Commission has allocated 70 billion of structural funds to this sector, of which 39 is earmarked for identifying strategies to limit atmospheric emissions in the transport sector and, in particular, road transport. These investments are made if there is a general framework of guarantees that guarantee a balanced market, in which the reasons of the investor are respected and the reasons of the worker are respected. A general concept within which there is no margin by exploiting the people who work, the economic pockets necessary for investments are not created by not paying people. The resolution is overall fairly balanced, but there are too many obscure points. To liberalize cabotage in a reckless way will be a bogus innovation, paid for by transporters who will play a game to the bottom and we will all lose out. It is therefore necessary to intervene on this lot, so that social guarantees, safety and balance in terms of administrative obligations are guaranteed, as many of our transport associations have said. There are no transports and empty returns because cabotage is too free, or rather too restricted, there is because it is difficult to match supply and demand. We are not wrong.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the road package is welcome, because, without clear and up-to-date European rules, governments were already creating a jungle of national rules, each more imaginative, fragmentary and protectionist. We trust that by the time we have to deal with the new proposal for the Eurovignette, the annoying dispute over the German toll will be resolved. The news that reaches us is still confusing. We also await with great interest the solution or counterpart that the Commission is going to give to the extra cost of the periphery. Regarding the package, we have certain reservations regarding the possible modification of the driving and rest times, as it was difficult for us to agree on it and, although there are elements to improve its effectiveness, any simplification that reopens the entire standard may make it unfeasible, or worse, less guaranteed and balanced. Mr Hogan, you rightly say about the tachograph that it is used to control irregularities. But what really controls them are the inspectors who control the tachograph, as with illegal cabotage. Hence, we need more and better inspectors and we are totally in favor of a European agency that reinforces and coordinates social standards, but also road safety, which is once again weakening. And I also trust that the debate on the package, instead of continuing to place the blame on truckers, opens the possibility of starting a black list of companies that fail to comply, so that they lose their honor.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! Transport is an integral part of the single market that has a huge impact on the competitiveness of the European economy. It is in the interest of all members of the European Union to build a competitive sector without physical, legal or administrative barriers. Unfortunately, today we find ourselves at a point where the future of the transport sector is at stake. In this context, I would like to refer to the ongoing work on the revision of the Posting of Workers Directive. The provisions of the directive currently in force, and in particular the proposed changes, in no way take into account the specificity of the transport sector. How to calculate the salary of a driver who travels through several countries? How to determine which country is the place of habitual work and which labor law should be applied, if the employee stays in several places during one month? How to enforce the obligation to notify, appoint a contact person, and store documents in the cabin? These are matters that negatively affect the development of the transport sector, which is why many MEPs support the exclusion of the transport sector from the Posting of Workers Directive and the development of sectoral solutions that take into account the high mobility of the sector. We expect the road package, to be published by the Commission at the end of May, to provide solutions that will protect workers and allow transport companies to develop, especially as we are currently dealing with numerous disputes and controversies related to road transport. As a result, several countries have recently introduced solutions that are protectionist and have a negative impact on the mobility and competitiveness of the sector. Unfortunately, there is no decisive action on the part of the European Commission. For two and a half years, companies have been waiting for the conclusion of the procedure on the minimum wage in Germany. Proceedings in France are pending and the Commission is silent. Companies, but also administrations national and regulatory authorities need to know what employment requirements and conditions apply.When is the Commission going to clarify this matter?

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I think it is not just rumours that the Commission is pleading for a temporary exclusion for drivers from the Posting Directive when they perform cabotage. For me that is a big problem, firstly because it wants to get rid of the limits of three operations and stretch this to unlimited operations for a number of days, and secondly because under the proposal a driver could be paid lower wages than the minimum wage in the country where he is working because currently that is prohibited by the Posting Directive.  I think that proposal is shameful. It would destabilise and undercut the domestic transport market. So, I have two questions. The first is, how will the new cabotage rules be checked? Could a Bulgarian driver for instance, drive around under Bulgarian wages in Germany for let us say five days, then leave the country to go to the Netherlands for a day and then come back and do the same thing? The second question is that under the proposal there should be equal work for equal pay – or did the Commission perhaps mean equal work for equal pay, but some workers are more equal than others?

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE).
text: - It is far from sufficient for traffic safety for drivers who comply with the regulations and drive at a reasonable speed and are sober and rested when driving.In traffic safety, employers play an extremely important role, forcing too many busy professional drivers to take to the road in order to make a profit, even when they need to rest, or forcing them to drive too fast to reach their destination on time.However, even good and clear regulations are not enough if the control over their implementation is poor.That is why we need the proactive operation of the police, inspection and other official bodies, but at the same time there must be enough of these bodies, and they must carry out controls where traffic conditions are difficult and not where it is easiest to fill the budget.It is up to the relevant ministries and the government to set priorities and allocate human and financial resources accordingly so that the police and other bodies can carry out their tasks.Each of us in society can contribute to security.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the road transport sector in Europe must be ready to seize the opportunities offered by digitization, with the development of both vehicle-to-vehicle and vehicle-to-infrastructure communication infrastructures. This is the future of road mobility and the Union must provide an adequate regulatory framework, logistical support and research and innovation capacity. The future of transport certainly passes through environmental sustainability, an issue on which Europe is strongly committed, but the functionality and interoperability of urban public transport must also become a priority. The adaptation of existing structures requires adequate support policies at European level and substantial investments to transform and adapt the transport systems of European cities. The issue of illegal road cabotage needs to be addressed soon, it is unfair competition which is causing considerable damage in the Union. The same controls must be made more effective, just as the sanction system must be modified in substance.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, the social aspect of road transport is certainly important in the European Union, however, we must take into account the figure already mentioned by my colleague Kelly, which is that 25% of carbon dioxide emissions are from transport and that it is the only sector in To the European Union which has not reduced its emissions since 1991. So, this importance means that we have to look at global competition that invests in the development of electromobility, that invests in the development of railways and where the European Union lags far behind in fact in the research and implementation of these policies. If we look at the infrastructure for alternative fuels, that is, the directive that obliged the members of the European Union to build that infrastructure, we see that the members are still lagging behind. And then the question remains how, through the taxes we all pay for the emissions our cars produce, will we motivate citizens to switch to electric cars or hybrids and thereby actually reduce their emissions into the environment by driving on highways.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we look forward to the Commissioner’s proposals in the road package at the end of this month. I would urge her to look at the area of serious road injuries and road deaths, and I know she has already committed to doing so. There were 35 000 serious injuries on Europe’s roads in 2015 and 26 000 fatalities. It is an area where technology can play a really, really important role in reducing such figures. Be these vehicle to vehicle or vehicle to infrastructure instruments, Europe has been to the fore in leading road safety and ensuring that cars and infrastructure are equipped with the relevant technology that can indeed save lives, and we can do still more.  Who among us can remember a time when we did not have seat belts in our cars? Now they are a requirement for all cars for sale in Europe and on European roads. So Europe has indeed been a leader in this area.  I would like also to mention the whole area of drivers and road vehicles. There has been much discussion around this, and here again we need a European solution. I would like to quote from a letter that the Commissioner has had from a number of road haulier associations across Europe, including the Irish Road Hauliers Group, asking for flexibility in rest periods, considering that those coming from outermost regions, and particularly islands, do have a difficulty in getting back to their home base at weekends.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I wish to thank all of the contributors to this debate. It is a very timely debate in the context of the resolution that will be brought before the House tomorrow. There is also the fact that the mobility package that has been indicated for some time by Commissioner Bulc will happen on 31 May.  Just to bring you up to date in relation to the business that Commissioner Bulc has been involved in over the last few hours, I can confirm that after this evening’s meeting in Brussels between the European Union and the United States that the European Union and the United States will continue to work very closely on aviation security. There is another meeting scheduled for next week, because of the great importance and urgency of the issues, to assess risks and provide practical solutions and approaches to the proposals that were put forward, particularly by the United States, which would have a very strong impact on citizens and on businesses and on people between the European Union and the United States, and indeed globally from a point of view of security. Everybody is on the same side in terms of protecting our passengers, and hopefully they can reach some practical solutions in the coming weeks. Just to take to speak about the rumours bit of business first which was mentioned by a few people regarding the road initiatives, I did state in my opening remarks on behalf of Commissioner Bulc that it is important to make clear that the rests will not be shorter and that driving time will not be longer in the proposals that would be put forward. This would compromise road safety which would not be acceptable and indeed would be completely out of tune with the Commission’s policies and Commission proposals.  In relation to other matters, I agree with most people who recognise that transport is economical, it is environmental and social in terms of all its dimensions. It is a bit like the area of responsibility that I know best: agriculture. But in any event the Commission plans, and I want to confirm this, to adopt all of the road initiatives on 31 May as part of the mobility package. I think that while some people were getting quite alarmed about possible rumours, hopefully we can put these to rest here this evening in saying that there is no need for people to be going on strike or writing to MEPs until such time that these road initiatives are adopted.  I would not encourage speculation, but some of the speakers have mentioned a number of issues to which I will refer. On cabotage, the current rules, which are based on three operations within seven days, cannot be enforced. The Commission plans to amend the current rules to make these enforceable within further opening or closing of the market for cabotage. In relation to the posting of workers, the Posting Directive applies to all economic sectors including transport, which means that drivers are posted when being abroad, but given the highly mobile nature of the road transport sector, there is a need for sector-specific rules for the road transport sector. The Commission intends to come up with these sector-specific rules as part of their own initiatives, which will lighten the administrative burden for road hauliers but guarantee workers’ rights and respect for drivers. This does not mean excluding drivers from the social rules.  In relation to rest times and rules, there are clear EU rules already on driving and rest times for drivers. For example, the daily rest time of at least 11 hours weekly, and the rest time of 45 continuous hours for the week. Some argue that these rules do not provide significant or sufficient flexibility and that they do not guarantee that drivers return to home on a regular basis. The Commission plans to modify the current rules to take these concerns into account.  Existing rules are unclear and interpreted differently across Europe about sleeping in cabins. At the moment, a few Member States prohibit drivers from taking the regular weekly rests in the cabin, while others allow it. This creates uncertainty for drivers and for hauliers. Drivers should be allowed to take some rests in their cabins if they choose to do so, but within certain limits to cater for social rights. This would be clarified also in the legal proposals of the Commission.  On the environment side, the CO2 emissions from transport are hugely significant in the overall emissions, and the limits that are expected of us now are rising from the Paris Agreement. Road transport will have to play its part. We will for the first time have the tool that is necessary for this: the VECTO tool to charge vehicles based on CO2 emissions, which would give users the incentives to purchase and use cleaner vehicles. This will be included in the road initiatives and the Eurovignette Directive.  I think Mrs Sender mentioned the phasing out of the time-based vignette, and Commisioner Bulc is indeed looking for ways to incentivise the use of distance-based systems. Such systems better reflect the ‘user pays’ and the ‘polluter pays’ principle than the time-based one and I know she is very sympathetic to your view on this. Current EU tolling systems lack interoperability, which is especially a problem for cross-border traffic. The Commission plans to put the conditions in place for new service providers to provide EU-wide tolling services. Besides better service to users, this will also reduce the cost of tolling and give the possibility for other ancillary services to be provided as well. With regard to what Commissioner Bulc has said in respect of the German road user charge for passenger cars and the inclusion of this in EU legislation, she stated clearly on 16 February during the plenary session of this parliament, that foreign drivers cannot be discriminated against. The Commission decided today to close the infringement procedure initiated in June 2015 against Germany regarding the introduction of a road charge for passenger cars. This decision follows the adoption last March of amending laws in Germany, and the Commission came to the conclusion that these laws have addressed its concerns by removing discrimination based on nationality. Of course, the Commission will now continue to monitor the correct implementation of this law, and the application of this law is very important. More fundamentally, we are also considering proposing rules that underpin non-discrimination of foreign vehicle owners as part of the road initiatives. This could include, for the first time, passenger cars, which are excluded so far.  In relation to the establishment of a European Road Transport Agency, which of course is the view of the majority of this House, this takes some time. I am not going to prejudge what Commissioner Bulc will say to you on the 31 May, but what I will say is that Member States in the meantime can continue with better enforcement regulations or rules if they wish, and they do have systems in place that they can enforce better. I think perhaps in the short term this is an area that we should look at and do more at the level of regional and national governments whilst we are waiting for the implementation of this over-arching overall agency that you wish to have. So those are just a few remarks responding to some of the concerns that have been expressed during the course of this debate. I think you will see that the Commissioner is very sympathetic and you seem to be going in the same general direction, pardon the pun, in relation to the proposals that are about to emerge in the mobility package. I am sure that this will go smoothly through with your help and support in due course.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: Thank you, Commissioner.Mr Van Dalen has the floor on a point of order.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: - (NL) Mr President, I have a point of order.The Commissioner has now explained the German toll and that today the Commission has apparently withdrawn the infraction procedure, but he must now make a commitment that we will receive a letter and a good explanation of why the Commission has now refrained fromto pursue that infringement procedure.We are entitled to this, because we have just passed a resolution here in Parliament that we want clarity about the position of the Commission.So I would like to hear from the Commissioner now: we will receive a letter with an explanation and an explanation.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: Mr van Dalen, obviously what you said was not on procedure and that is why you did not refer to an article in the Rules of Procedure.I am chairing and not the Commissioner.You referred to a procedural issue and there is no procedural issue.Do you have a procedural issue?

name: Michael Cramer (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mister President!That has to do with the rules of procedure, because we asked the Commissioner by a huge majority to explain to us that the burden on German drivers is being relieved more than before, and that is suddenly Europe-friendly, while it was previously anti-European.We wanted this explanation, we didn't get it.Nevertheless, the proceedings are discontinued - whoever wants to understand, we don't!

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: This, too, is not, in my opinion, a matter of procedure.But if the Commissioner wants to add anything substantive to these two speeches, I think it would be welcomed by both the Bureau and the MEPs who put it.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, just to clarify to the two gentlemen. The decision was made today. Of course it will be communicated in detail in the coming days to all Members that have an interest in this matter, including this House, and of course you do not expect that we have the full details today when the matter has just been concluded.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: Thank you, Commissioner, we hope to have the clarifications requested soon.I have received a motion for a resolution to end this debate.The discussion is over.The vote will take place tomorrow.Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: in writing. - There is no doubt that road transport is one of the pillars of the European economy, as it generates as much as 5 million jobs and creates nearly 2% of the EU's GDP. Therefore, I consider it extremely important to support him at the European level, both through appropriate legislation, development of road infrastructure, and support for people employed in this sector. Therefore, in our actions, we must pay special attention to the fact that the proposed solutions do not impose additional, unnecessary burdens on entrepreneurs, do not hinder the work of people employed in the sector and do not disintegrate the transport market. I am afraid that this is the effect of including road transport in the Posted Workers Directive. In addition, I believe that it is essential to combat unfair practices that harm workers in this sector, such as bogus employment or the illegal minimization of labor costs.

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: in writing. –  The set of legislative proposals, the so-called ‘Mobility Package’, part of what is expected on 31 May, should aim to increase the competitiveness of the road transport sector and growth of small and medium transport companies. However, up to now, instead of focusing on fair competition by combating fraudulent practices and eliminating the phenomenon of illegal work, one can hear many voices against so-called ‘social dumping’ and intentions to restrict road transport operations, including cabotage, and further regulate drivers. In recent years several Member States have placed certain restrictions on the conditions under which hauliers can perform international transport and cabotage operations. These are clearly protectionism measures and should not be tolerated. These measures lead to risk of fragmentation of the EU internal market.  I expect that the ‘Mobility Package’ will first of all clarify and simplify the existing relevant social legislation of the transport sector, so that the rules are uniformly interpreted and properly implemented. And only after that, any change to social and working conditions legislation must be evidence-based and carefully weighted, shall not restrict fair competition based on objective competitive advantages, and shall not create any further administrative burden and additional costs for transport undertakings.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. - We are living in difficult times: the EU's competitiveness is declining, unemployment is still high, youth unemployment is causing enormous tensions and the migration crisis is still on the agenda. During this period, the so-called. The term 'social dumping' is gaining ground in the arguments of both the European Commission and some Western Member States, even though the mobility of European citizens and businesses should not be reduced but, on the contrary, increased. It must be borne in mind that the EU's global competitiveness has been steadily declining since the 1990s. What is needed is not primarily a multi-speed Europe, but improved competitiveness and a truly single market where, in addition to capital and goods, services and labor can move freely! Thus, even more transport connections, more intensive trade in goods and even more better, cheaper services are needed so that consumers can spend more and more, creating even more new jobs. In a multi-speed EU, regional development policy (continued catching-up and convergence as a goal) would also be called into question, although its balancing function was one of the main attractions of accession, as was the single, free internal market. That is why, instead of reducing mobility, the European Commission must take action against any measures taken by Member States that restrict the free movement of services in the field of road haulage.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: signed up. - The legislative package on the road transport market to be proposed in the coming weeks must address the major problems currently facing the sector. Road passenger and freight transport companies need a clear legislative framework for generating growth and jobs. The Commission must take into account for future European legislation that transport must be more competitive and make a positive contribution to territorial cohesion. We cannot talk about a long-term transport strategy without focusing on the development of European road infrastructure, vehicle technology and the interoperability of transport systems and modes. Road safety must be a zero priority, so the necessary steps must be taken to develop the "vehicle-to-vehicle" and "vehicle-to-infrastructure" communication infrastructure. The Commission needs to harmonize existing rules on electronic tolling, monitoring of cabotage operations, signaling and electronic systems, on-board digital devices, safety equipment. I emphasize that the freedom to provide transport services throughout the EU is the basis of the internal market in the road sector. This fundamental right of workers must respect working conditions and rest periods, as well as access to qualifications and training, the health and safety of drivers.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: in writing.- The situation in the single European road transport market is far from uniform.The introduction of various measures at national level and different interpretations of existing legislation lead to its fragmentation.One of the key themes of the forthcoming road transport initiative will be to improve the social conditions of workers.I consider it important for the Commission to present a proposal in the road package that will ensure real enforcement of the rules and clarity of the rules and their application in the Member States.The aim should be to prevent circumvention by those carriers who take advantage of the various loopholes in the current legislation in force and, for example, set up mailboxes on purpose.I believe that the resulting Commission proposals will improve the working conditions of professional drivers and thus prevent their further outflow.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D)
text: written. - We can only hope that the Commission reads the resolution of the Transport Committee carefully, because we are very concerned about what we have informally about the road initiative. The Commission has now announced the road initiative for May 31st. There are plans on the table to remove truck journeys from the scope of the Posting of Workers Directive. That means: no protection requirements such as generally binding collective agreements and minimum wages for truck drivers. Free passage for social dumping, is that the Commission's plan? In our amendments to the revision of the Posting of Workers Directive, we have already made it clear: no exemption for transport! Let me give you just one current example: a Benelux transport company is accused of hiring around 1,100 of its truck drivers through letterbox companies in Eastern European countries. The drivers should nevertheless make their trips from Luxembourg and Belgium. However, they would be paid according to the standard that applies in Romania. Therefore, get in touch with the mailbox companies! The company location must be linked to the company's activity.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. - The road sector is one of the pillars of a thriving European economy. Transport initiatives should therefore support the development of vehicle technologies, promote the use of alternative fuels, increase the interoperability of transport systems and modes, and ensure market access for SMEs operating in this sector. It is also necessary to reduce the bureaucratic and financial burden resulting from different national rules in order to ensure greater freedom to provide transport services across the EU. Above all, however, one must remember that there is no free market or dynamic development without fair competition. This, however, is disturbed by many unfavorable factors, in particular by all kinds of protectionism and particularisms hitting the common market, which are particularly visible in the international road transport sector. To prevent them, European Union policy must therefore support the development of a sustainable road sector that is characterized by fair competition. Without building a broad front against the proliferation of protectionism in Europe, it may soon turn out that the single market is only an empty slogan with no content. We cannot allow this.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D)
text: written. - The mobility package launched by the Commission on 31 May is an excellent opportunity to ensure decent working and working conditions for drivers and to tackle social dumping definitively. That is what I will be evaluating the next package on: does it tackle social dumping and improve the working conditions of drivers? Will it end exploitation and the sometimes dire conditions in which drivers have to perform their jobs? Does it ensure that we get well-rested drivers on our roads with decent wages? Is the legislation being complied with? These are the crucial questions we must ask ourselves and what the package must be judged on. The fight against social dumping is not a fight between East and West. Let's not fall for that trap. It is a struggle for better working conditions for drivers, for greater safety on our roads, against fraud (often perpetrated by companies from Western European member states that flout the existing rules via post box companies) and against exploitation of drivers. I am counting on the Commissioner to come out with a package that unambiguously tackles social dumping and fraud and is fully committed to improving the working conditions of drivers.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: in writing. - Polish carriers are currently the largest group of road entrepreneurs on the European market. Every day, 200,000 trucks from Poland travel around the European Union, and 32,000 companies handle international transport. They are able to skillfully use Poland's accession to the European Union and work effectively in a competitive market. There is no doubt that truck drivers must have good working conditions and a decent wage. As they are busy with work and often spend many days away from home, they must also be given proper rest and safety. Therefore, I consider it a mistake to work on solutions that introduce additional administrative burdens for carriers without actually improving the living situation of drivers. In my opinion, the essence of the efforts of the European Union and individual Member States today should be to improve the road infrastructure, including the construction of new parking lots, adequately equipped and safe.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is Mr Szejnfeld's report on the implementation of the EU-Republic of Korea Free Trade Agreement

name: Adam Szejnfeld
text: rapporteur. - Mr Chairman! July 1, 2016 marked the fifth anniversary of the entry into force of the free trade agreement between the European Union and its member states and the Republic of Korea. It is the first new generation free trade agreement concluded by the European Union. The agreement, in addition to removing tariffs, also includes rules covering the elimination of non-tariff barriers, thanks to which it creates new market access opportunities, also in the field of services and investments, and in such areas as intellectual property, public procurement and competition policy. Regulations concerning sustainable development are also a very important part of the agreement. For these reasons, this agreement became the model for all subsequent free trade agreements. Our agreement with Korea is not only a breakthrough in terms of the quality and scope of international treaties, but also tangible economic effects for both parties. An example is the fact that thanks to this agreement, inter alia, the trade deficit with Korea amounting to EUR -7.6 billion was transformed into a trade surplus of EUR 2.5 billion, while European exports to Korea increased by around 50% during this period. As a result, trade between partners last year broke the record, reaching almost EUR 90 billion. Korea has become the European Union's eighth trading partner, and the Union has become Korea's third. Similar successes are also visible in the growth of trade in services - we recorded an 11% increase - or the level of foreign direct investment - an increase in Korean investments by 35%. The European Union has become the second, after the USA, area of ​​foreign direct investment for Korea, while the EU states are the first investor in Korea in terms of the value of accumulated direct investments. Behind these exemplary figures, however, there are not only investments, but most of all new jobs, which means an increase in the welfare of citizens of both sides. These are facts that are hard to dispute. Of course, nothing is perfect in life, especially on 100%, therefore the concluded contracts must be analyzed from time to time and possibly corrected. The same will be the case here. Therefore, the report I have prepared includes provisions about the benefits and good results, but also information about the need to solve some important problems. For the Union, these include direct transport clauses and issues of repairing exported goods. For Korea, this is an investment chapter. We would also like to talk about non-tariff barriers, sanitary and phytosanitary barriers, environmental protection, intellectual property protection or the implementation by Korea of ​​the International Labor Organization conventions - this, I admit, is a big problem. Equally important, the final document also contains provisions on the need to promote the contract among small and medium-sized enterprises so that they use the contract to a much greater extent than before. Summing up, especially today, when protectionist slogans are becoming more and more popular, it is worth talking about the benefits of international cooperation in the field of trade and investment. This is clearly demonstrated by free trade agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Korea. Its effects are excellent, far better than previously predicted results for both parties.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, let me thank the European Parliament, the Committee on International Trade and the rapporteur Mr Szejnfeld for the attention, the work and the commitment you put into this. As you said, it has been five years now since the EU-Korea free trade agreement entered into force, so it is very appropriate to evaluate it. We have done an external evaluation; the upcoming opinion of the Economic and Social Committee will deliver one; and together with the work you have done, this gives a good contribution to analyse the results of the first five years. This is, as the rapporteur said, an economic success story. During the first five years of the implementation, EU exports increased by 47%, or EUR 15 billion. Also, Korea increased its export, even if it was a little bit more moderate. This leads to more economic activity, more employment in the EU as well as in Korea. I fully agree with the conclusion of the report, saying that the FTA has and continues to have a positive impact on the socio-economic development of the parties. At the same time, I agree that Korea needs to do more on trade and sustainable development, particularly labour rights. To this end, we need to use all the available channels that we have to insist on the need of progress. I raised this matter with my Korean colleague when he was here just before Christmas, when we had the EU trade committee with Korea, and I have followed it up in a recent letter. In March, we also had a Committee on Trade and Sustainable Development (INTA), so Commission raised it there again. The efforts of civil society mechanisms that are established by the free trade agreement, as well as the government-to-government dialogue, have considerably raised awareness and pressure, and this is a driver for change – but it is not enough. I am fully aware of your request to open formal consultations with Korea on its commitment to freedom of association and collective bargaining. I believe that, as you know, there has just been an election in South Korea, and we should first talk about this with the new minister and the new government as soon as they are in place. Hopefully they will take a forthcoming position on this. Once we know what the new government thinks, we can reflect together on the most appropriate way to ensure better implementation of the trade and sustainable development chapter of this agreement. This would be a matter of priority with a new government, already inviting, as soon as there is a government; I hear this will happen in June, and then I will go to Seoul in September for a Trade Committee meeting that is already planned. There are also a number of items that we would like to address by an amendment to trade agreement: direct transport, repaired goods, truck tractors, and Korea, from their point of view, are interested in including an investment protection chapter. But the country has been hesitant when it comes to the investment quota system, so this makes rapid progress on an amendment package unlikely. In many other areas the implementation runs smoothly, but as you mention, further work needs to be done when it comes to sanitary, phytosanitary issues as well as intellectual property rights. The same applies to the adoption of new geographical indications and the further facilitation of customs procedures. All these issues are being addressed with our Korean counterparts in the different committees and working groups that have been established in the free trade agreement (there are in fact 15 of these groups). In addition, we have indicated to Korea that we will look at legal means if necessary if we do not see progress on these issues. The INTA Committee was informed about this in a report very recently. As I said, the next trade committee is planned for the end of September in Seoul, where I will attend. Thank you very much for the work that has been done here by the rapporteur, the shadow rapporteurs and the INTA Committee. I think this is an excellent work and I appreciate this possibility to discuss this with you.

name: Daniel Caspary
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mister President! It has already become clear: our free trade agreement that the European Union concluded with South Korea is a great success. My colleague Szejnfeld presented the figures. While we had a negative trade balance before this agreement entered into force, our trade balance is now positive. Our exports have increased by almost a third in five years. We have managed to turn a negative trade balance into a trade surplus of around five billion euros. The agreement with South Korea is a wonderful agreement to show many unsettled citizens that we can create all these successes, all these advantages for our employees, for our company and for our consumers without all the bad things happening again and again asserted, and with which our citizens are repeatedly unsettled. That's why I can only call out to everyone: Please do not believe those who sometimes campaign against foreign trade policy on the street. We want to shape globalization, and this agreement is wonderful proof that we are doing exactly what we say we are, that we are not lowering any standards, that we are not restricting services of general interest to the community, that we are not doing any negative things that we cannot do know what we're doing. Second, Commissioner Malmström mentioned that there are some things that we need to improve. I hope that we will use the regular contacts that we now have thanks to the free trade agreement to tackle things. I am thinking of food safety, geographical indications, intellectual property, non-tariff barriers to trade for our automotive sector, as well as the shipbuilding subsidies which are just not okay.

name: Joachim Schuster
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! The free trade agreement between the Republic of Korea and the European Union has been in force for almost six years. Economically, this agreement is certainly a success. The volume of trade has increased significantly over the past six years. The EU's previously existing trade deficit has been turned into a surplus in these years, and the interdependence of the two economic areas has increased overall. I think that is a very good thing, given the current threats of indiscriminate protectionism. However, we must also note that there are significant implementation deficits. The sustainability chapter in particular is being implemented very slowly by Korea. The obligation to ratify the ILO core labor standards has not yet been met. Union rights are ignored and union leaders are arbitrarily arrested in connection with demonstrations. For us Social Democrats, that is unacceptable. We have always said: For us, trade is not just an economic question. Trade without the observance of basic workers' rights cannot be accepted over the long term. Trade policy must also serve to anchor fundamental sustainability goals and fundamental workers' rights worldwide. We are in favor of free trade, but free trade needs a reliable framework and is not an end in itself, but must make a contribution to the implementation of sustainable development goals. We therefore expect the Korean government to finally tackle the implementation of the sustainability chapter decisively. We also have great hopes for the new Korean President Moon, who used to be an advocate for human rights. However, we also call on the Commission to press more vigorously than before to ensure that basic trade union rights are respected. The The Korean government's violation of union rights must be the subject of the dispute settlement mechanism provided in the trade agreement.How vigorously the Commission will proceed here is for us also a question of its political credibility, because sustainability goals can not only be propagated, but one must also try to enforce them more effectively.

name: Joachim Starbatty
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. -  Mister President! The figures show that the fearful rabbits among the Greens, the left and the right have not found confirmation. It is interesting now why the deficit in Korea has turned into a surplus for the Europeans. The reason for this is that the won has appreciated by 20% against the euro. One could ask: Isn't that a disadvantage for Korea? No, just the opposite! Because if we look at the structure of trade, we see that 30% of goods are equipment goods, 20% are means of transport, 12% are chemical products. So that strengthens the efficiency of Korea. As for us: Because of this devaluation of 20%, we are now selling our products 20% cheaper and we also buy Korean products 20% more expensive. This devaluation was a change in the terms of trade to the detriment of Europe. We kind of give away products, but Koreans use it to build their economy, and we buy Korean products too dearly. This is also the quintessence of the shift from a deficit with Japan to a surplus with Japan.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mister President! Allow me to take another look by way of introduction. I am sure we are all concerned about the situation on the Korean peninsula. With Trump and Kim Jong-un, two unpredictable characters meet on the world stage of history. With the election of human rights lawyer and dialogue advocate Moon Jae-in, the Korean people have clearly spoken out in favor of an end to the saber rattling. So, congratulations, President Moon! The second major motive for voting was to revive the Korean economy and create good jobs. And here we have to admit that with the EU-Korea Agreement, the trade balance has developed to the disadvantage of Korea. The deficit has been reversed. With a view to our claim - to fair trade - a partnership should not run like this. The protests against the poor economic development have been suppressed dramatically by the previous governments. Trade unionists, human rights activists and journalists ended up in jail. The ILO core labor standards have still not been ratified. Attempts at discussions by the Commission - which I acknowledge - on the basis of the sustainability chapter of the agreement were ineffective. Together with Korean and European civil society, we therefore call on the Commission to immediately request formal consultations in accordance with Article 13.14 of the Agreement. In this way, the new government can be encouraged and supported right from the start in implementing reforms. Also in the interests of stability on the Korean peninsula.

name: Klaus Buchner
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group.-  Mister President!In this report on the free trade agreement with Korea, it is particularly important to me that the Korean government should finally ratify the fundamental rights of workers, as laid down by the International Labor Organization (ILO).I am also glad that the report takes up the great problem of the oppression and the fight against the trade unions, just as Mr Scholz has just discussed.But I would also have liked the precarious situation of migrant workers in Korea to be addressed.Unfortunately that did not find a majority.My group and I are strictly against the demand for arbitration tribunals.I don't think we should support that and we should also take public opinion here seriously.I would therefore ask you to support my two amendments to this resolution tomorrow.

name: Edouard Ferrand
