text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, the primary vocation of the European Union is to establish free trade treaties. However, in each treaty that you propose to us, we note that the economic, social and health rules, in particular on pork, beef or AOC, are not respected. Why? Because South Korea refuses to sign the conventions of the International Labor Organization. Even though Korea is an essential partner of Europe, the fact remains that we, the European nations, are discriminated against in these agreements. They always benefit those who come to import here in Europe. Why? Quite simply because Korea is doing smart protectionism, which we have never succeeded in doing in Europe. Finally, Commissioner, I will tell you quite simply that if your agreements worked as well as this, Europe would not be the region of the world with the lowest growth. Unfortunately, we, in ten years, in France, have experienced an increase of one million unemployed and I think that these free trade agreements are increasingly weakening our European economies, because we are unable to do as the countries with which we share economic treaties: we are unable to impose the rules they impose on us.

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: - Mister President! I am pleased that this free trade agreement has become a real success story. As chairman of the European Parliament's group on friendship with South Korea, all I can really say is that we should continue on this path. The further development gives opportunities for new companies, especially now also for small and medium-sized companies. We have seen that the success was of course mainly used by the large international corporations in Europe and South Korea. The trade balance position has developed positively. We have created new, additional, attractive jobs not only in Europe, but above all in South Korea. Of course, South Korea currently has a great challenge with North Korea, where you can see that a military-dictatorial system cannot generate the prosperity that South Korea has advanced accordingly with a market-based and open concept. The judgment of the ECJ will now also give us new possibilities, so that the competencies are clearly regulated here. For the European Parliament in particular, it represents an upgrade because we can safely go into the future with it. We also see that the trade facilitation in the WTO negotiations is a big step together with South Korea to improve the conditions here, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, and that we now have to accelerate the implementation. I would also like to remind you that the European Union is now internationalizing the Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs program accordingly, and that there is a focus on South Korea, so that start-up companies and spin-offs from Universities will become more involved here in the future and be able to jointly implement this strategy of action with success for both sides. Commissioner Malmström, I congratulate you on yours Dedication, and I believe this success belongs to all of us.

name: David Martin (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I think there are two takeaways from the Korean Free Trade Agreement. Firstly, that free trade agreements do improve trade and they do create jobs here in Europe, but secondly, free trade agreements that have obligations on social environmental standards are only really going to mean anything if those standards can be enforced separately from the wider trade agreement. If they are simply the obligatory part of the agreement, but have no sanctions attached to them, they are not going to be effective, so what we have to argue for in future trade agreements is that the Sustainable Development Chapter itself should be subject to sanctions.  In addition, I want to join with my colleagues to say that we have some hope that the new president, President Moon of South Korea, will actually respond to our request. He has shown in the past in his work as a human rights lawyer that he is receptive to good labour rights and I wish the Commissioner well in her dialogue with him.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR).
text: - The international atmosphere is not very favorable for free trade. Rather, protectionism is rampant when it comes to free trade agreements, there are even conspiracy theories that corporations are behind it all and that ordinary people have nothing to do with it. That is why it is necessary to look for positive examples here. This agreement is certainly one of the positive examples. I think it is indisputable that it has helped to increase the volume of trade between the European Union and Korea. It is about a half increase, a record level has been reached in terms of the level of trade, and although the agreement obviously needs some improvement, I think we need to sell it as a clear success. In any case, it will pave the way for other trade agreements, especially now that the European Court of Justice has made this a little more complicated for us yesterday in its ruling on the bilateral agreement with Singapore. Negotiating further trade agreements will no longer be so easy. So please, let's sell it as a positive example.

name: Anne-Marie Mineur (GUE/NGL).
text: - (NL) Mr President, the free trade agreement with Korea has produced mixed results over the past six years. Korea has still not ratified the mandatory ILO conventions. A trade surplus of EUR 2.5 billion has been created, which is detrimental to the economic development of Korea. The trade agreement also leads to water pollution, environmental pollution and increased CO2 emissions. Furthermore, small and medium-sized businesses have barely benefited from that treaty. The plan now is to solve the problems by betting on ISDS and TiSA. I strongly oppose that. UN Secretary-General António Guterres this afternoon strongly criticized having double standards of human rights. We should understand this criticism as an incentive to give the highest priority to human rights, but also trade union rights, environmental protection, food safety and a fairer distribution of wealth. Instead of working on treaties such as TiSA, the European Union can put its energy much better into the International Convention on Transnational Corporations and Human Rights.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, thanks to Mr Szejnfeld for his work on this file. I welcome the positive outcomes of implementation of the FTA with Korea. It shows that trade liberalisation, opening markets and building trade partnerships with similar economies bring benefits for both parties. We are in the sixth year of implementation of this agreement and we can see positive tangible results. Our overall trade balance has been substantially increasing since starting implementation of this agreement in 2011. We should still be aware that this is the first comprehensive FTA negotiated with a fully industrialised and developed economy and at the same time the first trade agreement with an Asian country. The assessment of this FTA is a good opportunity to draw lessons for the future of EU external trade and investment policies through FTAs. I think it should be a strong argument for fostering other free trade deals with developing and developed countries in the region.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Korea is often shown as an example in free trade agreements. When we look at the trade balance today in favor of Europe, but also economic growth in Korea, we could say that, in the end, things are going very well. It’s true that’s part of the deal. Today, there are a number of criticisms on the issue of workers' rights in Korea. This is the main task we must tackle today. If, indeed, this chapter of social and sustainable development were binding, by also providing for sanction mechanisms, this would allow us to force Korea to take a step towards respecting these workers' rights. Therefore, I think it is important that these controls are put in place fairly quickly, that there is this formal consultation procedure with Korea and, most importantly, before any deepening, I think there is a need to '' demand that this country follow this logic of sustainable development and respect for workers' rights.

name: Karoline Graswander-Hainz (S&D).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! The free trade agreement between the EU and South Korea has been in force for over five years. From an economic point of view, there are certainly many positive things to report. When signing the agreement, South Korea also undertook to implement international standards for workers' rights. But that has not happened to this day. The fact is that labor standards are not being met and that there are still arrests and police violence at demonstrations. There can be no further negotiations with South Korea as long as South Korea does not meet its obligations to protect workers and does not take the sustainability chapter seriously. I expect the Commission to act and start talks with the new government. This example also shows us that in the future there will have to be sanction mechanisms in the sustainability chapter of all trade agreements because we will not get anywhere if we are voluntary.

name: Bernd Lange (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner!The deal is undoubtedly a good deal.But as it is in life: the better is the enemy of the good.That is why we naturally have to reflect on what we can do better with future agreements, since the ECJ yesterday in the ruling on the Singapore Agreement stated that workers' rights are an integral part of trade agreements and therefore also fall within our competence.If you look at South Korea now, there are problems with the joint implementation.So these domestic advisory groups do not have clear rules of procedure.It is not clear how quickly and by whom someone can be deployed there.The clear position of the rights of these domestic advisory groups is not regulated, nor is the question of the enforcement of their resolutions.That is why we must strengthen the rights and obligations of domestic advisory groups in agreements in the future.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - I have been studying statistics on trade between South Korea and the EU all afternoon this afternoon, and I must say what my PPE colleagues have said, the agreement is a clear success.In all categories, EU exports to South Korea are growing significantly.The negative trade balance 5 years ago became a positive trade balance for the EU and we could talk about individual categories of goods.Car exports to South Korea increased by 250%.This is truly extraordinary, and as some colleagues have said, this is a response to today's political debate about how beneficial free trade is or, conversely, such modern tendencies to isolate how dangerous they are.Commissioner, thank you for your speech.I keep my fingers crossed on your way to South Korea, please also negotiate rights for workers, but please, let us sell this agreement as a clear EU success.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, it was not so long ago that the Commission came here to tell us that its new free trade agreements would guarantee that our social model, the European social model, would also apply to our trading partners. There is no more palpable proof of this deception than the fact that after the Free Trade Agreement, South Korea continues without ratifying the fundamental ILO conventions and massively persecutes trade unionists who oppose the dismantling of collective bargaining and the rights of workers. union membership. Five days of vacation a year. Twelve hours of daily work schedule. Work and social conditions that have led to 15,000 suicides annually. Why, I ask, with these conditions we continue to collaborate with the dismantling of labor rights, with the situation that is occurring in South Korea. How to believe, therefore, that other social statements like those that were added to CETA are nothing more than dead paper. With what happened in South Korea it is clear that free trade is synonymous with social dumping. The agreements in force must be suspended until fundamental rights are fulfilled.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this debate. I think it has been extremely important. Korea is, so far, the most ambitious trade agreement that we have with any country and that makes this report very important for the free trade agreement per se, but also to see what we can learn, what can be drawn from the experience and the lessons that can be learned when it comes to other trade agreements too.  I have listened very carefully to your comments here and I think we share in the assessment that, economically, this been a very good, successful agreement. It has created job possibilities, growth and increased trade, and it has been good both for Korea and for us. This is absolutely something that we should use as a model.  Even further, we have spoken to Member States and I think there is even more potential for using this trade agreement, especially by small or medium-sized companies. We must see how we can help Member States to reach out to small and medium-sized companies, to tell them about the possibilities so that they also dare to invest and to engage in this.  However, and I do not think there is any disagreement here in this House, or in the Commission either, there are some problems. There are some problems related to the trade agreement when it comes to phytosanitary matters, for instance, some technical problems and some customs problems that we are trying to address. We are also, as you are, very concerned about labour rights and the way that trade union leaders have been treated in Korea.  I have raised this personally many times with the former government. We have written letters and we have addressed it in the different fora. I think it is fair that we at least wait for the new government to come into place so that we can have a dialogue with the new minister, who will probably come in a couple of weeks, to address this and to see if this government is more open to cooperation and more forthcoming when it comes to labour rights.  There are indications that this is the case and as soon as there is a minister I will liaise with him or her, and see how we can move forward on this issue. As I said, there is a formal meeting in September and I will be happy to report back to you, of course, on these conversations.  Our own evaluation of this Agreement, which the Commission is doing, of these five years will be published by the summer. I think this will further broaden the picture of five years’ experience and it can help us when we go further in negotiations with South Korea, but also in learning lessons from others. We will, of course, make sure this House has access to this and keep you all informed. Thank you to the rapporteur for this very useful debate.

name: Adam Szejnfeld
text: rapporteur. - Mr Chairman! First of all, I would like to thank all the speakers, people on their own behalf and on behalf of political factions, for your presentations and thus de facto votes of support for this agreement and this report, although I also understand all the doubts expressed here. They are also presented in the report itself. As I said in my speech, there are no perfect solutions, you have to keep working on them in order to strive for the ideal. I would also like to thank the Commissioner for her cooperation with me and the committee, as well as European Union diplomats, Korean diplomats and social partners. Because we met with social partners. Besides, I also organized a conference here in the European Parliament, where the positions and opinions of everyone - entrepreneurs, politicians and social partners - could be presented. I appreciate this conversation very much. However, it is worth saying a few words regarding commercial contracts in general. We live in what I call the globalization of prosperity, as opposed to the globalization of poverty that has practically embraced the Earth for decades or hundreds of years. This welfare globalization is characterized by the equalization of civilization development in the world, equalization of development between the North and the South of the world. If I say civilization, I mean not only economic and economic development, but also social development, the one that serves everyone living in the world. One of the instruments - who knows or not the most important - of achieving these good goals are trade agreements and international agreements. We should continue this path.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The discussion is over.The vote will take place tomorrow.Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Sandra Kalniete (PPE)
text: in writing. – The trade agreement between the EU and Korea is the first of the ‘new generation’ of the EU’s FTAs – a good example for the upcoming agreement. It entered into force in 2015 and has already successfully boosted EU-Korea trade exchanges. For the EU, exports increased by 47% and turned the EUR 7.6 bn EU trade deficit into a EUR 2.5 bn surplus.  On the occasion of the 5th anniversary of the FTA, the EPP Group shares not only the positive impacts of the FTA, but also acknowledges that the Trade and Sustainable Development chapter of the agreement does not fully meet expectations in line with EU values in terms of the trade policy. It is important to respect the International Labour Rights Convention and to further address a number of issues in the field of technical barriers in trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, intellectual property rights and rules of origin as well as newly created non-tariff barriers for European car manufacturers. It is also crucial to raise awareness among SMEs regarding the opportunities that the agreement has created. We support further deepening of trade and investment relations between the EU and Korea.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: in writing. - We are talking today about a free trade agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Korea, which is very important for the European economy. This is the first of a new generation of free trade agreements that the EU has concluded with its Asian partner. Importantly, this agreement includes, in addition to the elimination of tariffs, provisions on the removal of non-tariff barriers, creating new market access opportunities in the services and investment sectors, as well as in areas such as intellectual property, public procurement and competition policy. This agreement will therefore serve as a model for future free trade agreements. The implementation of this agreement should be supported as it favors EU entrepreneurs. Let us not forget that we have 2.5 billion with this country. EUR trade surplus. Further deepening of trade and investment relations between the EU and Korea, in particular under the investment chapter of the FTA, is very welcome. In this case, it should be noted that during the negotiations, the Commission would not apply the old method of resolving investor-state disputes, but would create a new system of investment courts in line with the proposal that has already been discussed in this House. In the long run, a multilateral system of investment courts could replace all investment dispute settlement systems in current and future free trade agreements. An agreement with Korea could be the start of this system.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the preliminary question (O-000037/2017) to the Commission on the state of progress in implementing the Sustainability Pact in Bangladesh (RSP 2017/2636) (B8-0217 / 2017).

name: Bernd Lange
text: Author. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! We are all still appalled by what happened in the accident in Rana Plaza in Bangladesh and many other accidents in Bangladesh, where people who produce textiles for us are putting their lives and their integrity at risk. That is why it was right and necessary that we acted together after the Rana Plaza disaster and launched the Sustainablility Compact, also accompanied by the Accord agreement, so that it is ensured that there are improvements in working conditions in Bangladesh. Tomorrow is the third follow-up meeting on the Compact and I hope it will be a success. But it can only be a success if a clear agreement is reached about how to proceed, and that is one of the reasons why we are here today. Without a doubt, there has been progress with the Compact. We have seen a change in the labor code. New unions have been formed. I believe that especially in view of the question of wages and working conditions, the question of the possibilities of collective bargaining is of course crucial in order to achieve improvements. We have seen an increase in the minimum wage, and thanks to the Accord, we have also achieved inspections and improvements in building security in 1,700 factories, including with regard to the fire problem. So there we have taken steps. Of course, the international labor organization admonishes us to see here too that there are still major shortcomings. Thankfully, the Commission made this very clear in a letter. In this respect, it cannot be, in my opinion, that on the one hand Bangladesh uses the possibilities of the tariff preferences of the LDC very skilfully - they have also had growth rates of 6.6% in the last three years - but on the other hand the obligations that indeed not fulfilled by our GSP system with regard to the recognition of employee rights. In the resolution on the textile industry in the last plenary session, we once again made it very clear that we also expect that we can create more binding rules here for compliance with sustainability criteria or due diligence, in accordance with the OECD guidelines, and that our system of preferences will also change oriented more towards the question of compliance with employee rights. We have to reflect on that too if there is no progress. It cannot be that we tolerate everything within the framework of LDCs. Ultimately, Parliament must then also draw conclusions. In this respect, there are a few problem areas: What about employee rights in the special export zones? There is now a movement that the government is apparently reconsidering the legislation, but we need clarity that there cannot be two classes of labor law. We must also deal with the difficulties of registering trade unions and also the issue of work in factories and recognition. And of course the repression that has happened against trade unionists and others in Bangladesh is not acceptable. So our question is indeed: How can we improve the implementation? How can we ensure that the ILO comments are implemented? And I also believe that we need to extend the Accord beyond May 2018 because the work is not yet done. So our questions to the Commission.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for putting this question on the agenda and thank you for your support for the Compact and your concerns for Bangladesh.  As you know, the Commission is fully committed to addressing respect for international labour standards, also in EU trade policy. We can use different instruments to do that, we have our trade and investment agreements, we have the GSP, we have specific partnerships, we have different works and we have this Compact.  I do share your concerns when it comes to labour rights and the lack of respect for them in Bangladesh. The International Labour Organization included a special paragraph on Bangladesh in its report last year on freedom of association and collective bargaining, and this is a serious warning. I also welcome that Members from this House have visited Bangladesh; the message that you passed on is very powerful and it pushes and puts the issue on the agenda. It has also created awareness, which is very important, and it is contributing to some movement by the Bangladeshi Government. I also share the goal, of course, that the Bangladeshi Government fully respect workers’ fundamental rights.  Turning to the specific questions raise here by Mr Lange and others. There have been some positive signals from Bangladesh on the labour front. They include, for instance, the Tripartite Agreement of February and the fact that the draft export processing zones law, which was not in line with the ILO Convention, has been taken back. That is a positive signal. This Tripartite Coordination Council is a platform for dialogue between social partners. It seems to have been tasked to review the whole labour law and that is also a positive signal. We should welcome this and recognise it.  At the same time, there are still questions about the prolongation of the accords mandate. There seems to be a general acceptance that we need to continue the work beyond 2018 in one form or another, but this of course is not enough. We need to have more and continuous improvement, and significant work is still needed.  What we will do tomorrow, as Mr Lange referred to, is the follow-up meeting of the High—Level Sustainability Compact Group. It will provide an opportunity to take stock of where we are and how we see future prospects. We have made it very clear to the Bangladeshi authorities that we expect them to take urgent progress on respect for labour rights. This cannot happen overnight, but there needs to be a strategy that is clear and transparent and with time bounds. This strategy needs to address freedom of association and collective bargaining. It should be a priority to have speedy and efficient trade unions registrations, as well as making sure that there is investigation and prosecutions of all acts of discrimination and violence against trade unionists. At the same time, we should foresee to revise the Bangladesh Labour Act and the law on the export processing zones in line with ILO conventions. Furthermore, the strategy should facilitate private sector investor initiatives so that they can be more involved, as in the accord.  In addition to ensuring the accord mandate and that it can be reviewed and renewed, we are also looking for ways to facilitate and to support dialogue among brands and their suppliers on responsible business conduct. We are exploring the possibility to organise technical workshops in cooperation with the OECD on garment due diligence guidance, with specific focus on purchasing practices. We will have to rely primarily on international bodies such as the ILO which are specialised in this matter to assess the actions of the Bangladeshi Government. The Compact remains a very important framework for engaging with Bangladesh, together with the other international partners on labour rights. If sufficient progress is not registered within a reasonable timeframe, the Commission will need to see what other actions it can take. We have tools we can use such as the GSP Regulation, and as you know the GSP Regulation in fact foresees temporary withdrawal of trade preferences in case of serious and systematic violation of human and labour rights. So that is a tool that we have, but I hope that that we do not have to use it and that we will see progress in Bangladesh. I hope that the meeting tomorrow will bring some advancement, but we will have to monitor this very, very closely. Thank you for this debate, thank you for the question and thank you for your engagement on this. I think if we work together and send the same strong message then we can hopefully convey this to the Bangladeshi authorities.

name: Fernando Ruas
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, first of all a word of appreciation to Mr Karim for the work done. This sustainability pact was signed in 2013, following the tragic accident that occurred at Rana Plaza in April of that same year. It is worth mentioning and remembering that more than 1 100 people died while working in this building and that is why, as European politicians, we must do everything to ensure that such a tragedy does not happen again. In that sense, this debate before the meeting in Dhaka tomorrow, as well as the resolution that we will vote on later, seemed quite appropriate. Dear Commissioner, I would like to ask you, and through the whole Commission, with the certainty that you will do so, that you do not lose heart in the work you are doing jointly with the Government of Bangladesh and the international organizations involved. I also ask that, when there is some relaxation in compliance with what has been previously agreed, put more pressure on the competent authorities to ensure that this commitment is fulfilled. We believe that international institutions, in particular the ILO, but also the private sector, should continue their work in improving the general conditions of workers in this country and the truth, and thankfully, is that there are many people vigilant about this achievement on the ground measures contained in this pact. It is that, despite the progress made in favor of general working conditions, particularly the safety of buildings, facts for which we are very pleased and in particular the Government of Bangladesh, we consider that these tangible benefits that have been verified, as, indeed, come reported in the annual evaluations carried out, have to continue and have to be expanded because, in fact, in recent months, we have not seen significant progress regarding workers' rights. It is therefore necessary to amend the labor law to include expressions freedoms of association and collective bargaining, which are contained in the ILO conventions.A serious and respectful rule of law is also needed.For this reason, we ask the Government of Bangladesh to fight corruption, to prevent arbitrary arrests, and we also call for possible investigations or impartial trials by its police and judicial authorities.I conclude, just by calling attention to the need for the laws that regulate the so-called industrial free zones for export to comply with accepted international standards and for all alleged abuses reported against union members to be properly investigated.

name: Agnes Jongerius
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, it is now four years since the Sustainability Compact was launched and we have to face the fact that Bangladeshi labour conditions are still quite bad and in some cases, for instance on trade union rights, are even deteriorating. Fortunately, the Commission recognises this as well, and the letter sent to the Ambassador of Bangladesh in Brussels by DG EMPL, DG DEVCO and DG TRADE gave the country notice that it had until 18 May to make sufficient, substantial and meaningful progress, together with a sound and time-limited strategy on several stated labour law shortcomings. Failure to do so would result in an official DSP investigation. It is 18 May tomorrow, and it has come to my – and your – attention that up to now the Bangladeshi Government has repealed the EPZ laws, but has made no other substantial moves whatsoever. We are of course some hours ahead of 18 May, but I would like to ask the Commission: what will happen after tomorrow when no further results follow? Are you going to repeat the suggestions in the Commission’s letter sent two months ago?

name: Sajjad Karim
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, it is always a pleasure to see  Commissioner Malmström in the Chamber. Madam Commissioner, I very much welcome the very open way in which you deal with trade matters in terms of this Parliament and the transparency that we get.  Bangladesh really is a story with two sides to it. One side is a matter for which we, as the European Union, and certainly this Parliament, can feel tremendously proud. We have played our role in helping development, making sure that some of the most disadvantaged people in Bangladeshi society today find themselves in a situation where they can earn an honest living with pride, and this is something which this House really has invested in greatly.  When one looks at the tremendous achievements that have been made, then one has to look at where we are today. It is quite clear to me that Bangladesh, the Government of Bangladesh, is either not listening, or choosing not to listen, or it is not understanding what we are saying. That is why I intend simply to pass on a very clear message today. It is not to deal with the details, as the Commission is dealing with that, but it is simply to say to Bangladesh that we do not want to see a situation where, from the clutches of victory and tremendous achievement, you deliver a negative result. We have done all that we can to make sure that the doors remain open for you. Please take that message today and react in a positive way, so that we can carry on with our journey of progress.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr. president. Well, indeed, four years ago - four - of Rana Plaza. And Bangladeshi workers, especially those in the textile sector, continue to experience a dramatic situation, even though many try to paint another painting. Freedom of association, freedom of expression and opinion are now non-existent in Bangladesh, and there are numerous arbitrary arrests, extortion and torture of trade unionists, opponents and human rights defenders. The Commission cannot continue to be negligent, although I am very pleased with the words of the Commissioner, but it should immediately initiate an investigation for the violation of international conventions on human and labor rights. In addition, we note with concern how voluntary initiatives for the sustainability of the textile sector do not work, they are unable to stop abuses. For this reason, just a few weeks ago, more than five hundred Members of this House demanded that the Commission propose binding legislation on due diligence in textile chains. Get going now, please.

name: Heidi Hautala
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to wish the Commissioner plenty of strength for the meeting tomorrow when the Commission will be discussing progress on the commitments that have been made by Bangladesh. There is a clear list of demands from the European Union. Commissioner, would you agree that, in the event that no conceivable progress is made in the commitments and the demands, there would be the prospect that the Commission could turn to the ILO and ask for an investigation into the breaches of international labour law. At the end of the day, I think we should take this new Compact very seriously as it is an admirable effort to promote value—based supply chains. But, if the other party does not live up to expectations, I believe some conclusions must be reached.  Secondly, I would like to mention that 500 Members have indeed called for binding, mandatory measures on due diligence for international companies. I believe that we should repeat that demand because it is something that is needed in order to have a level playing field.

name: Angelo Ciocca
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the week of my friend Gianluca Buonanno's birthday I want to use Gianluca's communication technique and I say, dear colleagues, dormant Europe, open your eyes! Opening your eyes is the watchword on this issue. Wake up, wake up, wake up! It is enough to be at the service of the interests of multinationals, multinationals that have shown, with the complicity of this Europe, that they have killed in Italy, but not only, the excellent manufacturing sector. Multinationals that to go to produce in other countries have decided to speculate on situations that are there for all to see, situations of slavery but also situations of child exploitation, children who work for twelve, thirteen, fourteen hours a day for 2 euros a day without any kind of protection, rules in the workplace, it is unacceptable. If Europe does not want to continue being complicit with these multinational "borrowers" and does not want to be complicit in these numerous deaths at work, it must, and I stress must, stop the entry into Europe of these illegal products. Products made without respecting the rules for the worker are illegal products.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! It is a pity that such great tragedies as the one that happened in Bangladesh sometimes lead to changes in the field of human rights, respect for workers' rights, including in particular the provisions of the health and safety at work. Fortunately, the agreement between Bangladesh and the European Union, as well as the United States and the International Labor Organization, improved the situation to some extent. Amendments were made to the Bangladeshi Labor Act of 2006, and over 2,500 workplaces were inspected. It is important to know that 32 factories were closed, over 300 trade unions were registered, employment in labor inspection institutions was increased, but also in the fire service, civil protection and development authorities. These are all very good, positive effects of the action of the European Union, but also the effects of the concluded agreement. Importantly, the companies themselves also got involved, and this is fundamental. Of course, the repair process is not complete. The repair process must be continued and it will not be easy. But you also have to remember that the jobs that companies provide in countries such as Bangladesh save millions, and tens of millions of people worldwide. Tens of millions of families are protected against unemployment, against lack of food, against hunger, and against poverty. Therefore, we must take these important solutions responsibly, so as to save and help people in poor countries, and at the same time not to kill the industry that gives them a chance to live.

name: Linda McAvan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for pursuing this issue. When we went to Bangladesh it was very clear that access to our market is a huge issue in Bangladesh. As the Chair of the Development Committee, of course I welcome the fact that tens of thousands of workers – particularly women – are gaining a livelihood and making their lives better because they have access to our market. But we also met trade unionists, and they told us about the difficulties they face trying to organise in the workplace, and the serious intimidation. So we welcome what you have done so far, and the letter from your services to the Ambassador in Brussels, because it is important to remind the Bangladeshi authorities that the EBA is not just a technical agreement. It is underpinned by our values, and that includes respect for rights at work. I have got a couple of additional questions. The first is about even-handedness. This kept coming up time and time again in Bangladesh. It is in no one’s interests to withdraw trade access from Bangladesh, only to see business move to countries where conditions are equally bad or even worse than in Bangladesh. So what reassurances can you give us about the Commission’s future trade agreements with other countries, that they will be similarly tough in making sure people comply with ILO standards and other human rights obligations? Secondly, responsibility of our companies: you cannot get investment in jobs and improving people’s lives unless people get a decent price for the goods that they manufacture. We had the report voted in Parliament last month. The Commission has now adopted your new sustainable garment value chains initiative. What is really going to happen? Are you going to do more? What more is the Commission going to do now to make sure that actually fair prices can be paid for goods from Bangladesh and similar countries for their garments?

name: Jean Lambert (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I would also like to thank the Commissioner for her ongoing interest and commitment to the issue of the ready-made garment sector, not least in Bangladesh, and I am speaking here in my role as Chair of Parliament’s Delegation for relations with the countries of South Asia, and we have followed the Sustainability Compact from the start. This was seen by many as a positive innovative response to the problem so brutally exposed by the Rana Plaza tragedy and indeed has been seen as a potential model for engagement with other governments, because I take the point that Linda McAvan has just made, that Bangladesh is not the only country with problems.  I think many of us would welcome the engagement of the Bangladeshi Government over the years with the Compact, but we want to see that engagement renewed and regenerated because this gives an opportunity for Bangladesh to actually be a leader in terms of sound trades union activity, good social dialogue, responsible production; just as we on our side ought to keep our side of the bargain about responsible supply chains so that we know we are not putting people’s lives at risk to clothe us.

name: Arne Lietz (S&D).
text: -  Mister President! As part of an S&D delegation to Bangladesh in March, I was able to see for myself that the working conditions in the textile and shoe factories have only improved significantly in terms of the structural standards. Trade unionists were arrested on short notice in late 2016 and the standards of the International Labor Organization are still being violated. Our S&D delegation called for these standards to be implemented on site and thus perfectly complemented the Commission's communication. I of course welcome the sustainability pact and am very excited about the outcome of tomorrow's meeting. I am particularly interested in the question of how the Commission, as a co-signatory of the pact, will continue to contribute to its implementation. I would like to remind the Commission again of Parliament's own-initiative report on supply chains in the clothing sector, which was adopted at the end of April. In this report, the European Parliament is calling for a legislative proposal from the Commission that will finally establish mandatory compliance with due diligence along the supply chain. In addition to the sustainability pact, this legislative initiative could contribute to better working conditions in the producing countries including Bangladesh.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, we have repeatedly dealt with the labor jungle in Bangladesh, where young children work for ten to twelve hours. Where labor laws are brutally violated. Where hundreds of workers have been burned alive, in Rana Plaza. Where the European multinationals, after closing the textiles in Europe, built factories, where thousands of workers work for a piece of bread. Bangladesh is not going to comply, rest assured. We will be ridiculed by both the Bangladeshi government and the multinationals. They will play hide and seek. The only solution is to ban the import of clothing and other textiles from Bangladesh. Take measures to revive the European textile industry, by providing a special regime for this sector, both in Greece and in the other countries of the European South.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - I listened very carefully to your answer to the question asked, thank you for it. I am very pleased that you want to stand so strongly for labor law in Bangladesh. The EU is a defender of human rights, and for me personally, fundamental labor rights are as important as the right to freedom of expression or the right of assembly or other political rights. We should not underestimate this issue. That is why it is good that we are discussing labor law issues in Bangladesh here in Parliament. I admit that, after studying all the documents, I am a little skeptical that the Bangladeshi Government would like to hear the Commission's initiative and letters and calls and respond and correct collective individual labor law in Bangladesh. So I will keep my fingers crossed for you at tomorrow's meeting, and I hope that, if nothing changes after 18 May, the European Commission will be able to intervene vigorously and clearly and will not end with more diplomatic promises and other mere letters.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all Members. This is indeed an extremely important issue. I would like to thank you for your strong engagement. We share your goals and we will work as hard as possible in our engagement with the Bangladeshi Government because we of course want decent working conditions there. As many of you have said, the Compact is actually something quite unique. It has not only raised awareness, but has engaged countries, companies and civil society, and has led to some improvements – not enough, but some improvements. European and other companies that did not really engage in this have started to engage and to work with corporate social responsibility. They are working with regard to inspections, improving rights and making sure that what they produce and then sell is sustainable. This has led to a lot of improvement, but – as you all pointed out – it is far from enough. The Bangladeshi Government needs to do so much more. It is true that there have been a few positive signals, but not enough. There will be a meeting tomorrow. Let us be fair and listen to our Bangladeshi partners; let us see what they are planning and whether they have the strategy that we have asked for. Let us discuss this in friendship and openness with them. We have said before – and I reiterate it again – that there are measures that we can take if we see that no progress is being made, or even that the situation is deteriorating. We are ready to take them, but we cannot threaten that today, before the meeting. The meeting is tomorrow. Let us give it a chance. We have other means as well.  We have made it extremely clear to them that the four ILO recommendations, namely: to amend the Labour Act in order to bring it into compliance with ILO conventions; secondly, to ensure that the law on export processing zones allows for full freedom of association; to make sure that all acts of anti-trade union discrimination are investigated and prosecuted at a later stage; and to ensure that applications for trade union registrations are acted upon as quickly as possible and not denied unless there are really objective grounds for doing so. These are the four most urgent recommendations and we fully support ILO in their work there. When it comes to due diligence, such as with the conflict mineral agreement that we have – which we should be extremely proud of – it is more complicated with the garment sector. We are working very closely, not only with the ILO but also on the OECD, to develop the due diligence guidelines for this sector. So the priority now, on a short—term basis, is to make them materialise and to make sure that they work in practice. Garment supply chains are fragmented and complex. There is a lot of diversity and a number of actors all across the world, so doing this will be extremely complicated. We already have legislation on corporate social responsibility and responsible business conduct. We also have the non—financial disclosure directive for some large EU companies, which also apply to the garment sector. We are working with ILO and looking at what we can do with other partners in the region to support change, to train them, to encourage them, and to organise meetings in order to connect the different actors in the region. So technically and politically, there is outreach and engagement.  This has led to some results. We will continue to do this. I look forward, in close cooperation with you, to continue to see how we can jointly apply pressure and make sure that there is improvement for the workers, the labour organisations and, ultimately, the people. Most of them in this area are, of course, young women and girls. They still need us to be there and to continue this fight for them. Thank you for your engagement. I am sure we will come back to this issue before very long.

name: Presidente. –
text: The discussion is closed.The vote will take place during the June part-session.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is, for joint discussion, - the recommendation of the Committee on International Trade on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union, Iceland, the Principality of Liechtenstein and the Kingdom of Norway on an EEA financial mechanism for 2014-2021, of the agreement between the Kingdom of Norway and the European Union on a Norwegian financial mechanism for the period 2014-2021, of the Additional Protocol to the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Kingdom of Norway and the Additional Protocol to the Agreement between the European Economic Community and Iceland (06679/2016 - C8-0175 / 2016 - 2016/0052 (NLE)) (A8-0072 / 2017) (rapporteur: David Borrelli), and - the question with request for an oral answer to the Commission on the increase of Norwegian duties on agricultural products / recent negotiations on the protocol on fish trade, by Bernd Lange, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade rnational (O-000023/2017 - B8-0215 ​​/ 2017).

name: Bernd Lange
text: Author. - Mister President! Commissioner Hogan, nice to see you here in plenary. This is always a pleasure for me. Tonight we are talking about relations with Norway, and there we have two threads that we have to discuss: One is Norway's decision to apply ad valorem tariffs of 200 to 400% on cheese, lamb and beef to raise. They did that back in 2013, and since then we have been calling for something to be done. We made this very clear in a resolution by Parliament on July 4, 2013, but nothing has happened yet. In this respect, the second strand, which we are also discussing tonight - Mr Borrelli is here as rapporteur - namely financial relations, the financial mechanism from 2014 to 2021 and a Fish Protocol, is on the agenda, although we are dealing with the first strand have not yet resolved. And of course that started some reflection processes in us. How can it be that on the one hand we have a conflict and on the other hand we conclude an agreement where we work very closely together? And therefore the question: what will the Commission and the External Action Service actually do to finally find a solution? We find it really difficult to give consent to the financial mechanisms if the customs issue has not been resolved beforehand. Hence the second question: What specific expectations and measures are there to find a solution, quasi in the context of the financial mechanisms, and are the Commission and the External Action Service really convinced that different negotiations can actually lead to success? That is the substantive story where we in the Committee on Trade, as the committee responsible, got a little brooding, Commissioner Hogan. And we also have a second thing, it's more about the formal work: we negotiate especially with the Commission and the Council on an interinstitutional agreement that is intended to ensure that the provisions of the Treaty, that Parliament is fully informed in the same way as the Council, are also implemented, and that there can be no provisional application of an agreement before that European Parliament has not decided. And that does not seem to us to be guaranteed with the Norway Agreement with regard to the financial mechanism and the fisheries agreement. That is why we have also said here: Do we really want to give consent now if this obligation, which in our opinion clearly arises from the contract, is not met? There are now signs that there is an improvement, and of course we do not want to hold Norway virtually liable for a case for which the Commission and the Council are responsible. But we have to address the problem. We must ensure that Parliament and the Council are given equal information and that there is no provisional application of agreements of any kind before the European Parliament, as the democratically elected body of the European Union, has given its approval.

name: David Borrelli
text: speaker. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I, of course, as you rightly pointed out, will only deal with the question of the agreement. Of course, I totally agree with what has just been said on the question of tariffs, but I will concentrate much more on the question of the agreement. This is an agreement on the European Economic Area, known as the EEA Agreement, of 1994, which allows the participation in the single market of Norway, Iceland and Lichtenstein, members of the EFTA. The EFTA countries have contributed since 1994 to reducing economic and social disparities within the EEA through a dedicated financial mechanism, complemented by a further contribution from Norway. These financial mechanisms, which expired in 2014, need to be renewed as well as the protocols concerning the fish trade. Today, therefore, at this stage we are examining four acts, or two agreements relating to financial mechanisms, one between the EU and Iceland, Lichtenstein and Norway, and one between Norway and the European Union, and two protocols on fisheries, one between the EU and Norway and the other between the EU and Iceland. These agreements will jointly provide a financial contribution for economic and social cohesion of the EEA amounting to 2.8 billion euros in the period from 2014 to 2021. This framework, which has so far been beneficial for the European Union, must be included in a political reflection broader than our EU-EFTA relations. There are no particular problems with Liechtenstein and Iceland, indeed with Iceland we will soon start discussing new agricultural agreements with Iceland in the INTA commission and here we will have to pay attention to the fact that Iceland still has a free trade agreement with China. , so we want to emphasize this aspect too. With Norway, as has rightly been said a moment ago, the issue is more sensitive due to some duties imposed on European meats and cheeses. This practice definitely has slowed down the process of the dossier and also gave rise to the oral question that is under discussion today, presented by the president. Political and economic relations between the EU and Norway have always been pretty good, but the issue of tariffs in recent years has been a vulnus in our trade relations, as has rightly been said. Norway is the fifth trading partner of the European Union in terms of imports and the seventh destination for the European Union in terms of exports. Strengthening our trade relations with Norway is obviously important, but these developments must take place in full compliance with the objectives of the EEA Agreement. We know that negotiations are underway between the EU and Norway for some liberalization of trade in agricultural products; these are favorable news which, however, should be accompanied by the quick removal of the duties that have been imposed for years. This removal must be a priority for both parties and thus contribute to strengthening commercial relations which are, fortunately, already strong. The European Union exports 4.1 billion euros of agricultural products to Norway and imports 488 million euros. Equally important is the import of fish products, which amounts to 5.6 billion euros. I therefore close by thanking my colleagues for the work done in the International Trade Committee and the colleagues who will now speak for their ideas, hoping that here too we can count on a broad consensus for this agreement.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I am here, of course, as you realise, on behalf of High Representative Mogherini, but also on behalf of Ms Mogherini and myself I wish to welcome the opportunity to contribute to this joint debate on the European Union-Norway Agreement. I am pleased to share with you our views on the agreement itself between the European Union, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway on the EEA Financial Mechanism 2014-2021 and the increase of Norwegian duties on agricultural products, which has been mentioned by both speakers. The Financial Mechanisms have played an important role in reducing social and economic disparities in the European Economic Area since the entry into force of the EEA Agreement in 1994. In addition, as of 2004, Norway has set up a complementary bilateral financial mechanism as well. But I would like to acknowledge the positive recommendation of the rapporteur, Mr Borrelli, to the plenary, in order to give its consent to the conclusion of the relevant agreements and protocols. In view of the continued need to alleviate economic and social disparities within the EEA, in particular after the 2008-2009 financial crisis, the EEAS and the Commission received an ambitious negotiating mandate in January 2014 not only to renew the EEA-Norway grants, but to substantially increase them. The EEA and Norway Financial Mechanism agreements were signed on 3 May 2016 and have been provisionally applied as of July and August of 2016. These grants will provide a financial contribution by the EEA EFTA states of EUR 2.8 billion for a seven-year period 2014 to 2021, which is an increase of 11.2%. This includes a special allocation of EUR 100 million for promoting regional cooperation in order to fight youth unemployment. The European Union cohesion key will be used for the distribution of the financial allocations of both EEA and Norway grants. The Commission will have a stronger role in strategic planning by promoting complementarity and synergies with EU Cohesion Policy. The agreements on the EEA and Norway grants have been complemented by two other separate bilateral agreements with Norway and Iceland. Their aim is to renew existing preferential trade access to EU markets for their fish and fishery products. These concessions were in place in the period 2009-2014 and have now been renewed with a modest improvement in trade access. Furthermore, Norway has agreed to continue allowing for free transit of fish and fishery products landed in Norway from vessels flying the flag of a Member State of the European Union. The outcome of these negotiations and the provisional applications of these agreements were commended by all Member States, notably in the December 2016 Council Conclusions on the extended single market. The successful outcome of these negotiations would not have been possible without the tireless political support and interest by the Members of this House. You have regularly used the joint EEA Norway and Iceland parliamentary committees to call for an immediate and successful conclusion of these negotiations. Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway are part of our European continent and we share the same space, but also the same principled interest: to make growth in Europe more inclusive and sustainable. We have a responsibility to work together with our neighbours, strengthening a spirit of European solidarity and cooperation beyond the borders of our Union. So I want to thank you Members for raising the issue of the increase of Norwegian duties on agricultural products, and for the very keen interest which this House has shown in it, as evidenced by the resolution that has been adopted. In order to reflect your concerns, I want to assure you and reassure you that the Commission and the EEAS have done all they can to address the situation following the changes in Norwegian duties on certain cheeses, on lamb and beef products, from 1 January 2013. The issue has been raised at a number of high-level meetings, including at the highest political level. In fact, in 2015 the Commission requested the Norwegian authorities to include this issue in the EU-Norway agricultural trade liberalisation negotiations. These negotiations were concluded just five weeks ago, on 5 April 2017. Under the negotiated agreement, the Norwegian authorities will grant the European Union tariff-free quotas to compensate for the effects of the duty switch. The Commission is convinced that the deal we reached is beneficial to the European Union and that Norway provided sufficient compensation for the effects of the duty switch. The exact size of the compensation was detailed in the information paper that was sent to you, Mr Lange, and your committee at the beginning of April. The Agreement will formally be submitted to the European Parliament for your consent at a later stage, which I hope can be forthcoming. With that consent, the Council can then formally conclude the negotiations (it cannot do so before that) in order to allow the Agreement to come into force. As with Norway, another additional protocol was negotiated for fisheries originating in Iceland. Both EEA partners have made conditional their contribution of funds to the last three EEA Financial Mechanisms, upon obtaining temporary fish trade concessions. No other trade concessions or considerations, such as the improved market access for agricultural products or for the solving of the pending trade irritants, have to date been linked with the Financial Mechanism negotiations. Thank you for attention and I hope that this information is useful to you.

name: Artis Pabriks
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I think that this discourse and discussion today, at 10 o’clock in the evening, could very well have been spared if cooperation between Parliament and the Commission were better. I really very much and sincerely hope that what is happening now, regarding the Agreement on the European Economic Area (EEA) and the discussion between the Commission and this Parliament, is not a pattern of passivity on the part of the Commission, firstly in defending the interests of European nations and the European Union and, secondly, in having a respectful attitude towards this Parliament.  These are two major complaints from the European People’s Party (PPE). We were not satisfied, Commissioner, with your proposal, or the fact that you have already been going on with this agreement without prior consultation with us. You are putting us in the position, in the current political circumstances, where we are speaking about the irrelevance of Parliament and, at the same time, you are trying to drive us into a discussion where you are presenting – this evening too – everything that has already been mentioned in the explanatory statement. We already knew all that!  Secondly, I think the pattern that we see here can also be seen in the passivity of the Commission regarding activities in the Arctic area and in the Commission office responsible for international affairs. We also see that in cases where we need to defend, for instance, our fishermen, who have already been arrested for half a year in Norwegian ports. So in this regard, we really would like to see in future a much more proactive and cooperative role from the Commission side, otherwise it will be very difficult for us to cooperate.  It has nothing to do with Norway, in this case. It is to do with you not responding in a timely fashion, and not defending in a timely fashion the interests which we are asking you to defend.

name: Nicola Danti
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I believe that the agreements between the European Union and Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein that we are called to ratify tomorrow are an excellent example of collaboration between our Union and the countries of the European Economic Area. These agreements will provide, as mentioned above, a total contribution of 2.8 billion euros to the European Union for the period 2014-2021, with an increase of 11.3 per cent compared to the previous period. The funds will be directed towards those areas of the European Union where social and economic disparities clearly persist, with the aim of strengthening economic and social cohesion, always favoring a better functioning of the single market, to which Iceland, the Liechtenstein and Norway participate fully. Among the priority areas of investment, I would like to highlight that relating to youth employment and that relating to justice and home affairs, which therefore includes strategic sectors such as asylum and migration. It should also be emphasized that compared to the previous period these resources can also be assigned to those countries that in 2013 had a youth unemployment rate higher than 25 per cent. With respect to the question raised by the oral question, it will be crucial to find a quick solution as the imposition of increased duties by Norway on certain European products clearly violates the spirit and letter of this agreement. Finally, allow me a consideration, President. In post-Brexit debates there has been a lot of talk about the possibility for the UK to adopt the Norwegian model of participation in the European Union. We agree, contributing financially to the European Union and accepting its four fundamental freedoms are sufficient criteria to open the doors to our single market, as is the case with Norway and other countries, but it does not seem that this is the path that the British government wants to take and they will soon realize that, as our dear colleague said in the aftermath of the referendum, the best possible agreement for the United Kingdom is the one we already have.

name: Czesław Hoc
text: on behalf of the ECR Group.- Mr Chairman!The protocol on trade in fish and fishery products, as well as the Norwegian Financial Mechanism, are very important and necessary for European Union countries, including Poland as a country that is the largest importer of raw fish from Norway in the European Union.Therefore, measures to facilitate the flow of goods from Norway to the European Union as well as increasing duty-free tariff quotas are welcomed.Poland supports efforts that contribute to the elimination of barriers and thus ensure easier flow of fish products from Norway to the markets of the European Union countries.In addition, under the Norwegian financial mechanisms, we hope to establish closer and measurable cooperation in the field of scientific research in the field of fisheries management.

name: Jasenko Selimovic
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, allow me to start by congratulating Norwegians on their National Day: ‘Gratulerer med dagen, Norge’. But, when it comes to the topic ‘liberalisation of trade’ there is no reason for congratulations. The EEA Agreement was signed in 1994. Since then, talks on liberalisation of trade in agricultural products have been slow and with no genuine engagement by the Norwegian side. On the contrary, during these talks, in 2013 Norway drastically increased import duties for EU products – 280% on cheese, 430% on sheep meat, and 350% on beef. So if you buy a hot dog – a lamb sausage – in Oslo, it will cost you about EUR 2, but if the lamb comes from the EU, it will cost you EUR 10, five times more. On top of that, there is a new import duty of 70% on hortensia flowers from the EU. Seventy! Do not even think of buying flowers for your girlfriend if she is Norwegian. Love has a very high price in Norway. I have to say to my fellow Norwegians, that if you respect your commitments and decrease import duties, I can promise you that the world will not go under. The sun will still rise in the morning. The lakes will be fresh and clean – era fjorder underbara – and you will still be able to eat your brunost since we have do not have any intention of buying it, whatever the price might be. If you do not care about us as a partner, please care about your citizens, who already pay some of the highest food prices in the world. Do not make it even more expensive.  I would therefore sincerely like to encourage both the Commission and our Norwegian partners to show a more flexible, constructive and swift approach in order to settle this longstanding issue.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Commissioner! I think the excitement of some colleagues is inappropriate. We should start this debate differently: first, we should recognize Norway's great financial commitment to helping to reduce the poverty gap within Europe. And we should make it clear that we are aware of this contribution, especially in the current situation in connection with the Brexit negotiations. We should recognize consideration for market access and contributions in the now updated agreement, which are regulated there. Customs lines on which no agreement could be reached can legitimately be increased and decreased by Norway, as with all other trade relations. So it's a matter of negotiation. The EEA Council has just confirmed that further liberalization of agricultural trade remains the goal. So everyone seems to agree and there is no problem. At the same time, I could have understood a Norwegian position that, because of the particularly harsh natural conditions for farmers and fishermen in our partner country, would take an even more critical view of unrestricted agricultural trade. So: There is no alternative to sensible negotiation.

name: Bronis Ropė
text: On behalf of the Verts / ALE Group.- Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner.The financial mechanism of the European Economic Area is, I would say, an excellent instrument for bringing the communities of the new Member States of the European Union and Norway closer together, promoting cohesion and mutual understanding.I say this as a former mayor of a municipality who has experience in this work and in applying this mechanism.In Lithuania, as in other beneficiary countries, we have created an efficient system for the administration of the funds received, involving local government and civil society.This cooperation is also important for the other countries of the European Union, as its main goal - smart, sustainable and integrated growth, reducing economic and social disparities between the countries, contributes to the sustainable development of the whole continent.I therefore suggest that no new obstacles be created for him and that an agreement be reached as soon as possible.

name: John Stuart Agnew
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I am giving a speech on behalf of my colleague, William Dartmouth, who has had to return to the UK. I see I am not the only person engaged in substitution, as my old friend the Agriculture Commissioner is here substituting for another Commissioner, so I am setting a trend. In the UK, the Remain camp are obsessed with access to the single market. This is significant because this report talks about the entry fee that Norway must pay for such access. Clegg, Blair, Mandelson and other Europhiles tell us that the single market is so important that any price is worth paying to get into it. So what happens in Norway? They have been the lucky recipients of 12 000 directives and regulations. Some of these are exceeding the authority of the original agreement. A recent 56-page report by Nei til EU has found that the cost to Norway of this agreement has risen tenfold since 1992. It now costs them GBP 650 million a year for their five million people. In Norway, the polling company Sentio has found that 47% of Norwegians want a referendum on this agreement against 20% who do not. If Norway is having misgivings, Clegg and company should forget all about saddling the British with a bill that could approach GBP eight billion a year.

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE).
text: –Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! We are actually discussing two things today: One is an agreement that the European institutions have negotiated with Norway. We don't like some of the content. I can understand then that the Norwegian government has come very close to its limits, which it could approach, given the fact that it is a minority government. But I am convinced that the European Commission and the European External Action Service have completely neglected to involve us in Parliament closely in negotiating this agreement, to take us on board and also to point out the limits to the Norwegians, whom we as Parliament regularly address to have. What annoys me most is that we have a clear agreement between the European Parliament and our Foreign Trade Commissioner that no trade agreement can be put into effect on a provisional basis until the European Parliament has given its opinion. We don't have that sort of thing with the European External Action Service, and we don't have that sort of thing with the other Commissioners, but that this agreement is being applied provisionally, and a large part of this agreement is external trade agreements. To put it bluntly, it is insolence and unreasonableness what the European External Action Service and High Representative Mogherini expect us to do here. And I call on the Commission and call on the European External Action Service: for all future agreements, we expect that we can vote in good time, we expect that there will be no provisional application, and I can only call on them to really take that into account. The second: what Norway is doing is also not in the sense of the agreement. Massively increasing tariffs, imposing trade barriers on us, all of this without prior consultation - this must also be said to the Norwegians very clearly. The colleague Scholz is right, they make it formal nothing illegal, but that is not amicable, that is not announced, that is not voted on.Here, too, I can very well understand that many affected farmers, many affected entrepreneurs and, above all, many affected citizens in our Member States are annoyed about this.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, four years ago - and it has been said - Norway unilaterally decided to increase its tariffs on certain European agricultural products such as cheese or lamb meat and beef, which is contrary to the spirit of our agreement with this country. We, the Parliament, had asked that the Commission enter into negotiations with our Norwegian partner to find a mutually satisfactory solution. It is clear that Norway has kept its tariffs as they are. Four years after the introduction of these measures, I ask the Commission to communicate to us precisely, for each of the Member States, their consequences for European farmers. Moreover, failing today to have Norway come back on this decision, the Commission must at least make a firm commitment to protect our producers from this harmful situation and ensure that the losses suffered by our farmers are fully covered. compensated. The dispute must of course be resolved through dialogue, but agriculture must not, once again, be sacrificed on the altar of European trade policy.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, here in the European Parliament, we are outraged by the imposition of Norwegian ad valorem duties for certain products in 2013. These increases go against the spirit of good cooperation and the letter of the bilateral agreement with Norway, but this is not the only issue that sheds a bad light on relations between the European Union and Norway. I am referring to the unjustified and gradual appropriation of fish resources in the area of Spitsbergen and the preferential treatment of Norway, which does not respect the provisions of international agreements. This leads European fishermen into bankruptcy, as well as allowing Norway to disrespect and disregard the European Union as a partner. We cannot accept this. For the sake of respecting international law, for the sake of good mutual cooperation, and to protect European Union industry from bankruptcy, I ask the Commissioner to look for a mutually satisfactory solution to be put in place as soon as possible.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the funds associated with the European Economic Area mechanism are part of the contribution of Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein to participate fully in the European Union's Single Market. This mechanism has resulted in the development of important activities of scientific research and encouraging social inclusion in Member States of the European Union. So far, the relationship between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway has brought mutual benefits. Despite the benefits in the agreements related to trade and fish transit, Norway has been taking unilateral actions that cause us a lot of concern. These include disregarding the Svalbard Treaty. We heard the Norwegian Fisheries Minister in the European Parliament and his arguments did not convince us. The European Commission has my full support for ensuring equitable and environmentally sustainable access for Union fishermen to Svalbard waters.

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE).
text: - Sir. Chairman! The Commission has acted directly against the resolution we adopted on Norway in this House in 2013. It is with unparalleled arrogance. The Commission not only knew the decision, it only hurts worse, but acted directly against a political majority in this House. It's a scandal. As you know, Norway raised tariffs massively on cheese, lamb, steak and certain flowers. This was done unilaterally without any prior negotiations with the EU, which has hurt farmers in Germany, the Netherlands, Sweden and Denmark. It was an act directly against the spirit of Article 19 of the EEA Agreement. It was a unilateral protectionist move on the part of Norway. The Commission has the mandate to negotiate on behalf of the EU, but that responsibility has not been taken seriously, but simply accepted the violations and concluded a new agreement with Norway. The agreement entered into force without taking into account our decision in Parliament. The customs problem is unresolved. The Commission treats Parliament as a simple rubber stamp. Margaret Thatcher once called the European Parliament a Mickey Mouse Parliament. As guardian of the Treaty, the Commission has treated the European Parliament like a Mickey Mouse Parliament. The Commission has shown itself to be whistling indifferent to this Parliament in this matter. Had a Danish minister behaved like this in my country against the majority of Parliament, he would have been fired. Had it been officials, they would have been poured out of the office. I have not experienced anything like this through 25 years in my political life. There are people in the Commission who are probably suitable for something other than dealing with foreign trade cases. What will the Commission do to prevent this from happening again? Why has the Commission ignored the wishes of this House? Do you even acknowledge that you have made a mistake? I do not think so when I hear the speechwriter.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: - Sir. Chairman! Like most of my colleagues here tonight, I would like to endorse the criticism of the European Commission. Of course, it is fine for Norway to pay more to gain access to the EU's internal market, but the price for that has been far, far too high. In fact, the European Commission has now accepted that Norway may well have their very high tariff wall aimed at European agricultural products. That is unacceptable. This means that Norway can keep Funen hydrangeas out and North Jutland cheese, meat, and what else we have heard about here tonight. It is to the great detriment of trade, and it is completely contrary to the spirit of the EEA Agreement. So it's an ommer, Commission. Something needs to be done about this. You will have to put an end to Norway's customs wall. It's illegal. You will have to deliver, because this is unacceptable, and in addition you have also chosen to ignore this for several years. It was not in 2013, it was already in 2012 that this happened. My call to you is crystal clear: Take it easy now and solve this problem.
